summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Tottenham midfielder Andros Townsend after Townsend was subbed on in the 83rd minute of Tottenham’s 0‑0 draw with Burnley, prompting Merson to mock him on Twitter; the dispute began when Merson wrote in his Sky Sports column that Townsend’s inclusion in the England squad “opens it up to anybody,” a comment Townsend later retorted to after scoring England’s equaliser in a 1‑1 friendly with Italy, leading Merson to admit he was wrong and praise the goal, while both players continued to trade barbs on social media despite the tension seemingly easing.

Chelsea have formally offered FC Tokyo’s 22‑year‑old forward Yoshinori Muto a move this summer, with the Japanese international set to join Chelsea’s Dutch partner Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season if the transfer goes through; the bid, reportedly around £4 million, is unrelated to Chelsea’s recent £200 million sponsorship with Yokohama Rubber, and would make Muto the first Japanese player at the club. Muto, who has made 37 appearances and scored 16 goals for FC Tokyo, earned 11 caps and one goal for Japan, graduated with an economics degree from Keio University two weeks ago, and has continued strong form this season with three goals in four games, helping his team sit third in the J‑League. While he called the offer an honour, he has not yet decided whether to join the Premier League side. Yokohama Rubber will become Chelsea’s official shirt sponsor from the 2015‑16 season under a five‑year, £200 million deal, with a possible two‑week pre‑season tour of Japan being considered.

A large Finnish study of over 12,000 children found that infants who received antibiotics in their first six months, especially repeatedly before age two, were more likely to be overweight or obese by age two—affecting about one‑fifth of boys and one‑tenth of girls, with boys showing a stronger association and also being slightly taller; while the research does not prove causation, the authors suggest that antibiotics may disrupt gut bacteria that normally limit food absorption and increase appetite, and they warn that such early exposure could contribute to the broader childhood obesity epidemic and underscore the need for careful antibiotic use.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped on a manhole cover while taking position during the Changing of the Guard, causing him to slide sideways, knock his bearskin, drop his rifle and fall in front of hundreds of tourists; the incident was captured on video by tourist David Meadwell, who described the guard’s embarrassed reaction as he scrambled to his feet, and officials suggested the slip may have been caused by metal protectors on his boots, while the Ministry of Defence declined to comment.

A&E, Lifetime and History will simulcast a new version of the landmark miniseries “Roots” in 2016, updating the 1977 epic that drew over 100 million viewers; the remake, described as “original” and “contemporary,” will rely more closely on Alex Haley’s novel and involve scholars of African and African‑American history for authenticity, with original star LeVar Burton serving as co‑executive producer and Mark Wolper—son of the original producer—also executive producing, while network executives emphasize bringing Kunta Kinte’s story to a new generation that has seen milestones such as Barack Obama’s presidency and the film “12 Years a Slave” amid ongoing racial tensions.

Former royal footman Christopher Lawler, now 64, alleges that in January 1978 he was forced into a sexual assault by palace aides at Clarence House, the Queen Mother’s London residence, where he was pinned to a chair, groped and threatened after being offered a drink and asked if he was gay; he fled the room, was followed and threatened, and quit his job the same day, later reporting the incident to palace officials after a 2022 child‑sex‑abuse inquiry but receiving no response for months until the complaint reached Scotland Yard, prompting a police investigation that the Royal Household says it will cooperate with, while a retired royal aide denied involvement, claiming he was then serving the Queen at Balmoral.

Oregon couple Jesse and Melissa Meek announced they are expecting a child in a rap video set to the 1990s sitcom The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air theme, which has amassed over 1.7 million YouTube views; the clip shows them rapping about their life in Happy Valley, buying a house, building a homestead, the two‑month conception period, Melissa’s surprise positive test, and ends with a sonogram of the unborn baby, was filmed in five takes, and was created to inform distant loved ones, with the couple noting its unexpected popularity and hinting at a possible gender‑reveal video, while also noting Jesse’s lineage as the great‑great‑grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek and referencing a similar Fresh Prince‑themed pregnancy announcement made by a Pennsylvania couple the previous year.

A gray jacket‑and‑skirt ensemble worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O’Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind* sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions sale in Beverly Hills, part of a lot of more than 150 items from the movie; the dress, originally slate blue‑gray, has faded to light gray with age and was rescued in the 1960s by James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios hair‑and‑makeup head who bought it for $20 and built a collection of over 300,000 film artifacts, and the auction also fetched $52,500 for Leigh’s straw hat, $55,000 for Clark Gable’s trousers and jacket, and $30,000 for a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia de Havilland, while the film, based on Margaret Mitchell’s 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary and featured Hattie McDaniel as the first African‑American Academy Award winner.

A two‑year‑old boy fell 10–12 feet into the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo’s cheetah exhibit after his parents dangled him over the railing, but he was rescued by his parents before firefighters and paramedics arrived; he suffered minor bruises and a leg injury but was listed in stable condition at MetroHealth Medical Center and was not attacked by the cheetahs, which stayed away while witnesses expressed shock at the parents’ actions; the zoo closed the exhibit and announced plans to press child‑endangerment charges against the mother.

A bright yellow Gatso speed camera on Wellington Road in Handsworth, Birmingham, was re‑aimed to point directly at a house’s front door, but it has been non‑functional for more than two years after all fixed speed‑enforcement devices in the West Midlands were switched off in March 2013 because their technology became obsolete; enforcement now relies on a few mobile units, motorway cameras and patrol officers. Birmingham City Council officials are aware of the re‑pointed camera, plan to send an engineer to the site and may remove it, and confirmed the camera will not be included in a forthcoming digital‑technology pilot, while the homeowners declined to comment.

Usain Bolt, the six‑time Olympic gold medallist, will join the Jamaican squad at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2‑3, confirming he is fit, healthy and eager to run; the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association expressed excitement about his participation and anticipates “sprint magic,” while noting that the full team roster will be released soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended Barcelona’s Euro League basketball El Clasico with Neymar’s sister Rafaella, where Barcelona edged Real Madrid 85‑80 but Madrid remained division leaders on points difference; earlier, Neymar captained Brazil to a 1‑0 win over Chile at the Emirates, enduring tough challenges and a clash with Gary Medel, while Barcelona’s football side had just beaten Real Madrid in La Liga to sit four points clear at the top and were set to face Celta Vigo as they pursued a treble.

Italy is confronting a surge of desperate African and Middle Eastern migrants trying to reach Europe, with the coast guard rescuing 8,480 people from Friday to Monday and receiving SOS calls from 20 boats on a single day; Save the Children warned that up to 400 migrants may be missing after a reported capsizing of a 550‑person vessel 80 miles off Libya, though officials said no evidence of such an incident has been found, and recent months have seen a sharp rise in crossings—over 10,000 arrivals in the first three months of 2015, about 2,000 rescued during one weekend in April’s Channel of Sicily, and 978 rescued in a single day—most migrants coming from West Africa, Somalia and Syria via Libya, with at least 480 deaths this year attributed to bad weather, overcrowded smuggler boats, and abandoned crews.

Arsène Wenger admits he does not know why Alexis Sánchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool but is pleased the Chilean forward joined the club for £32 million, made an instant impact and has already scored 19 league goals, praising his efficiency, work‑rate and fighting spirit; Wenger suggests Liverpool’s interest may have been used as leverage in the Suarez‑to‑Barcelona negotiations, while also downplaying speculation about a possible Raheem Sterling move to Arsenal and noting that despite recent setbacks Liverpool, under Brendan Rodgers, have performed well after Suarez’s departure and Daniel Sturridge’s injury, even scoring over 100 Premier League goals last season.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, the 35‑year‑old four‑time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on 7 June at London’s Olympic Velodrome (Lee Valley VeloPark), aiming to surpass the current mark of 52.491 km set by Australia’s Rohan Dennis in February; the event, expected to draw a 6,000‑person crowd and be broadcast live on Sky Sports, will have tickets on sale from 19 April with prices of £49, £39 and £29, while Wiggins, who ended his Team Sky career at Paris‑Roubaix and will ride the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire for his eponymous team, also targets a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Games.

Serena Williams overcame a tough Fed Cup match against Italy’s Sara Errani, winning 4‑6 7‑6(3) 6‑3 to improve her head‑to‑head record to 8‑0, but the United States still fell 3‑2 overall as Williams and Alison Riske were beaten 6‑0 6‑3 in doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in relegation to World Group II; Williams called the experience an “eye‑opener,” saying she was less prepared for the clay‑court season than she thought and must adjust her hard‑court style, while US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for harder work to regain elite status, noting the team’s depth in the top 100 and hoping for two wins next year to return to the World Group.

River Plate are eager to re‑sign former striker Radamel Falcao, though a deal is complex; vice‑president Matías Patanian said the club “dreams of Falcao” and “the doors are open.” Falcao, who joined River at 15 in 2001, made his first‑team debut four years later and scored 34 goals in 90 Primera División appearances before leaving for Porto in 2009. Currently on a season‑long loan from Monaco at Manchester United, he has struggled, netting only four Premier League goals, and it is unclear whether United will keep him or he will return to Monaco. Recently, he scored three goals in two matches for Colombia, tying the nation’s all‑time scoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, the 19‑year‑old X Factor finalist and pop star, has become the first brand partner for dry‑shampoo brand Batiste, serving as the face of its 2015 “Ready For It” campaign—a collaboration arranged by the MILES agency that includes a TV advertisement featuring her single “Mirror Man.” The campaign showcases Henderson in various city‑backdrop images with her long hair styled in glossy waves, a half‑ponytail, and a black‑lacy dress, highlighting her regular use of the product, while CEO Mark Hargreaves of Crown Talent & Media Group notes the partnership as her inaugural endorsement and a natural synergy between the internationally acclaimed artist and the world‑famous brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, a 26‑year‑old man fatally shot by Kenosha police officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after a vehicle and foot pursuit in which Siler, wanted on a felony probation and parole warrant, “armed himself with a weapon,” are outraged by a billboard erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin by the Kenosha Professional Police Association that features a photograph of Torres and his dog with a “Thank you for your support, Kenosha” message; the billboard has been called “disrespectful” and a “thank you for killing Aaron” by Siler’s loved ones, who are demanding its removal, while the police association says no offense was intended and it merely thanks the community for its support. Torres is on leave pending an investigation into Siler’s death, which is being handled by the state Division of Criminal Investigation, and the incident follows a shooting ten days earlier in which Torres wounded 66‑year‑old Terry Knight, who was armed with knives; that case was turned over to District Attorney Robert Zapf, who ruled the shooting justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed and three militants died in a clash near the southeastern town of Negur after the attackers crossed from Pakistan, according to Iranian state media; the Sunni anti‑Iranian group Jaish al Adal, which operates in Pakistan’s Balochistan province and has previously targeted Shiites and Iranian forces—including a 2013 attack that killed 14 guards—claimed responsibility, prompting Iran to criticize Pakistan for not restraining the militants, while Pakistan condemned the incident as terrorism, said its security agencies were investigating, and pledged to apprehend any assailants who returned to its territory.

The passage reports that Japan’s Defense Minister Gen Nakatani told the Diet that the Air Self‑Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO, explaining that when unidentified objects are detected the force may scramble jets for visual observation but only birds or non‑aircraft objects have been found, and no alien craft has been confirmed; this response came after former wrestler‑turned‑lawmaker Antonio Inoki asked whether jets had ever been scrambled for extraterrestrial threats and whether research on alien visitors was underway, noting that Inoki himself claims to have seen a UFO but is unsure of alien existence, and recalling that a similar parliamentary discussion occurred in 2007 when then‑Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal implications of defending against an outer‑space invasion.

Passenger Jin Pai, a 35‑year‑old man waiting to board a flight at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Anhui Province, was hospitalized after the toilet he was squatting on collapsed, shattering and cutting his left leg and buttocks; he received dozens of stitches, had called his travel companions for help, initially admitted squatting to avoid an unclean seat but later told police he was sitting, and authorities deemed the incident an accident while reminding the public that airport toilets are intended for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56‑year‑old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested after a 15‑year‑old girl discovered a hidden camera under her bathroom sink, leading police to trace the device to him; investigators uncovered 41 videos—34 of which showed victims showering—recorded over three to four years, and the girl reported that Rebbie had been watching and molesting her since she was nine, prompting charges of aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children and invasion of privacy, with a preliminary hearing set for May 1 and bail set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama’s new series, featured in a book roughly titled “Daughter and Salaryman,” pairs po‑faced teenage daughters—dressed casually and smiling at the camera—with their fathers, sharply dressed in suits, leaping energetically in front of various Japanese landmarks; the images let typically serious “salary‑man” fathers express a playful, heroic side, though some older dads show slight pain, and the unusual concept has already attracted considerable online interest.

The passage notes that after Paul Downton was dismissed as England’s managing director, attention turned to the upcoming county championship, where Kevin Pietersen was photographed for Surrey at the KIA Oval, appearing both thoughtful and jovial; his presence signals a possible return to the England Test side after being controversially dropped in 2014 and last playing internationally during the 2023 Ashes whitewash, and he hopes to use his Surrey performances—beginning with a match against Glamorgan on April 19 and a university game versus Oxford MCCU—to force his way back into the national setup.

Relegation‑threatened Romanian side Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2‑0 defeat to mid‑table FC Botosani left the team 16th in the league, six points from safety; the 41‑year‑old former Inter Milan and Parma right‑back, who earned 25 caps for Brazil over a five‑year international career, had been reinstated a day after an earlier firing, had replaced Florin Marin in January as the club’s third coach of the season, and will now be succeeded by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Nabil Dirar, Falcao’s former Monaco teammate, says the Colombian striker likely regrets his season‑long loan to Manchester United, where he has scored only four goals and failed to recapture his pre‑injury form, making a £46 million permanent move unlikely; Dirar added that Falcao was unhappy in France and would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played in the Champions League and enjoyed a more supportive atmosphere.

New Zealand police are seeking public help to identify a very tall man who robbed a dairy on Union Street in east Christchurch on a Saturday around 12:30 pm, wearing a distinctive oversized cartoon mask and a fluorescent orange sweatshirt; the robber demanded cash from the owner’s daughter, threw the register to the ground, and fled with the till drawer and up to $1,500, leaving no weapons behind, and authorities urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111 or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24‑year‑old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was first arrested on March 19 for an inappropriate relationship with a 15‑year‑old student, admitting she had kissed him and let him touch her breasts, after which she was suspended and placed on administrative leave; she was released on bail but was arrested again on Monday on new allegations that she had sex with a different 15‑year‑old pupil in her car on consecutive nights in January, was booked into Irving County Jail, posted a $50,000 bail, and it remains unclear how she will plead to the second set of charges.

A video showing a large American crocodile calmly swimming through Puerto Vallarta’s public marina while holding a dead black dog with a red collar in its jaws has been viewed over half a million times; New Zealand tourist Tim Weston, who was on holiday with his wife, witnessed the incident and said the croc kept the dog in its mouth for hours, noting that a crocodile sanctuary lies about 200 m upriver and that such reptiles are common in the mangrove‑filled resort, often seen on the golf course, with urbanisation bringing them closer to humans, while social‑media users reacted with horror and disgust.

Steve Bruce insists Hull City can avoid relegation despite a 2‑0 loss to Southampton that left them just two points above the drop zone, noting that while he originally aimed for ten wins he now believes nine or eight may suffice as they head into six remaining games against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham and Manchester United; he attributes their struggles to long‑term injuries to key players such as Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavić and Robert Snodgrass, but remains confident the squad can stay positive and pick up the needed results, while Southampton’s James Ward‑Prowse scored a penalty in the same match and manager Ronald Koeman later dealt with Sadio Mane’s attempt to take a penalty, reminding his team of discipline.

Ian Guffick, a 31‑year‑old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he asked pupils to alter their answers on the national curriculum SATs for 11‑year‑olds in English, maths and science and also changed some answers himself after the exam session had ended; a local education authority investigation in June found these breaches, leading the Department for Education to annul all of the school’s SATs results for 2014, and Guffick, who resigned, admitted the allegations, was deemed to have acted dishonestly (though not fraudulently), expressed remorse, and was given 28 days to appeal the prohibition order.

Anders Lindegaard, the Denmark international goalkeeper at Manchester United who has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons and is now third‑choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdés, celebrated his personal life by posting a sunny Instagram photo with his wife, Swedish‑Albanian model Misse Beqiri; the couple, who have been together since 2012 and share a son, married in a beach ceremony in Mauritius last year, and despite his limited playing time and a failed transfer link to FC Midtjylland, Lindegaard is enjoying his off‑pitch life.

The 13 glowing blue letters that hung over Yankee Stadium in the Bronx from 1976 until the venue’s 2008 closure—each about 10 feet tall—were put up for auction at Sotheby’s, where no external bidder met the $300,000‑$600,000 estimate and only a Sotheby’s employee raised a paddle at $260,000; the signage’s current owner, Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who bought the letters after the stadium’s final game, said he hoped a new generation would enjoy the iconic piece, and while the letters failed to sell, a separate lot—a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s—sold for $112,500, far above its $20,000‑$30,000 estimate.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers reprimanded Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe for recent off‑field incidents—Sterling’s inhalation of nitrous oxide and both players being photographed with shisha pipes—reminding them of their professional responsibilities but stating they will not be disciplined and urging them to move past the episode; meanwhile, Rodgers is focused on the upcoming FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa, noting that Steven Gerrard is available after serving a three‑match suspension but has not yet decided whether to recall him, and emphasizing that the team must learn from past near‑misses in the league and cups to reach the final.

Arsenal midfielder Mesut Ozil returned to London after the international break, sharing a photo of himself relaxing with his dog, and is gearing up for Arsenal’s weekend Premier League match against Liverpool after missing the previous game against Newcastle due to illness; the German international had helped Germany beat Georgia 2‑0 in a Euro 2016 qualifier, and since returning from injury he has contributed four assists and three goals, fitting “perfectly” into the demanding English schedule, a sentiment he expressed while confirming his £42.5 million 2013 transfer from Real Madrid and dismissing rumors of a Berlin nightclub appearance.

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu said the club has no intention of replacing Luis Enrique, who took over last summer on a two‑year contract running to 2016 and is now only six games from clinching the La Liga title; Bartomeu praised Enrique’s work ethic and recent performances, noting his preparation for the Champions League match against PSG and the subsequent league win over Valencia, where Luis Suárez and Lionel Messi scored, and affirmed that Barcelona remain capable of winning three trophies.

Jordan Henderson has agreed a new long‑term contract with Liverpool, extending his deal to the summer of 2020 and reportedly worth around £100,000 a week, after his previous contract had 14 months remaining and following the club’s FA Cup semi‑final loss; the 24‑year‑old midfielder, signed in 2011 for £16 million, has become one of Brendan Rodgers’ most improved players, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season, and is expected to be considered for the captaincy when Steven Gerrard departs, making him the third recent high‑profile extension after Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho.

Filipe Luis, who joined Chelsea on a three‑year deal last July after leaving Atletico Madrid, says he wants to remain at the club until his contract expires despite Atletico’s interest in re‑signing him; he has struggled to cement the left‑back position at Stamford Bridge, recently featured for Brazil in friendly wins over France and Chile, and now turns his focus to Chelsea’s Premier League title run‑in, with manager José Mourinho urging the team to stay concentrated for the nine challenging games ahead.

Nathan Hughes’ three‑match ban for the knee‑to‑head collision that knocked out George North while he was scoring a try on 27 March was overturned on appeal after widespread criticism, with his red card rescinded and the appeal panel concluding the incident was accidental and involved no foul play; although the Fiji‑born forward missed his club’s Champions Cup quarter‑final loss to Toulon while the ban was pending, he is now cleared to play but was omitted from the next match‑day squad and is unlikely to feature again until at least the Exeter visit on 26 April, while North, suffering his third concussion in two months, was taken off on a stretcher and advised to rest for a minimum of a month.

A vivid red sunset over Washington on Sunday was caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, where farmers’ grass burns combined with strong winds on April 14 to ignite and spread flames that destroyed dozens of villages before rescue crews extinguished them; the smoke was carried across the Pacific by atmospheric winds, reaching the Pacific Northwest and filtering out shorter‑wavelength light (greens, blues, yellows, purples) so that reds and oranges dominate especially at sunrise and sunset, and as the smoke dissipates air quality will improve and the intense hues will fade.

Becky Schoenig, a St. Louis mother, had her brand‑new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway a month after purchase, but police recovered it on April 1 after a tip from Mick Sexton, who recognized the vehicle; the thieves had spray‑painted the rims red, added red side detailing and orange accents to the steering wheel, and left a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, prompting Schoenig to have the car professionally cleaned, while she thanked the thieves on Facebook and announced she would honor Sexton with a “Sexton on Wheels” smoothie (banana, pineapple, peach and coconut cream) at her restaurant, The Hot Pot.

Manchester City’s squad faces £500,000 bonuses per player—about £12 million in total—if they fail to reach the Champions League group stage, with star contracts for Sergio Aguero, David Silva, Joe Hart, Yaya Toure and others designed to meet financial‑fair‑play rules; after a 1‑0 loss to Manchester United in the 169th derby, City sit fourth, four points ahead of Liverpool, needing a qualifying‑round win to join the automatically qualified top three, while manager Manuel Pellegrini admits the season has “disintegrated” after a joint‑top start, seven defeats and early cup exits, and the club now eyes signings such as Juventus midfielder Paul Pogba amid a schedule that includes fixtures against West Ham, Aston Villa, Tottenham, QPR, Swansea and Southampton.

Manchester United’s Under‑18 side edged Altrincham’s City 1‑0 in a “mini‑derby” at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the only goal from a free‑kick just before the hour mark; the match, free to the public, attracted close to 1,000 fans and featured 13 English players (10 from Manchester), while United’s Marcus Rashford missed two chances and Cameron Borthwick‑Jackson struck the crossbar, and the result left United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while injury‑hit City have now lost both of their Barclays Under‑18 Premier League play‑off matches, underscoring FA chief Greg Dyke’s concerns about limited first‑team opportunities for home‑grown talent.

England goalkeeper Joe Hart praised Italian veteran Gianluigi Buffon as a “legend of the game” after Buffon earned his 147th cap in a 1‑1 draw with England, noting that he still learns from Buffon’s example at 37; Hart, who celebrated his own 50th England appearance at the Juventus Stadium, expressed pride in reaching that milestone at a relatively young age and said he wants to continue improving and adding more caps for club and country.

Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food‑delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery of online and mobile orders in 67 cities, charging a nine‑percent service fee and delivery fees starting at $5 that vary by distance and demand; the chain, which had previously declined other third‑party delivery offers, will use Postmates’ independent‑contractor drivers, and its rollout has drawn political attention, with candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton spotted ordering at Chipotle locations, while other major brands such as Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald’s and Burger King are also pursuing delivery partnerships.

The parents of Martin Richard, the eight‑year‑old killed in the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have written an emotional op‑ed urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty from Dzhokhar Tsarnaev’s sentencing, arguing that a life‑without‑parole sentence would spare their surviving children the prolonged trauma of appeals; they recount the brutal evidence they witnessed in court, acknowledge the heinous nature of the crimes that also maimed their seven‑year‑old daughter Jane, and stress that continuing to seek execution would extend their anguish, while emphasizing that their plea reflects only their personal desire to “turn the page” for their family, Boston, and the nation.

A custom‑built Boeing 747‑8 has been transformed into a £400 million luxury residence for an unnamed billionaire, a three‑year project that replaces the aircraft’s 600‑seat cabin with hotel‑style amenities including multiple bedrooms, a large dining room with an adjoining kitchen, several lounges, a state room, a conference table, an office/guest suite, and an “aeroloft” on the upper deck containing eight full beds; while designed for a single owner, the plane can accommodate dozens of guests and features high‑end décor, porthole‑style windows, and entertainment areas, making it one of the most extravagant private jets ever created.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station, delivering over 4,300 lb of supplies including an espresso maker, and after a few days the Dragon will dock, be unpacked for about five weeks, then be refilled with more than 3,000 lb of experiments and trash for return to Earth via a Pacific splashdown; the mission marked SpaceX’s sixth ISS flight and a second launch attempt after a weather‑related scrub, while the company’s attempt to land the first rocket stage on a floating droneship failed as the booster tipped over, continuing its effort to develop reusable rockets to dramatically lower launch costs.

Priscilla Presley, age 69, will serve as witness at the inaugural wedding in the newly opened Elvis Presley’s Graceland Wedding Chapel at the Westgate Hotel in Las Vegas—formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 sold‑out shows—on Thursday, April 23; the ceremony is the prize for an NBC Today‑sponsored contest for an Elvis‑obsessed couple, whose entry (a video or photos with an explanation) will be announced next Monday and includes a free wedding reception, a two‑night hotel suite, airfare and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show, while the chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside Memphis, explicitly bans impersonators.

Liverpool vice‑captain Jordan Henderson, after playing his 47th game of the season alongside goalkeeper Simon Mignolet in a 2‑0 win over Newcastle United, said the team can still catch Manchester City, who sit four points ahead after a recent 4‑2 loss to Manchester United; Henderson highlighted Liverpool’s return to winning form following poor results against Manchester United and Arsenal, and stressed the need to keep winning as the season ends, while Raheem Sterling opened the scoring in the ninth minute and Joe Allen added a second after a defensive error, securing a vital victory in the Premier League race.

Roma snapped a four‑month home winless run by beating Napoli 1‑0 in a Serie A clash that could shape the race for Champions League spots, with Miralem Pjanic scoring after a swift counter‑attack in the 25th minute and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making multiple crucial saves in the second half; the win moved second‑place Roma four points clear of city rivals Lazio, while Napoli’s own winless streak stretched to five games, leaving them fifth, and the match featured tight security after a fan death at a previous cup final, a ban on tickets for Campania residents, and the absence of injured Roma captain Francesco Totti and forward Gervinho, while Napoli’s Lorenzo Insigne returned briefly after a knee injury.

Doncaster Rovers, stuck in mid‑table mediocrity in League One, drew 0‑0 with Fleetwood Town—who had seen their play‑off hopes fade—at the Keepmoat Stadium, a match that left the club’s media team with little to showcase, prompting them to post a brief 27‑second YouTube highlight containing only 14 seconds of action (the kickoff, a goal kick and the final whistle).

Roland Giroux demonstrates a unique tactile bond with his blood‑parrot cichlid, gently cupping and massaging the fish in its tank, which relaxes, swims in circles, and repeatedly returns to his hand for strokes, even following his hand to the surface when removed; after removing two bullying tank mates, he hand‑feeds frozen bloodworms, fostering the fish’s sociability and daily need for about 15 minutes of play, while noting that the hybrid species—originating from a cross of midas and redhead cichlids—was first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes returns to the Kensington Oval, the site of his wrist‑breaking locker‑punching incident, and must now channel his famed fiery aggression after a clash with Marlon Samuels that prompted a lengthy talk with England coach Peter Moores; while his exuberant character is valued for its ability to produce runs and wickets, the team aims to manage his temperament carefully, keep him in the side as much as possible, and balance his role alongside other all‑rounders such as Chris Jordan and potential spinners like Adil Rashid.

Wales will face Belgium in a Euro 2016 qualifier on 12 June at the 33,000‑seat Cardiff City Stadium, a match declared a sell‑out after overwhelming ticket demand; both sides sit on 11 points from five games, with Belgium leading the Group B table on goal difference despite Wales’ recent 3‑0 win over Israel that has boosted hopes of securing an automatic spot for the 2016 finals, and the Welsh squad prefers the more intimate Cardiff venue over the larger Millennium Stadium, a change barred by UEFA rules within 120 days of the fixture.

England’s under‑17 side, coached by John Peacock, has announced its squad for next month’s UEFA European Under‑17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the defending champions—who qualified with a perfect record—are drawn in Group D with Holland, Italy and the Republic of Ireland; they will open the tournament against Italy in Burgas on 7 May before facing Holland on 10 May and Ireland on 13 May, and the 23‑player roster features goalkeepers Paul Woolston and Will Huffer, defenders including Danny Collinge, Reece Oxford, Easah Suliman, James Yates, Jay DaSilva and Tayo Edun, midfielders such as Trent Arnold, Daniel Wright, Herbie Kane, Tom Davies, Marcus Edwards, Nathan Holland and Chris Willock, and forwards Layton Ndukwu, Stephy Mavididi and Ike Ugbo, with notable Premier League talents like Chelsea’s Jay DaSilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal’s Chris Willock and first‑timer Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool’s Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold returning after missing the Elite Round qualifiers.

Manchester City are eager to sign 14‑year‑old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, a top talent who has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona; he previously turned down Barcelona’s La Masia at age 12 to continue his studies, and City are now negotiating a compensation package with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock as manager Manuel Pellegrini looks to secure his future by acquiring the promising youngster.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33‑year‑old Mexican transgender escort who worked in London, Paris and Miami, was found strangled and beaten to death with head and neck injuries in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south‑west London, after London Ambulance Service was called to the address on 28 March around 9:30 pm; a 23‑year‑old man was arrested in connection with her death, released on bail and asked to return for further questioning, while Scotland Yard, led by DCI Rebecca Reeves, has appealed for anyone who had contact with Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward, noting that police have not confirmed whether her profession was central to the investigation.

Dawn, a mother who has endured seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show after discovering that £207 set aside for a £500 gravestone for her baby Daniel James had been stolen; she accused her house‑mate Jamie—who lives with her and her partner, also named Jamie—and his girlfriend Carol, and after a lie‑detector test confirmed Jamie’s guilt, she broke down in tears, feeling betrayed as the theft undermined her effort to honor her lost child.

ISIS released more than 200 Yazidis—primarily women, children, the ill and elderly—on Wednesday, with officials reporting 217 freed and a Peshmerga commander counting 228, after coordination with Arab tribal leaders; the Peshmerga received the captives and sent them to Irbil, though the motive for the release remains unclear. The Yazidis, a Kurdish‑descended pre‑Islamic minority of about 500,000 people in northern Iraq, had been subjected to extreme violence, displacement, enslavement and mass killings when ISIS seized their towns, especially Sinjar, last summer, prompting an international coalition to airdrop aid, conduct rescues and launch airstrikes against the militants.

Harry Kane’s animated celebrations this season have highlighted his on‑pitch energy, and he is now featured in a new animation by Copa90 that strings together still photos of his best goals and celebrations, including a long‑range strike against Chelsea, a header versus Arsenal, and his debut goal for England; the video, titled “Harry Kane – PFA Player of the Year?”, was released ahead of the awards ceremony where the Tottenham striker, who has scored 20 Premier League goals and helped Tottenham and England, is nominated for both the PFA Player of the Year and Young Player of the Year awards, competing with Eden Hazard and Alexis Sánchez.

Jamie Carragher defended Brendan Rodgers as the right manager for Liverpool despite a trophy‑less season and a likely finish outside the top four, noting that the team’s future shouldn’t be judged on a single game and that the squad still needs time to settle and improve, especially with upcoming signings; he highlighted Liverpool’s seven‑point gap to fourth‑place Manchester City and their recent FA Cup semi‑final loss, while also celebrating his own Beacon Award for community work through the 23 Foundation, which provides coaching in deprived Merseyside schools and reflects his commitment to giving back to his hometown of Bootle.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after security officers, deeming it a security risk, frisked him and forced him to surrender the toy, which was flagged by X‑ray machines; his father described the checks as “over‑zealous” and “ludicrous,” noting they caused a delay and they could not argue without missing their flight to Lanzarote. The airport later apologized, offered to mail the toy back, and explained that regulations prohibit any items resembling a prohibited weapon, including replica or model guns, even though the specific toy is not listed. After a ten‑day holiday, the family bought a replacement gun on eBay, restoring James’s smile.

A 31‑year‑old man who identifies only as “Rich” from Humpty Doo in the Northern Territory posted a Gumtree advertisement seeking a “girlfriend/wife” and listed extensive requirements for his ideal partner—including being non‑drinking, non‑smoking, fit, attractive, good with hands, a good cook, great in bed, enjoying the outdoors yet able to act like a “princess,” reliable, honest, loyal, and willing to work around the house—while offering benefits such as accommodation, a possible company car, phone, laptop, free gym membership, and other perks; he described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, 175 cm tall, well‑endowed, owning property, making good money, loving cars, bikes, travel, sports, fishing and camping, and emphasized he does not drink, smoke, or use drugs, and that “all reasonable offers will be considered,” noting that former partners need not apply.

FA chairman Greg Dyke, backed by former England managers Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven‑Goran Eriksson and Steve McClaren, is pushing radical reforms to raise the minimum number of home‑grown players in club squads from eight to twelve and to redefine “home‑grown” as having trained in England for three years before age 18 rather than before 21, despite Premier League opposition; the managers warn that failing to adopt the proposals could further shrink England’s top‑level talent pool—already reflected in only 36.8 % of Premier League starters being eligible for England—and stress that emerging players such as Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling and Harry Kane show the country can still produce top talent if given more opportunity.

Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, has given birth to Ross Poldark’s (Aidan Turner) baby daughter, despite the show’s rapid timeline that jumps from a pregnancy announcement to an eight‑month claim and then to delivery within minutes of the next episode, a pacing that fans have noted and compared to a previous similarly swift pregnancy storyline, while many viewers continue to idolize Ross as a heartthrob whose heart is now off the market.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson urged his team to stay focused on their own performances and ignore the results of relegation rivals, emphasizing that their future depends on doing their own job as they approach the season’s final games; after back‑to‑back victories—including a 3‑2 win at West Brom where Jamie Vardy scored an injury‑time winner that gave the Foxes a slim survival lifeline despite remaining bottom of the Premier League—Pearson warned against “flipping the emphasis,” saying that while other teams’ results can be helpful, Leicester must concentrate on their own run‑in and avoid becoming overly optimistic about their chances.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara set a new mammalian migration record by swimming nearly 14,000 miles (22,500 km) from her feeding grounds off Russia’s Sakhalin Island across the Pacific to Baja, Mexico, surpassing the previous Guinness record of a 10,190‑mile humpback whale round trip; the Oregon State University‑led tracking study, headed by Bruce Mate, noted that Varvara visited three major eastern gray‑whale breeding areas, suggesting she may be an eastern rather than a western gray whale—a distinction that could affect estimates of the roughly 150 remaining western gray whales and prompts a re‑examination of the species’ genetic differentiation.

Residents on Hokkaido’s east coast awoke to a new stretch of coastline on the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu after a landslide, triggered by melting ice and snow that caused a section of land to drop and pivot the seabed upward, forced 1,000 ft of ocean floor to the surface and created a landmass 30–50 ft above sea level, roughly 1,000–1,640 ft long and 100 ft wide; locals reported no tremors or sounds, an aerial survey confirmed the landslide origin, officials say it is unlikely to expand further and is unrelated to earthquakes, and marine organisms such as seaweed and sea urchins remain attached to the newly emerged land.

Gregory van der Wiel refuted rumors that he will leave Paris Saint‑Germain this summer, emphasizing his happiness and love for the club, the city and his teammates, and stating he wants to sign a new contract and is ready whenever the coach calls on him, despite a recent dispute with manager Laurent Blanc after being dropped for the Champions League match against Chelsea; meanwhile, PSG’s interest in signing Barcelona’s Dani Alves raises the possibility that Van der Wiel could still be sold.

Carlos Tevez has told Juventus he wants to leave this summer to return to Boca Juniors, and must first terminate his contract that runs until 2016 before the Argentine club can complete the move; Boca’s president Daniel Angelici confirmed the deal is near completion, while Juventus, despite being reluctant to lose their league’s top scorer with 17 goals this season, have accepted his wish and begun scouting replacements, and both Tevez’s international manager Tata Martino and the clubs stress that the transfer will not affect his Argentina future.

Bayern Munich thrashed Porto 6‑1 at the Allianz Arena, leading 5‑0 at halftime and securing a place in the Champions League semi‑finals thanks to goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jérôme Boateng, Thomas Müller, Xabi Alonso and a brace by Robert Lewandowski, while Porto entered the match with a two‑goal advantage from a 3‑1 win in Portugal; during the excitement, Bayern’s manager Pep Guardiola ripped the left leg of his grey trousers, briefly exposing his underwear, joked about needing new ones for the next match, and even discarded his suit blazer in the later stages.

Ten people, including four children, were involved in a three‑vehicle crash on the Brisbane Valley Highway 2 km south of Fernvale, resulting in the highway’s temporary closure and diversions. A 40‑year‑old man with chest and shoulder injuries, a five‑year‑old boy with chest pain, a 27‑year‑old woman with arm injuries and a six‑year‑old girl with abdominal pain were airlifted by rescue helicopter to Princess Alexandra Hospital, while six others—including an infant, two young girls, a man with hand lacerations and two uninjured females—were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or assessment. Emergency crews used hydraulic cutting gear to free a trapped occupant before the Rescue 500 helicopter evacuated patients.

Arsenal travel to face league leaders Chelsea in a crucial weekend match, with midfielder Mesut Ozil flaunting a new Apple Watch—priced £299‑£13,500—on Instagram, likening it to Michael Knight’s gadget from “Knight Rider” ahead of the 4 pm kickoff; Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 games this season, is expected to start as Arsenal trail Chelsea by ten points with six games remaining, while the side’s prospects have been bolstered by the return of injury‑prone Jack Wilshere, who featured on the bench in the FA Cup semi‑final and is hailed by club legend Ray Parlour as the club’s future provided he can stay fit, a concern echoed by references to Abou Diaby’s injury woes.

Referee Mark Clattenburg, a 40‑year‑old regarded as one of the Premier League’s top officials, has been appointed to officiate the Manchester derby at Old Trafford, with assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin and fourth official Jonathan Moss supporting him; this season he has issued only two Premier League red cards, both to Manchester United players (Tyler Blackcett and Luke Shaw), and previously sent off City and Belgium captain Vincent Kompany during an international match, leaving Kompany suspended for Wales; the derby, coming after United’s shock 2‑1 loss to Crystal Palace that left them a point ahead of City, could decide the runner‑up spot behind Chelsea, with United riding a five‑game winning streak while City have slipped to fourth place.

Outspoken federal MP Bob Katter accused the Queensland Government of treating embattled independent MP Billy Gordon as “a little black puppet on a string” after Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party amid domestic‑violence allegations and the revelation of his criminal history, a move that left the government’s razor‑thin majority in turmoil; Katter, who says he has faced racist attitudes and is of Lebanese descent, defended his controversial wording by citing his personal experiences, warned that independents can become government puppets—as he cited Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott—and asserted that Gordon would not repeat that mistake, while the statement drew criticism on social media for its terminology.

Dayna Dobias, a 19‑year‑old from Downers Grove, Illinois who was born with cerebral palsy, creates enthusiastic dancing videos—such as clips set to Taylor Swift’s “Shake It Off”—to challenge stereotypes, counter bullying, and show that she is “just like everyone else” despite her disability; she hopes the videos inspire others, improve representation of people with disabilities in media and fashion, and encourage viewers to look beyond her condition, and she has also begun giving motivational talks at several Chicago‑area schools, highlighting that she can walk, drive, attend college and live a typical teenage life.

Orlando City, an MLS club with a large Latin‑American fanbase, have expressed interest in signing Manchester United forward Javier Hernández, who is on loan at Real Madrid and has attracted interest from eight European clubs—including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio and Inter Milan—with United willing to sell for about £8 million; Hernández, 26, has one year left on his contract. At the same time, United have offered a revised contract to 19‑year‑old midfielder Andreas Pereira, who has drawn interest from Paris Saint‑Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven and Feyenoord after rejecting United’s initial offer, and was on the bench against Aston Villa.

A gang of at least three people attempted to carjack a man pumping gas at a 76 station in South Los Angeles around 12:15 a.m. on Saturday, pulling a gun and demanding his white Dodge Charger; when he fled, the suspects sprayed gasoline on the vehicle, which still had two passengers inside, and set it ablaze, completely destroying the car’s front end but causing no injuries. The driver’s grandmother reported the incident, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating it as arson while the suspects remain at large and surveillance video is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, southern Iowa, surrendered his state license after the Iowa Board of Chiropractic detailed charges that he accepted sex as payment, performed exorcisms on patients, bartered sex for services, and advised patients to stop prescribed medication; he signed an agreement admitting the misconduct, pledging not to seek reinstatement for at least ten years and to prove that the circumstances leading to revocation no longer exist before practicing again, despite having received perfect five‑star patient‑satisfaction ratings from a small number of reviews on HealthGrades.com and listing a residential address as his practice location.

A Russian SU‑27 fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC‑135U reconnaissance aircraft over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland, performing aggressive, close‑proximity maneuvers that the Pentagon described as “unsafe and unprofessional,” while Russia claimed the U.S. plane’s transponder was off—a claim the U.S. denied; the United States said it will lodge a diplomatic complaint, noting this follows a similar dangerous encounter a year earlier over the Sea of Okhotsk, and highlighting that Russian and U.S. aircraft frequently meet in Northern Europe and the region between the Russian Far East and Alaska.

An FBI agent’s sniper rifle, secured in a hard case and locked to a truck safe, was ripped from his car’s rear‑right window and stolen overnight from the Marriott Springhill Suites parking lot in Salt Lake City on March 27, just days before President Obama’s scheduled Utah visit; police say the thief broke the window, used a rope or cable to pull the case free with momentum from another vehicle, and left skid marks, rope fragments and the case’s broken handle, while also taking the agent’s gear bag, backpack, clothing and tools, though the bags were later recovered at a nearby Residence Inn; the hotel lacks surveillance cameras, the rifle’s serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer, and the Secret Service was notified of the theft prior to the presidential trip, but the weapon has not been recovered and investigators are unsure whether the agent’s car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is on trial for the July 2012 murder of his elderly neighbour Terrence Freebody in the dining room of his Red Hill, Canberra home, where he allegedly stomped, slit the victim’s throat and stabbed him multiple times; forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa’s mental state was deteriorating due to dementia compounded by alcohol, noting fluctuating mood, confused behavior such as a trail of faeces to the toilet, and that he likely did not understand his actions or their consequences, while prosecutor Shane Drumgold suggested Costa may have feigned memory loss, a claim Mullen denied, and emphasized that proving Costa’s unstable mindset could lead the jury to return a not‑guilty verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley’s decision to take a 10th‑minute penalty in the 1‑0 win over Burnley, despite the presence of Leighton Baines, who has a 15‑for‑16 Premier League record; Barkley’s well‑struck effort was saved by Burnley keeper Tom Heaton, but the miss proved inconsequential as Kevin Mirallas scored the only goal at 29 minutes, and Martinez emphasized that he likes having several players capable of taking penalties and that Barkley was within his rights to request the spot‑kick.

Two passengers were found dead inside their stateroom on Holland America Line’s ms Ryndam in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what the cruise line says appears to be a murder‑suicide; the cabin was secured and the FBI and other authorities were notified and are investigating, while the ship, which departed Tampa on March 29 for a 14‑day Southern Caribbean cruise, continues its itinerary.

Former Dutch forward and former assistant coach Patrick Kluivert, whose mother is from Curaçao, has guided the Caribbean island’s national team to the second round of CONCACAF 2018 World Cup qualifying after a 2‑1 home win and a 2‑2 away draw gave a 4‑3 aggregate victory over Montserrat, with Charlton Vicento’s late substitute goal averting extra time; Curaçao will meet Cuba on June 8 and 16, and Kluivert brings experience as a 1998 World Cup semi‑finalist player and 2014 assistant to Louis van Gaal.

Esteban Cambiasso, the Argentine midfielder who has won every major European trophy with clubs such as Inter Milan (including five Serie A titles, four Coppa Italia, four Supercoppa, a Champions League and a FIFA Club World Cup) and Real Madrid (La Liga, Supercopa de España), says that helping Leicester City avoid relegation this season would feel like winning another cup; with the Foxes seven points from safety and only eight games left, he remains confident they can secure enough points to stay up, despite a winless run since January, and has expressed happiness with his one‑year deal at Leicester, hinting he may remain beyond the season.

Gemma, a 23‑year‑old mother of two children under five by different fathers, handed both infants to her 52‑year‑old mother Debbie when they were four months old; since then Debbie has cared for the children after social services warned of removal, but now threatens to ban Gemma from seeing them because Gemma continues to drink, party, use the legal high MKat, is unemployed, and is suspected of stealing an iPad and other items to fund her lifestyle, despite Gemma’s denial of the iPad theft and admission of past thefts, leading Debbie—who appeared with Gemma on The Jeremy Kyle Show—to consider cutting off all contact to protect the children.

Chelsea’s Eden Hazard opened the scoring against Manchester United after a controversial build‑up in which captain John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United striker Radamel Falcao, sending the Colombian to the ground; the resulting loose ball was collected by Cesc Fabregas, passed to Oscar and then to Hazard, who finished. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp and Graeme Souness all agreed the tackle should have been called a foul, with Souness noting an elbow to Falcao’s head, Henry saying he would have welcomed a foul, and Redknapp deeming the challenge illegal despite Falcao’s possible better balance.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott’s tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas after a rear tire blew out, but she, her husband, the tour manager and the driver escaped unharmed; the rear lounge was destroyed except for her Bible, while the band’s other members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus, and the group is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas.

Scottish physicist Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing space‑based lasers that would harvest sunlight with mirrored satellites, convert it to laser light using semiconductors, and beam the energy back to Earth to boost solar‑panel output and potentially power homes, with successful initial trials in Scotland and plans to test in Portugal; while the beams would be far weaker than cinematic weapons, Quarterman cautions that control of the satellites could be a concern, and similar low‑power laser concepts are being explored by Tokyo researchers to target small orbital debris from the ISS, a use also deemed non‑weaponizable.

Stephen Munden, a 54‑year‑old convicted paedophile with a “fanatical obsession” with young girls, escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire, after being detained under the Mental Health Act following a conviction for sexually touching a three‑year‑old girl on a bus; he was last seen leaving the Winchfield hospital at 6:15 pm on Tuesday, is described as about 5 ft 8 in tall, heavy‑built with dark hair and may have shaved his beard, and police have launched an urgent manhunt, seeking information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano to repay more than $2.6 million in gifts that Donald Sterling allegedly gave her, after his wife Shelly Sterling sued, claiming Sterling used the couple’s money to buy Stiviano luxury cars, a duplex and other items and that she targeted wealthy older men; Stiviano defended the gifts as permissible, but the court’s decision was hailed by Shelly’s lawyer as a victory for the Sterling family and a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of ill‑gotten gifts, while Sterling’s own downfall stemmed from a recorded rant in which he berated Stiviano for posting photos with Black individuals, leading NBA Commissioner Adam Silver to ban him, fine him $2.5 million and terminate his ownership of the Clippers.

Thierry Henry criticised Arsenal’s recent transfer activity, urging the club to sign four key players—a goalkeeper, a centre‑back, a defensive midfielder and a top‑quality striker—to give them a realistic chance of winning the Premier League, and he doubted that Olivier Giroud, despite his 14 league goals, could lead them to the title; he cited Chelsea’s successful summer acquisitions of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas and Diego Costa as a model, noting Arsenal are currently third, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand, and that manager Arsène Wenger must create a more competitive squad to contend for the championship.

A young woman, whose name is withheld, testified in Sydney’s District Court that she endured years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, who has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences including persistent sexual abuse of a child; she described lasting trauma such as fear for future relationships, loss of agency over her body, chronic depression since age 14, hospitalisation for self‑harm, and a suicide attempt after finally speaking out when Van Ryn was caught, while also expressing anxiety about his eventual release and the enduring impact on how she relates to men.

Serge Gnabry, the 19‑year‑old Arsenal midfielder who impressed last season, has been sidelined since a serious knee injury suffered in the Champions League last‑16 second leg against Bayern Munich in March, preventing any first‑team appearances; however, he recently completed a full 90‑minute match for Arsenal’s Under‑21 side against Reading, says he feels “better and better,” has overcome his injury concerns, and is eager for his next game.

Jacob Phillips, a 23‑year‑old graduate accountant who worked for the clothing label Pretty Green, died after leaping over a fence in the dark and falling about 70 feet down a cliff at Penarth’s disused Northern Promenade when he ran from a taxi to avoid paying the fare; he and two friends had left the cab to use an ATM, lacked cash for the journey, and split up, with Phillips running in the opposite direction, becoming disoriented and falling into the sea, his body being found the next day by a dog walker, and an inquest ruled his death accidental, noting he could not have known the danger of the sheer drop.

Last summer’s passport‑delay crisis left thousands of holidaymakers without compensation while the HM Passport Office posted a £42 million surplus and paid managers up to £3,500 in bonuses; ministers refused a blanket refund for families who paid extra for fast‑track service or missed trips, and only 2,191 compensation claims were approved between April 2014 and January 2015, totalling £203,066 (average £92.68), with the highest payout £5,463, despite Home Affairs Committee chair Keith Vaz’s calls for redress.

A semi‑detached house in Horfield, Bristol, unchanged since the 1930s and now up for auction on 30 April at the County Ground, retains original features such as stained‑glass windows (ships in the hall, coats of arms in the living‑room), oil‑fired central heating, a mint‑green and black bathroom with original tiles, wooden floor, yellow wallpaper and green sink, a kitchen with 1930s cupboards, a brick open‑face fire, a dated sink, and a hallway shelf holding vintage tins of Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk, Tate and Lyle sugar and Colman’s mustard; the property also has a wood‑panelled hall, double glazing, three bedrooms and a guide price of £200,000‑£250,000, with auctioneers warning that renovation costs may deter developers but noting its appeal to families passionate about antiques.

Colin Kaepernick began his NFL career as Alex Smith’s backup, became the San Francisco 49ers’ starting quarterback midway through the 2012 season after Smith suffered a concussion, and remained the starter for the rest of the year, guiding the team to its first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they were defeated by the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth “Babyface” Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before relocating to Texas and later to San Francisco; Route 495 is a 3.45‑mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, linking the New Jersey Turnpike (I‑95) at exits 16E and 17 in Secaucus to New York State Route 495 inside the Lincoln Tunnel in Weehawken, thereby providing access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal’s Telemundo Enterprises division.

Damon Albarn, raised in Leytonstone and around Colchester, met Graham Coxon at Stanway School and co‑founded Blur, whose first album Leisure (1991) received mixed reviews; after drawing on alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae and pop, the band achieved worldwide success with their self‑titled album in 2001, and Albarn later released his solo debut Everyday Robots on 28 April 2014, co‑produced by XL Recordings CEO Richard Russell and featuring collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, and samples of Lord Buckley’s rants.
Mogadishu, locally called Hamar, is Somalia’s capital and its most populous city, housing many of the nation’s key institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut EP, Broken, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born on August 14 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The passage describes two adaptations of “Shooter”: the 2007 film follows former Force Recon veteran Bob Lee Swagger, played by Mark Wahlberg, who is framed for murder by a rogue secret private‑military unit; the television series stars Ryan Phillippe as Swagger, an expert marksman living in exile who is drawn back into action after learning of a plot to kill the president.
House, also known as House, M.D., is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, running from November 16, 2004 to May 21, 2012.

In 1971 Charles Manson was convicted of first‑degree murder and conspiracy for the killings of seven people—including actress Sharon Tate—carried out by his followers at his direction, and also received first‑degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald “Shorty” Shea; after his charges, recordings of songs he wrote and performed were released commercially.

Sean Justin Penn (born August 17, 1960) is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his career with a television appearance in a 1974 episode of *Little House on the Prairie* directed by his father, Leo Penn; after his film debut in *Taps* (1981) and varied 1980s roles such as in *Fast Times at Ridgemont High*, he gained critical notice for crime dramas like *At Close Range* (1986), *State of Grace* (1990) and *Carlito’s Way* (1993). He rose to prominence with the drama *Dead Man Walking* (1995), earning his first Academy Award nomination and the Best Actor award at the Berlin Film Festival, followed by Oscar nominations for *Sweet and Lowdown* (1999) and *I Am Sam* (2001), and won Best Actor Oscars for *Mystic River* (2003) and *Milk* (2008).

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (27 August 1908 – 25 February 2001) was an Australian cricketer renowned as the greatest batsman of all time, and after retiring he remained influential in the sport for three decades as an administrator, selector, and writer.

L.A. Reid has held senior executive roles in the music industry, serving as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music Entertainment division), president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is a drummer best known for his work with the rock bands Rage Against the Machine (1991–2000 and 2007–2011) and Audioslave (2001–2007); he began his drumming career with Greta in 1990 and co‑founded Rage Against the Machine with Tom Morello and Zack de la Rocha in August 1991, and as of 2016 he was playing in Prophets of Rage alongside Tim Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B‑Real and DJ Lord, while the passage also notes that a separate German heavy‑metal group named Rage was formed in 1984 by Peter “Peavy” Wagner.

The Millers was a multi‑camera series that aired on CBS from October 3 2013 to July 18 2015, spanning 34 episodes across two seasons; CBS announced its cancellation on November 14 2014, after four episodes of the second season had aired.

Dorothy Ann Willis Richards (1933–2006) was an American Democratic politician who served as Texas state treasurer, delivered the keynote address at the 1988 Democratic National Convention, and became the state’s 45th governor from 1991 to 1995, noted as the second female governor and for her outspoken feminism and witty one‑liners before losing re‑election to George W. Bush in 1994; a separate Ann Richards (1935–1982) was an American jazz singer and the wife of pianist Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell independently released the EP "A Reminder" in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona; Janet Leigh (born Jeanette Helen Morrison; July 6 1927 – October 3 2004) was an American actress, singer, dancer, and author who wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios (24 July 1783 – 17 December 1830), known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who was instrumental in establishing Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru and Panama as independent sovereign states free from Spanish rule.

The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil’s Triangle, is a loosely defined area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where numerous aircraft and ships are reported to have disappeared under mysterious circumstances.

Colin Kaepernick began as Alex Smith’s backup before taking over as the 49ers’ starter in 2012 after Smith’s concussion, leading the team to a Super Bowl appearance that ended in a loss to the Baltimore Ravens, and in his first full season as starter in 2013, he guided the 49ers to the NFC Championship, where they were defeated by the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an audio or visual, openly sponsored, nonpersonal form of marketing communication used to promote or sell products, services, or ideas; unlike personal selling, it is not directed at specific individuals and is delivered through various mass media, including traditional outlets such as newspapers, magazines, television, radio, outdoor advertising, and direct mail, as well as newer channels like search results, blogs, websites, and text messages.
Private Lives refers to both a 1930 three‑act comedy of manners written by Noël Coward and a 1931 American Pre‑Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton (10 February 1894 – 29 December 1986), was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from 10 January 1957 to 19 October 1963.

Aristotle (384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice; he entered Plato’s Academy in Athens at about seventeen or eighteen, remaining there until roughly age thirty‑seven (c. 347 BC), and after Plato’s death he left Athens to tutor Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon beginning in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz (born February 16, 1982) is an American former arms dealer who became a musician, inventor, and entrepreneur; he created the BeatBuddy guitar‑pedal drum machine and now serves as CEO of the music‑technology company Singular Sound.

Magic Johnson was the Lakers’ point guard for 13 seasons, drafted first overall in 1979, and won a championship and NBA Finals MVP as a rookie before adding four more titles in the 1980s; after a four‑year retirement prompted by player protests, he returned in 1996 at age 36 to play 32 games before retiring permanently, and later became a prominent businessman—named by Ebony in 2009 as one of America’s most influential Black businessmen—and a part‑owner of the Lakers for several years.

Tenacious D, an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles in 1994 by Jack Black (lead vocalist/guitarist) and Kyle Gass (lead guitarist/vocalist), released three albums—*Tenacious D* (2001), *The Pick of Destiny* (2006) and *Rize of the Fenix* (2012); they first rose to prominence in 1997 after starring in their eponymous television series and beginning to support major rock acts.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and, after the 1603 union of crowns, ruled England and Ireland as James I until his death; although Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with distinct parliaments, judiciaries and laws, he championed a single parliament for both realms, succeeded largely in Scotland, but encountered major challenges in England, notably the 1605 Gunpowder Plot and ongoing conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also called Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality show, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley, a British actor, broadcaster and voice‑over artist born on 4 October 1967 who has been the voice of the UK version of Big Brother since its 2000 debut, left Channel 4 in July 2011 to continue narrating the revived series on Channel 5, and is widely recognised for his Geordie‑accented voice.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked German federal state bordering Brandenburg, Saxony‑Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland’s Lower Silesian and Lubusz Voivodeships, and the Czech Republic’s Karlovy Vary, Liberec, and Ústí nad Labem regions; it is the tenth largest of Germany’s sixteen states (18,413 km²) and the sixth most populous with about four million residents, has a history spanning over a millennium, and, together with the Saale‑Unstrut area, forms one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and one of only two of Germany’s thirteen wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park located in the East End neighborhood of Cincinnati, United States, and “In the End” is a song by the American rock band Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown launched her solo career by releasing “I Want You Back” with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon and Naseeruddin Shah with supporting roles by Paresh Rawal, Gulshan Grover, Raza Murad and Sadashiv Amrapurkar; it was released on 1 July 1994, became the second‑highest‑grossing Indian film of that year, received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995, originally featured Divya Bharti as the female lead before her death led to Raveena Tandon’s casting, and is remembered for its chart‑topping songs.
Hourglass is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure and also the title of singer‑songwriter James Taylor’s fourteenth studio album.

Shane Black (born December 16, 1961) is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor best known for writing the 1987 action film *Lethal Weapon* and for making his directorial debut with *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang* in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond spy film and the seventh and final installment featuring Roger Moore as the MI6 agent James Bond.

Papua, Indonesia’s largest and easternmost province that covers most of western New Guinea, was formerly known as Irian Jaya (earlier called West Irian or Irian Barat) and once comprised all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unverified rumors suggested his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez entered the music scene in 1999 with her debut album *On the 6* and the number‑one single “If You Had My Love”; in 2001 she made history as the first woman to have a number‑one album (*J.Lo*) and a number‑one film (*The Wedding Planner*) in the same week, and after her second divorce, her high‑profile relationship with Ben Affleck influenced her 2002 album *This Is Me … Then* while the 2003 film *Gigli* flopped; she later married longtime friend Marc Anthony, achieved box‑office success with *Shall We Dance?*, gave birth to twins in 2008, and after a less successful period returned to prominence in 2011 as an *American Idol* judge and with “On the Floor,” one of the best‑selling singles ever.

A working animal is a usually domesticated animal kept and trained by humans to perform tasks such as providing tractive force (e.g., draft horses, logging elephants), assisting humans (e.g., guide or assistance dogs), milking, or herding, with human training required to encourage cooperation; while rare instances involve tamed wild animals used for novelty or entertainment, true working animals are characterized by domestication, trustworthiness, and a mild temperament.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct‑to‑video comedy directed by Alan Metter and starring Mary‑Kate and Ashley Olsen; Top Latin Albums is Billboard magazine’s leading chart for Spanish‑language full‑length albums in the U.S. market; and the Regional Mexican Albums chart is a weekly, genre‑specific Billboard listing for Mexican‑style music in the United States.

Vedam (English: Chant) is a 2010 Indian Telugu-language drama film written and directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi, featuring an ensemble cast that includes Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Men in Black II (stylized as MIIB) is a 2002 American science‑fiction action comedy film starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Johnny Knoxville, Rosario Dawson, Tony Shalhoub, and Rip Torn.

Sancho Panza is a fictional character in Miguel de Cervantes’s 1605 novel *Don Quixote*, serving as Don Quixote’s squire and offering commentary throughout the work in the form of “sanchismos,” a blend of broad humor, ironic Spanish proverbs, and earthy wit.
The Adventures of Pluto Nash is a 2002 Australian‑American science‑fiction action comedy film starring Eddie Murphy in a dual role and directed by Ron Underwood.
Ibsen attended the world premiere of Hedda Gabler, which was held on 31 January 1891 at Munich’s Residenztheater.
Brazzers is a pornographic production company based in Montreal, Canada.
Timothy Simon Roth, born on 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director.

Juventus Football Club S.p.A., commonly called Juve, is a professional Italian football club based in Turin, founded in 1897 by a group of young Torinese students including its first president Eugenio Canfari and his brother Enrico; it is the second oldest active club in Italy after Genoa’s football section (1893), has worn a black‑and‑white striped home kit since 1903, and currently plays its home matches at the 41,507‑capacity Juventus Stadium.

Viola Davis performed supporting and minor roles in various films and television series during the late 1990s and early 2000s, including the movies Kate & Leopold (2001) and Far from Heaven (2002) as well as the TV series Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

Jenna Jameson, born Jenna Marie Massoli on April 9, 1974, is an American entrepreneur, webcam model and former pornographic film actress who has been dubbed the world’s most famous adult entertainment performer and “The Queen of Porn,” beginning her erotic video career in 1993 after working as a stripper and glamour model.
