The New Orleans Pelicans are an NBA franchise that competes in the league’s Western Conference Southwest Division.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event that ran from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast via closed‑circuit television and later on pay‑per‑view, first under the National Wrestling Alliance (NWA) and later World Championship Wrestling (WCW); it followed a tradition dating back to the 1960s‑1980s of Jim Crockett Promotions (JCP) holding major Thanksgiving and Christmas shows, primarily at Greensboro Coliseum, with the 1985, 1987, and 1997 editions marking the third, fifth, and fifteenth installments of the series respectively.

Jack Ryan Falahee (born February 20, 1989) is an American actor best known for playing Connor Walsh on the ABC legal drama *How to Get Away with Murder* and Benjamin Stringfellow on the PBS historical series *Mercy Street*.

Seohyun (Seo Ju‑hyun, born June 28 1991) is a South Korean singer and actress who debuted with the girl group Girls’ Generation in August 2007 and later joined its subgroup TTS; the group became one of South Korea’s best‑selling and globally popular acts. Beyond group activities, she has performed in stage productions such as Moon Embracing the Sun, Gone with the Wind, and Mamma Mia. She launched her solo career with the debut EP Don’t Say No on January 17 2017, becoming the third member of Girls’ Generation to release solo material.

The Apple II, an 8‑bit home computer introduced in 1977, was one of the first highly successful mass‑produced microcomputers; it was primarily designed by Steve Wozniak, with Steve Jobs overseeing its foam‑molded plastic case and Rod Holt creating its switching power supply, and it launched the Apple II series (trademarked “Apple ][” and later “Apple //”), a family of text‑command home computers manufactured by Apple Computer (now Apple Inc.). Stephen “Woz” Gary Wozniak (born August 11 1950) is an American inventor, electronics engineer, programmer, philanthropist, and technology entrepreneur who co‑founded Apple Inc.

A&E, formerly the Arts & Entertainment Network, is an American cable and satellite television channel that serves as the flagship property of A&E Networks, a joint venture equally owned (50 % each) by the Hearst Corporation and Disney’s ABC Television Group, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company.

L.A. Reid is a music executive who has served as chairman and CEO of Epic Records (a Sony Music division), president and CEO of Arista Records, chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group, founded and led Hitco Music Publishing, and co‑founded LaFace Records.

The title “Veeram (Valour)” refers to two separate Indian films: a 2014 Tamil action movie directed by Siva and produced by Vijaya Productions, and a 2016 epic historical drama written and directed by Jayaraj.

Home for the Holidays refers to two distinct films: a 1972 American made‑for‑television horror movie directed by John Llewellyn Moxey, produced by Aaron Spelling and starring Sally Field, Eleanor Parker, Julie Harris, Jessica Walter and Walter Brennan, which premiered on ABC on November 28, 1972; and a 1995 feature film starring Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton and David Strathairn.

Ronald Bilius “Ron” Weasley is a fictional character in J. K. Rowling’s Harry Potter series.
Reign Over Me is a 2007 American drama film written and directed by Mike Binder, produced by his brother Jack Binder, distributed by Columbia Pictures, and released on March 23, 2007.
Colin Rand Kaepernick, born November 3 1987, is an American football quarterback who is currently a free agent.

In 2016, actress Sheryl Lee appeared in the film Café Society and later completed the 2017 Showtime revival of Twin Peaks, reprising her role as Laura Palmer, while Sheryl Lee Ralph performed as Madame Morrible in the Broadway production of Wicked that same year.

"Same Old Love" is a track by American singer Selena Gomez from her second studio album, *Revival* (2015); the album debuted at number one on the Billboard 200, and its first three singles—“Good for You,” “Same Old Love,” and “Hands to Myself”—each reached the top of the U.S. Mainstream Top 40 chart.
Weekly Idol is a show hosted by comedian Jeong Hyeong-don and rapper Defconn.

Heavy metal is a rock music genre that emerged in the late 1960s and early 1970s, primarily in the United Kingdom and the United States, and was later continued in the late 1970s by new wave British heavy metal bands such as Iron Maiden and Saxon.
Ashton Kutcher later starred in several romantic comedies, notably Guess Who (2005), A Lot Like Love (2005), What Happens in Vegas (2008), and No Strings Attached (2011).

Topman, a subsidiary of the Arcadia Group—alongside brands such as Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins—operates a chain of high‑street men’s clothing stores that are found on nearly every UK high street and also maintain main‑street outlets in six Irish cities and towns.

At the onset of the Industrial Revolution, Wales shifted from an agricultural society to an industrial nation due to the development of mining and metallurgical industries, and the exploitation of the South Wales Coalfield spurred a rapid increase in the country's population.
Tool is a band that has won three Grammy Awards, performed worldwide tours, and released albums that topped the charts in several countries.
YouTube is an American video‑sharing website headquartered in San Bruno, California, and it is ranked by Alexa Internet as the second most popular site worldwide.

Trollhunters is an American computer‑animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.

The Armenian Genocide, also called the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of about 1.5 million Armenians—mostly Ottoman citizens—throughout the Ottoman Empire and its successor, the Republic of Turkey; similarly, the Ottoman authorities targeted other indigenous Christian groups, such as Assyrians and Greeks, in the Assyrian and Greek genocides, which many historians view as part of the same genocidal policy.
Marcus Morgan Bentley, born on 4 October 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice‑over artist.

William Jefferson Clinton, born August 19 1946, is an American politician who served as the 42nd President of the United States from 1993 to 2001, with his first inauguration taking place on January 20 1993 on the West Front of the United States Capitol Building in Washington, D.C.

Danny Boyle (born 20 October 1956) is an English director, producer, screenwriter and theatre director best known for films such as Shallow Grave, Trainspotting, The Beach, 28 Days Later, Sunshine, Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours and Steve Jobs; The Beach, a 2000 adventure‑drama he directed, adapts Alex Garland’s 1996 novel and was scripted by John Hodge.
In the first week after the image of the dress appeared, it generated over 10 million tweets, with users employing hashtags like #thedress, #whiteandgold and #blackandblue.
Major Bruce Middleton Hope Shand, MC and bar, (22 January 1917 – 11 June 2006) was an officer in the British Army.
Advertising is an audio or visual marketing communication that uses openly sponsored, nonpersonal messages to promote or sell a product, service, or idea.

The 2001 film *The Others* earned eight Goya Awards—including Best Film and Best Director—becoming the first English‑language movie to win the Goya Best Film prize without any Spanish dialogue, and it received six Saturn Award nominations (such as Best Director and Best Writing for Amenábar and Best Performance by a Younger Actor for Alakina Mann) while winning three Saturn Awards for Best Horror Film, Best Actress (Nicole Kidman) and Best Supporting Actress (Fionnula Flanagan).
Ralph Fults (1911–1993) was a Depression-era outlaw and escape artist who was associated with Raymond Hamilton, Bonnie Parker, and Clyde Barrow of the Barrow Gang.

The 14th Dalai Lama, religious name Tenzin Gyatso (born Lhamo Thondup on 6 July 1935), was born in Taktser village, Amdo, Tibet (then part of Qinghai, Republic of China); he was identified as the tulku of the 13th Dalai Lama in 1937 and publicly recognized in 1939 near Bumchen, and after the 1959 Tibetan uprising he fled to India, where he now lives as a refugee.

Miracle at St. Anna is a World War II film set in German‑occupied Italy that follows four Buffalo Soldiers of the 92nd Infantry Division who seek refuge in a small Tuscan village and form a bond with its residents; the story is told as a flashback narrated by a surviving soldier reflecting on these events from 1980s New York.
Caroline Bouvier Kennedy, born on November 27 1957, is an American author, attorney, and diplomat who served as the United States Ambassador to Japan from 2013 to 2017.

Home for the Holidays (1995) features an ensemble cast that includes Holly Hunter, Robert Downey Jr., Anne Bancroft, Charles Durning, Dylan McDermott, Geraldine Chaplin, Steve Guttenberg, Cynthia Stevenson, Claire Danes, Austin Pendleton, and David Strathairn.
Anne Rice was born in New Orleans, spent her early life there, and later moved first to Texas and then to San Francisco.
Stephen Hillenburg was born in Lawton, Oklahoma, grew up in Anaheim, California, and as a child developed a fascination with the ocean and an interest in art.

The passage explains that a mendicant way of life—characterized by reliance on alms and asceticism—is practiced by many religious groups, including Catholic mendicant orders, Hindu ascetics, certain Sufi dervishes, and the monastic orders of Jainism and Buddhism; it also defines a monk (from Greek monachos “single, solitary” and Latin monachus) as a person who lives a monastic, ascetic life either alone or with others, dedicating themselves to serving all living beings or voluntarily withdrawing from mainstream society to devote themselves to prayer and contemplation.
The Mod Squad was an American crime drama series that aired on ABC from 1968 to 1973.
The Dark Tower is an upcoming American film that combines science‑fantasy, western, action, and horror elements, and it is directed and co‑written by Nikolaj Arcel.

Arizona, located in the southwestern United States, is the sixth‑largest and 14th‑most populous state, becoming the 48th state on February 14, 1912; roughly one‑quarter of its land consists of Indian reservations that house 27 federally recognized Native American tribes, including the Navajo Nation—the largest tribe in both the state and the nation with over 300,000 members—making Arizona notable for its high Native American population.
Smriti Mandhana, born on 18 July 1996, is an Indian cricketer who plays for the Indian women's cricket team.

Emma Charlotte Duerre Watson (born 15 April 1990) is a French‑British actress, model and activist; she was born in Paris, raised in Oxfordshire, attended the Dragon School and trained as an actress at the Oxford branch of Stagecoach Theatre Arts.
Angela Bassett began her film career in the mid‑1980s after earning a Bachelor of Arts degree from Yale University and a Master of Fine Arts degree from drama school.

The Congressional Space Medal of Honor, NASA’s highest award, is presented by the President in Congress’s name based on recommendations from the NASA Administrator and is granted to astronauts who achieve extraordinary feats during NASA‑authorized spaceflight; the passage also notes Frank Frederick Borman II, born March 14 1928, a retired USAF colonel.
The Saw film franchise has collectively grossed over $873 million at the worldwide box office.
Down with Love is a romantic comedy film released in 2003.
Paul Nicholls is an actor best known for portraying Joe Wicks in the BBC series EastEnders and DS Sam Casey in the ITV series Law & Order: UK.

Rick Yune was a main cast member of Netflix’s original series *Marco Polo*, which was cancelled on December 12, 2016.

Kentucky is renowned for its horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal industry, the historic My Old Kentucky Home site, automobile manufacturing, tobacco production, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Boyhood, filmed between 2002 and 2013, follows Mason Evans Jr. (played by Coltrane) from age six to eighteen as he grows up in Texas with his divorced parents, portrayed by Arquette and Hawke.
The 2016 film *Hush* was produced by Trevor Macy through Intrepid Pictures and by Jason Blum through his Blumhouse Productions banner.

The Penibaetic System, also known as the Sistema Penibético or Cordillera Penibética, is the southernmost of the three mountain‑range systems that make up the Baetic System in the southern Iberian Peninsula.

Bonobos offers a comprehensive range of men’s apparel—including suits, trousers, denim, shirts, shorts, swimwear, outerwear, and accessories—while Topman, a brand within the Arcadia Group (which also owns Burton, Miss Selfridge, Wallis, Evans, and Dorothy Perkins), operates a widespread chain of high‑street men’s clothing stores throughout the United Kingdom and maintains outlets in six cities and towns in Ireland.
"Roar" is a song by American singer Katy Perry from her fourth studio album, Prism (2013), released as the album’s lead single on August 10, 2013.
Saturn Corporation, also called Saturn LLC, is a registered trademark founded on January 7 1985 as a subsidiary of General Motors.

The Armenian Genocide, also referred to as the Armenian Holocaust, was the Ottoman government’s systematic extermination of roughly 1.5 million Armenians—primarily Ottoman citizens—within the Ottoman Empire and its successor, the Republic of Turkey, and the modern Turkish state denies that the term “genocide” accurately describes the mass killings that began in 1915.

Muslims believe the Quran was verbally revealed by God to Muhammad through the angel Gabriel over roughly 23 years, beginning on 22 December 609 CE when Muhammad was 40 and concluding in 632, the year of his death.

The human brain, together with the spinal cord, forms the central nervous system and comprises the cerebrum, brainstem, and cerebellum, with the cerebrum being the largest component; beneath the cerebral cortex lie key structures such as the thalamus, epithalamus, pineal gland, hypothalamus, pituitary gland, subthalamus, limbic elements like the amygdala and hippocampus, the claustrum, various basal ganglia nuclei, basal forebrain structures, and three circumventricular organs.
T2 Trainspotting is a 2017 British comedy‑drama film set in and around Edinburgh, Scotland.

AMGTV is an American family‑oriented television network that offers a diverse lineup of programming, including drama, sports, movies, entertainment, how‑to segments, hunting and fishing content, children’s shows, and other features.

Sir Donald George “Don” Bradman (1908–2001), an Australian cricketer known as “The Don,” is widely regarded as the greatest batsman of all time; even after becoming reclusive in his later years, his opinions remained highly sought after, and his status as a national icon endured, exemplified by Prime Minister John Howard’s 2001 description of him as “the greatest living Australian.”

Margaret Hilda Thatcher (13 October 1925 – 8 April 2013) was a British stateswoman who served as Prime Minister from 1979 to 1990, making her the longest‑serving British prime minister of the 20th century, and as Leader of the Conservative Party from 1975 to 1990; she was the first woman to hold the office of prime minister and the first woman to lead a major political party in the United Kingdom, having defeated Heath in the 1975 Conservative leadership election.

Randy Mario Poffo (November 15, 1952 – May 20, 2011), better known as “Macho Man” Randy Savage, was an American professional wrestler and color commentator most famous for his work with the World Wrestling Federation (now WWE) and later World Championship Wrestling.
Alice Cooper, born Vincent Damon Furnier on February 4, 1948, is an American singer, songwriter, and actor whose career has lasted more than five decades.

EA Black Box, originally named Black Box Games, was a video game developer founded in 1998 by former Radical Entertainment employees in Burnaby, British Columbia, Canada, and was later acquired by Electronic Arts.

Baiae was an ancient mineral‑spring and coastal resort on the northwest shore of the Gulf of Naples, while nearby Herculaneum (modern Ercolano in Campania) was a Roman town destroyed by Vesuvius’s pyroclastic flows in 79 AD and now exists as ruins; the Naples region is rich in culturally significant sites such as the Palace of Caserta and the Roman ruins of Pompeii and Herculaneum, and famous ruins can be found worldwide across ancient Chinese, Indus Valley, Judean, African, Greek, Egyptian, Roman, Incan and Mayan civilizations.

No Country for Old Men is a cat‑and‑mouse drama set in the desert landscape of 1980 West Texas, starring Tommy Lee Jones, Javier Bardem and Josh Brolin, and follows a Texas welder and Vietnam veteran; the passage also enumerates Tommy Lee Jones’s notable starring roles, including Woodrow F. Call in the TV mini‑series Lonesome Dove, Agent K in the Men in Black films, Sheriff Ed Tom Bell in No Country for Old Men, Two‑Face in Batman Forever, terrorist William Strannix in Under Siege, a Texas Ranger in Man of the House, rancher Pete Perkins in The Three Burials of Melquiades Estrada (which he directed), Colonel Chester Phillips in Captain America: The First Avenger, CIA Director Robert Dewey in Jason Bourne, and Warden Dwight McClusky in Natural Born Killers.

Palo Alto is a charter city situated in the northwest corner of Santa Clara County, California, within the San Francisco Bay Area, and its name derives from the Spanish words “palo” (stick or tree) and “alto” (tall), together meaning “tall tree.”

Albert Lawrence Brooks, born Albert Lawrence Einstein on July 22 1947, is an American actor, filmmaker, author, and comedian; the film Finding Dory was directed by Andrew Stanton with co‑direction by Angus MacLane, and its screenplay was written by Stanton and Victoria Strouse.

Morse code transmits text as on‑off tones, lights, or clicks, allowing skilled listeners or observers to understand messages without special equipment; its characters vary in length roughly inversely to their English frequency, making common letters shorter and speeding communication. Compared with voice, it is less affected by poor signal conditions yet remains human‑readable, and it is employed by many amateur radio repeaters for identification even in voice‑based systems. In emergencies, Morse can be sent with improvised keying methods, making it one of the simplest and most versatile telecommunication techniques.
Alexandra Anna Daddario, born March 16 1986, is an American actress.

The 2005 Hindu Kush earthquake struck northeastern Afghanistan on December 12 at 21:47 UTC with a magnitude of 6.5, and the Hindu Kush is an 800‑km mountain range along the Afghan‑Pakistan border extending from central Afghanistan to northern Pakistan, featuring many snow‑capped peaks, the highest of which is Tirich Mir (7708 m) in Pakistan’s Chitral District, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
In 2015, Ripon College in Wisconsin had a student body of roughly 840, with the majority residing on campus.

Fox Sports is a brand encompassing various sports channels, broadcast divisions, programming, and media worldwide that are controlled or partially owned by Rupert Murdoch’s family; Murdoch exercised full control as Chairman and CEO of the global media holding News Corporation—then the world’s second‑largest media conglomerate—and its successors, News Corp and 21st Century Fox, after the companies split on 28 June 2013, with the Murdoch Family Trust holding ownership of both 21st Century Fox and News Corp.
Wildfang is a US-based women's apparel company that offers tomboyish-style clothing.
Bessie Smith (April 15, 1894 – September 26, 1937) was an American blues singer.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that creates methods and technologies for converting spoken language into text by computers, drawing on research from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering.
Aleister Crowley, born Edward Alexander Crowley on 12 October 1875 and deceased 1 December 1947, was an English occultist, ceremonial magician, poet, painter, novelist, and mountaineer.

Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge, released on 20 October 1995, stars Shah Rukh Khan and Kajol, and was filmed in India, London, and Switzerland from September 1994 to August 1995.

Timothy Simon Roth, born 14 May 1961, is an English actor and director, while Tim Roth, born 6 December 1975, is the guitarist, backing vocalist, and sole remaining founding member of the Canadian melodic death‑metal and progressive‑metal band Into Eternity.
In 1986, Tatum O'Neal married professional tennis player John McEnroe, and they have three children together.

Sean Penn debuted in the drama Taps (1981) and built a diverse 1980s résumé with films such as Fast Times at Ridgemont High, At Close Range, State of Grace, and Carlito’s Way, gaining critical attention; he rose to prominence with Dead Man Walking (1995), earning his first Oscar nomination and the Berlin Film Festival Best Actor award, followed by Oscar nods for Sweet and Lowdown (1999) and I Am Sam (2001). He won Best Actor Oscars for Mystic River (2003) and Milk (2008), and his 2007 biographical drama Into the Wild received critical acclaim and two Academy Award nominations.

Volcanic outgassing likely formed Earth’s early, oxygen‑poor atmosphere and oceans, making the initial environment toxic to modern life; as the planet cooled, a solid crust developed, permitting liquid water on the surface, while ongoing plate tectonics continues to shape oceans, continents, and the species they support, and contemporary biospheric changes—especially human activity—significantly impact the atmosphere, ozone layer, greenhouse‑gas levels, soil productivity, and air and water quality, with water covering 71 % of Earth’s surface.
Nuuk is the capital and largest city of Greenland, situated within the municipality of Sermersooq.

How to Train Your Dragon 2, written and directed by Dean DeBlois, features the returning voice cast from the first film and adds new talent—including Cate Blanchett as Valka, Djimon Hounsou as Drago, and Kit Harington—alongside Jay Baruchel, Gerard Butler, Craig Ferguson, America Ferrera, Jonah Hill, Christopher Mintz‑Plasse, T.J. Miller, and Kristen Wiig.

Down with Love is a 2003 romantic comedy directed by Peyton Reed, written by Eve Ahlert and Dennis Drake, and starring Renée Zellweger, Ewan McGregor, Sarah Paulson, and David Hyde Pierce; the film serves as a pastiche of 1950s‑60s sex comedies, especially Doris Day and Rock Hudson’s Pillow Talk (1959), Lover Come Back (1961), and Send Me No Flowers (1964). A television series of the same name aired in Taiwan, first on free‑to‑air China Television (CTV) from 31 January to 23 May 2010 (Sundays, 22:00‑23:30) and concurrently on cable TV Gala Television (GTV) Variety Show/CH 28 from 2 February to 30 May 2010 (Sundays, 20:00‑21:30).
The album “Paris” by Paris Hilton incorporates elements of reggae, soul, and pop rock in its production.

Stripes is a 1981 American buddy military comedy directed by Ivan Reitman, starring Bill Murray, Harold Ramis, Warren Oates, P. J. Soles, Sean Young, and John Candy, and it featured early significant film roles for John Larroquette, John Diehl, Conrad Dunn, and Judge Reinhold, with additional early appearances by Joe Flaherty, Dave Thomas, Timothy Busfield, and Bill Paxton.
Janelle Monáe Robinson, born on December 1 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who is signed to her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, as well as Atlantic Records.

Jewell is a singer best known for her track “Love or Lust,” which appeared in Bill Duke’s film *Deep Cover*, and for providing choruses on notable West Coast rap songs such as Snoop Dogg’s “Gin and Juice” and Dr. Dre’s “Let Me Ride.”

The University of Mississippi’s student body is predominantly local, with about 55 % of undergraduates and 60 % of all students coming from Mississippi; minorities comprise 23 % of the population, and international students represent 90 different nations.
The Mighty Ducks was produced by The Kerner Entertainment Company and Avnet–Kerner Productions and distributed by Walt Disney Pictures.

Johanna Braddy played Jenny Matrix in the web series *Video Game High School* (2012‑2014), co‑starred as Anna Martin in the Lifetime dark comedy‑drama *Unreal* in 2015, and currently stars as Shelby Wyatt in the ABC thriller *Quantico*.

Martin Van Buren (December 5 1782 – July 24 1862) was an American Democratic politician who served as the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841, after previously holding the offices of eighth Vice President (1833‑37) and tenth Secretary of State (1829‑31) under Andrew Jackson; he was a key supporter and organizer for Jackson’s 1828 campaign, briefly served as Governor of New York before resigning to become Secretary of State, helped resolve the Petticoat affair, and in 1831 received a recess appointment from Jackson as American minister to Britain.
Camden, New Jersey hosts Rutgers University–Camden, originally founded as the South Jersey Law School in 1926, and the Cooper Medical School of Rowan University, which opened in 2012.

Michigan, located in the Great Lakes and Midwestern regions of the United States, is the tenth most populous state and ranks 11th in total area, making it the largest state east of the Mississippi River; it is uniquely composed of two peninsulas, which contributes to its prominence in recreational boating, and, like all states, serves as a constituent political entity of the United States.

Penguin Books transformed 1930s publishing by introducing low‑cost paperbacks sold for sixpence in Woolworths and other high‑street shops, making high‑quality fiction and non‑fiction widely accessible to the mass market.
The 2008 film *Australia* was produced in Sydney, Darwin, Kununurra, and Bowen.

Billy Ray Cyrus is an American country music singer, songwriter, actor, and philanthropist who contributed to making country music a global phenomenon; “Excuse My French” is the debut studio album of American rapper French Montana; and “Excuse My French” is also a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, based on his experiences in a public middle school after returning from Saudi Arabia, which faced censorship challenges that forced script adjustments while preserving its core theme of religious discrimination.
In 2013, Derek Hough starred in the South Korean‑American independent dance film “Make Your Move,” which is inspired by Romeo and Juliet.

"Bad Romance" is a 2009 song by American singer Lady Gaga from her EP *The Fame Monster*; after an illegal demo leak, she premiered the final version at Alexander McQueen’s Paris Fashion Week show in October 2009 and released its cover art, and the single went on to top charts worldwide, selling 12 million copies and becoming one of the best‑selling singles ever. The title also refers to a 2011 independent drama film, *Bad Romance* (original French title *Les Mauvais Romans*).

DreamWorks Animation has released 34 feature films, encompassing the Shrek franchise and its prequel‑spinoff Puss in Boots, as well as the Madagascar, Kung Fu Panda, How to Train Your Dragon, and Trolls series, alongside standalone hits such as Monsters vs. Aliens (2009), Rise of the Guardians (2012), The Croods (2013) and Home (2015); additionally, the studio co‑produces the American computer‑animated fantasy series Trollhunters for Netflix, created by Guillermo del Toro and produced with Double Dare You.

Christopher Livingstone Eubanks (born 8 August 1966), known as Chris Eubank, is a British former professional boxer who fought from 1985 to 1998, while his son Christopher Livingstone “Chris Eubank Jr.” (born 18 September 1989) is a British professional boxer who has held the IBO super‑middleweight title since February 2017, previously winning the WBA interim middleweight title in 2015 and the British middleweight title in 2016; as of May 2017 he was ranked the world’s fifth‑best super‑middleweight by BoxRec, seventh‑best middleweight by The Ring magazine, and eighth‑best middleweight by the Transnational Boxing Rankings Board.

Sophia Anna Bush, born July 8 1982, is an American actress, director, spokesperson, and activist best known for her film roles in *John Tucker Must Die* (2006), *The Hitcher* (2007), and *The Narrows* (2008).

Rupert Murdoch currently serves as chairman and acting CEO of Fox News, while his younger son James Rupert Jacob Murdoch (born 13 December 1972), an Australian‑British‑American businessman, holds the positions of chief executive officer of 21st Century Fox and chairman of Sky plc; following the 28 June 2013 split of News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch retained full control as chairman and CEO of the resulting global media entities, News Corp and 21st Century Fox.
In 2013, Gal Gadot was the second highest‑earning actress/model in Israel, ranking behind Bar Refaeli but ahead of Esti Ginzburg and Shlomit Malka, with most of her income coming from acting.
Creedence Clearwater Revival (CCR) was an American rock band active in the late 1960s and early 1970s.
Calcaneal spurs are usually identified through a radiographic examination, commonly known as an x‑ray.
The South Wales Coalfield (Welsh: Maes glo De Cymru) is a large coal‑rich region in South Wales, notably encompassing the South Wales Valleys.

The CONCACAF Champions League is an annual continental football club competition organized by CONCACAF for top clubs from North America, Central America, and the Caribbean, originally called the CONCACAF Champions' Cup when it began in 1962.

After George’s death in 1936, Mary of Teck became queen mother when her eldest son Edward ascended the throne, but he abdicated later that year to marry the twice‑divorced American Wallis Simpson; she then supported her second son Albert, who became George VI and reigned until his death in 1952, and Mary herself died the following year during the reign of her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth II, who had not yet been crowned.
The film Poseidon earned $181,674,817 worldwide against a $160 million budget.
The NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Drama Series was first presented in 1996, and Omar Epps and Joe Morton share the record for the most wins, each having won three times.

Human trafficking involves the trade of people primarily for forced labour, sexual slavery, or commercial sexual exploitation, generating an estimated $150 billion in annual profits (2014) according to the ILO; of the 14.2 million victims, 68 % are exploited for labour, 22 % for sexual exploitation, and 10 % in state‑imposed forced labour.
The 2011 film Rio was followed by a sequel, Rio 2, which was released on April 11 2014.

Francis I (Franz Stefan, François Étienne, 1708‑1765) served as Holy Roman Emperor and Grand Duke of Tuscany, though his wife exercised the actual authority of those offices, while an earlier Francis I (François Ier, 1494‑1547) was the first Valois king of France from the Angoulême line, ruling from 1515 until his death; he was nicknamed “François au Grand Nez,” “Grand Colas,” and “Roi‑Chevalier” for his active role in wars against his rival Charles V, formed a controversial Franco‑Ottoman alliance with Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent, and fought the Italian War of 1536‑1538 against Charles V.

Peking University (PKU), known as Beida in Chinese, is a leading Chinese research university in Beijing and a member of the C9 League; founded in 1898 as the Imperial University of Peking to replace the ancient Taixue/Guozijian, it initially served as the highest education administration in China and is consistently ranked as the top mainland Chinese higher‑learning institution.
Lemmy was noted for his appearance—particularly his friendly mutton chops—along with his distinctive gravelly voice and unique bass playing style.
Global warming threatens human food security by reducing crop yields and may force the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.

Australia is a 2008 Australian‑American‑British romantic historical adventure drama directed by Baz Luhrmann, starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman, and described as an epic historical romantic drama.
Michael Dwayne Vick (born June 26, 1980) is a former American football quarterback who played 13 NFL seasons, primarily with the Atlanta Falcons and the Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a variety of cultural expressions, including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and traditional practices such as food‑making and craft‑making, with oral traditions like tales, proverbs, and jokes forming a central component.
The First Motion Picture Unit created over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining, while also producing additional training films and training combat cameramen.

James Jones, the author, won the 1952 National Book Award for his debut novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was quickly adapted into a film and later a television series; James Jones, the basketball player, averaged 25 points per game as a senior to earn Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All‑State honors, has won three NBA championships (two with the Miami Heat and one with the Cleveland Cavaliers), reached the NBA Finals for a seventh straight year in 2017 alongside LeBron James, placed third in three‑point percentage in the 2007‑08 season, and won the Three‑Point Contest in 2011.
In 1999, the American Film Institute named Humphrey Bogart the greatest male star of classic American cinema.

Computer animation is the process of generating animated images, and Trollhunters is an American computer‑animated fantasy series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro, produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You.
Shane McMahon announced his resignation from WWE in 2009, with the resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker, an English actor, is best known for portraying the fourth incarnation of the Doctor in the science‑fiction series *Doctor Who* from 1974 to 1981—the longest tenure of any actor in the role—and for narrating the comedy series *Little Britain*, as well as providing narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and other television series.
Angelsberg is a small town situated within the commune of Fischbach in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site encompasses a cleanup project, the Columbia Generating Station commercial nuclear power plant, and several scientific research and development centers, including the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official appointed by the president who serves at the president’s pleasure without Senate confirmation, acting as the spokesperson for the executive branch—particularly the President, senior executives, and policies—and, through frequent media briefings, holds a prominent non‑Cabinet position.

Kentucky, nicknamed the “Bluegrass State” for the bluegrass thriving in its fertile pastures, features the central Bluegrass Region that includes its major cities Louisville and Lexington, and is renowned for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic My Old Kentucky Home site, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film starring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, who also appeared in The Cat in the Hat, Old Dogs, and Broken Bridges.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper who was formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5 2017, two new versions of “Despacito” were released: an electronic rendition produced by the American trio Major Lazer together with Colombian DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000, initially broadcast via closed‑circuit television and later via pay‑per‑view; it was produced by the National Wrestling Alliance and subsequently World Championship Wrestling. Beginning in 1987—after the WWF’s Survivor Series demanded exclusive cable carriage—Starrcade became the first NWA event shown on pay‑per‑view. In 2014 the WWE Network added the 1983‑1986 closed‑circuit shows to its pay‑per‑view library, rating them TV‑MA for the high level of violence, notably the “I Quit” match between Tully Blanchard and Magnum, T.A. The 1997 edition marked the fifteenth annual Starrcade PPV.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for the service and marks the return of a Star Trek series after the conclusion of Star Trek: Enterprise in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also competed in the World League of American Football with the Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album of American rapper French Montana, while the same title also refers to a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama that draws on his own middle‑school experiences after returning from Saudi Arabia; additionally, Benjamin Paul Ballance‑Drew (born 22 October 1983), known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip‑hop recording artist who also works as an actor, film director and producer.

A floppy disk (also called a floppy, diskette, or simply disk) is a type of disk storage that consists of a thin, flexible magnetic medium encased in a rectangular plastic enclosure lined with fabric to keep out dust.

Guatemala faced chronic instability and civil strife in the mid‑to‑late 19th century, and from 1960 to 1996 endured a violent civil war between a U.S.-backed government and leftist rebels, during which the military carried out genocidal massacres against the Maya population.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used to grasp and hold objects, and outside of medicine they are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps.
The TV series *The Closer* launched its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after its sixth season had been the highest‑rated drama on cable.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the fictional protagonist of the American drama series Lost, which aired on ABC from September 22 2004 to May 23 2010 across six seasons and 121 episodes, with its first season drawing an estimated average of 16 million viewers per episode.

Matthew David McConaughey (born November 4, 1969) is an American actor who, since 2011, has focused on dramatic roles, appearing in films such as *The Lincoln Lawyer*, *Bernie*, *Killer Joe* (all 2011), *The Paperboy*, *Mud*, and *Magic Mike* (2012), *The Wolf of Wall Street* and *Dallas Buyers Club* (2013), *Interstellar* (2014), as well as *The Sea of Trees* and *Free State of Jones* (both 2016); the 2012 film *Mud* also stars Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer is a writer best known for his books, including *Deep Blues*; his music journalism for the New York Times and *Rolling Stone*; his production of blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film *Deep Blues*; and his clarinet playing with the 1960s band the Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum (1912–1986) was an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer who is best known for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial after his father, Gutzon Borglum—the original designer and leader of the project from 1927 until his death in March 1941—passed away, at which point Lincoln Borglum assumed leadership of the construction.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau, written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams, starring Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 follows a group of teenage survivors—Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, Octavia Blake, Jasper Jordan, Monty Green, Raven Reyes, Finn Collins, John Murphy, and Wells Jaha—who are among the first people from the space habitat known as the Ark to return to a post‑nuclear‑apocalypse Earth, while also focusing on Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke’s mother, council member Marcus Kane, and Ark Chancellor Thelonious Jaha, Wells’ father.

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite later financial difficulties due to its pioneering nature, is regarded as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid effort that raised significant awareness and funds and served as a valuable model and inspiration for subsequent projects such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized by the media as one of India’s influential filmmakers, widely credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and reshaping the overall profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was presented by Stephen A. Douglas during the second Lincoln‑Douglas debate on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois; this debate was part of the Lincoln‑Douglas (or Great) Debates of 1858, a series of seven discussions between Republican Senate candidate Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas, with the Freeport, Quincy, and Alton debates drawing especially large crowds from neighboring states because of the nation‑wide significance of the slavery issue.

Easy A (stylized as easy A) is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck, written by Bert V. Royal, and starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica; she launched her professional writing career with Interview with the Vampire in 1976 while living in California and wrote its sequels in the 1980s, gaining increasing critical and popular acclaim after an initially mixed reception, and was married to poet‑painter Stan Rice for 41 years (1961–2002) until his death from brain cancer at age 60.

Camden, located in Camden County, New Jersey, had a population of 77,344 at the 2010 United States Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in the state, and its early‑twentieth‑century residents were primarily European immigrants; a city is defined as a large, permanent human settlement.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller‑drama film The Canyons, which was directed by Paul Schrader and received critical derision.

The Lincoln‑Douglas Debates, also known as the Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates held in seven Illinois towns between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas.

Homer is the name the ancient Greeks gave to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, the two epic poems that form the core of ancient Greek literature, while The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel written by American author Joe R. Lansdale.

Christopher Scott Kyle (April 8, 1974 – February 2, 2013) was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas, on February 2, 2013.

Audioslave was a four‑piece band featuring Soundgarden frontman Chris Cornell on lead vocals and rhythm guitar, alongside Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass and backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums); Wilk, known for his drumming with Rage (1991‑2000, 2007‑2011) and Audioslave (2001‑2007), began his career with Greta in 1990, co‑founded Rage with Morello and Zack de la Rocha in 1991, and as of 2016 was playing in Prophets of Rage with Commerford, Morello, Chuck D, B‑Real, and DJ Lord; Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of vocalist/rapper Zack de la Rocha, bassist/backing vocalist Tim Commerford, guitarist Tom Morello, and drummer Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson (born December 1, 1985) is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model who operates under her own imprint, Wondaland Arts Society, and is signed to Atlantic Records; in 2010 she released her critically acclaimed debut full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album sequel to her first EP, which was issued by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel written by Mark Helprin and published in 1983.

Lake Providence is a town that serves as the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States, while the University of Mississippi reports that roughly 55 % of its undergraduates and 60 % of its total student body are from Mississippi, with minorities comprising 23 % of students and international enrolments representing 90 different nations.
In July 2016, the series “Flaked” was renewed for a second season consisting of six episodes, slated to premiere on June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served twice in the New York State Assembly (1784‑1785 and 1798‑1799), was New York State Attorney General from 1789 to 1791, represented New York as a U.S. senator from 1791 to 1797, and culminated his political career by becoming vice president.

The Soyuz rocket was commissioned to launch the Soyuz series of spacecraft for the Soviet human spaceflight program, beginning with eight unmanned test flights and then the first nineteen manned launches; the Soyuz spacecraft, designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) in the 1960s, succeeded the Voskhod, was originally built for the Soviet manned lunar programs, and remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

In the year the band faced internal tensions, vocalist Zack de la Rocha left, causing Rage Against the Machine to break up; de la Rocha pursued a low‑key solo career while the remaining members created the rock supergroup Audioslave with former Soundgarden frontman Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007, when Rage announced a reunion and performed at Coachella after a seven‑year hiatus, and their fourth studio album, Renegades, had been released on December 5, 2000 by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free‑float market‑weighted index of 30 well‑established, financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, and Tata Motors, which is listed on the BSE, is a constituent of this index and is also traded on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost nation on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia with about 92.7 million people, making it the world’s 14th‑most‑populous and the ninth‑most‑populous Asian country; it borders China, Laos, Cambodia, Thailand (across the Gulf of Thailand), and the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia (across the South China Sea). Since 2000 its economic growth has been among the world’s highest, ranking first on the 2011 Global Growth Generators Index among major economies, and it remains one of four remaining one‑party socialist states that officially espouse communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins, marking his directorial debut.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary whose two dramatic acts of violence against the British and his execution at age 23 on 23 March 1931 made him a folk hero of the Indian independence movement, gaining widespread popularity after his death.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Hindi biographical sports drama “Dangal,” starring Aamir Khan and directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I (19 June 1566 – 27 March 1625) ruled Scotland as James VI from 24 July 1567 and, after the union of the Scottish and English crowns on 24 March 1603, ruled England and Ireland as James I, maintaining a personal union of two sovereign states that retained separate parliaments, judiciaries and laws; he strongly advocated a single parliament for both kingdoms but encountered numerous difficulties with Parliament during his English reign.

Danielle Cormack (born 26 December 1970) is a New Zealand stage and screen actress who began as an original core cast member of the long‑running soap Shortland Street and is also known for playing the Amazon Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, appearing in the 2009 film Separation City and the Australian series Rake, portraying Sydney underworld figure Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor, and most recently starring as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth for four years before departing the show in 2016.
Rob Sheridan (born October 11, 1979) is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer best known for his extensive work with the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade has starred and co‑starred in films such as *Tommy Boy*, *Black Sheep*, *Joe Dirt*, *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser*, *Grown Ups* and *Grown Ups 2* (among others), and *Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser* is a 2015 American comedy directed by Fred Wolf and written by Spade and Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born on August 16 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop received mixed reviews from critics but achieved strong commercial success, debuting at number one on the U.S. Billboard 200 with 258,000 first‑week sales, becoming Lady Gaga’s second consecutive number‑one album, ultimately selling 757,000 copies in the United States and 2.3 million copies worldwide, ranking as the ninth‑best‑selling album of 2013.
In 2006 the Red Hot Chili Peppers released “Stadium Arcadium,” the band’s fifth and final album featuring guitarist John Frusciante, who later confirmed his departure from the group in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, introduced policies known as Thatcherism; she remains a controversial figure, celebrated as one of the greatest and most influential British politicians, while debates over the merits of Thatcherism continue.

Michael Andrew “Duff” McKagan (born February 5, 1964) is an American musician, singer, songwriter and author who has also written weekly columns on various topics for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, also narrates commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially València, is the capital of Spain’s autonomous community of Valencia and the nation’s third‑largest city after Madrid and Barcelona, with about 800,000 residents in its administrative centre and a metropolitan population estimated between 1.7 and 2.5 million; the Valencian Community, also called the Valencian Country, is an autonomous region whose homonymous capital, Valencia, ranks as the third‑largest city and metro area in Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and later by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
Make It or Break It was announced on April 26 2012 to end after its third season, with the series finale airing on May 14 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an interdisciplinary subfield of computational linguistics that combines linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering to convert spoken language into text, enabling applications such as voice user interfaces (e.g., voice dialing and call routing), domotic appliance control, audio search, simple data entry, structured document preparation, speech‑to‑text processing, and aircraft Direct Voice Input; its progress is reflected not only in a surge of academic publications but also in widespread industry adoption of deep‑learning methods by major players including Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, iFlyTek, and CDAC.

Richard Alf (1952–2012) was an American businessman and former comic‑book store owner who co‑founded the event that became San Diego Comic‑Con International, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970, alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry, and he served as its chairman beginning that year.
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee as the lead character.

France’s Dubuisson posted a 67 to join South Africa’s Van Zyl at 16‑under, while Rory McIlroy recorded his third consecutive 67, moving to 15‑under alongside Thailand’s Kiradech Aphibarnrat and featuring an eagle on the 12th as he chases his first win since May; after a level‑par start, three‑putts and a brief putter‑throwing outburst, he rebounded with a birdie on 11 and an eagle on 13. McIlroy, who ruptured a left‑ankle ligament in July, missed several events but returned to defend his US PGA title at Whistling Straits, played three FedEx Cup playoffs and tied 26th at the Frys.com Open, now targeting a third Race to Dubai title in four years and leading England’s Danny Willett by 271 points with three tournaments left after the Turkish Open. Englishmen Chris Wood (‑13) and Richard Bland (‑12), who were tied for second overnight, have slipped to fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman told the BBC that a meaningful national dialogue requires the government to present concrete solutions and a spokesperson for the royal family, noting Crown Prince Salman al‑Khalifa as a reformist amid a court split between his reformist stance and hard‑liners led by unelected Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al‑Khalifa, who fear concessions will spur further demands; despite this, Sheikh Salman urged immediate dialogue, while al‑Wefaq’s leader highlighted youth disillusionment, the need to work with reformist Sunnis like the US‑ and UK‑educated Crown Prince, and the collapse of a seven‑point plan for a constitutional monarchy when GCC troops intervened on 14 March 2011; he expressed hope that US Secretary of State John Kerry would apply stronger pressure for human rights, criticized the UK for private rather than public calls for reform, reaffirmed al‑Wefaq’s commitment to peaceful demonstrations despite a ban, and demanded the release of 13 opposition leaders sentenced on evidence obtained under torture, warning that excluding them would doom the dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a pivotal figure in the early‑music movement, died at his Cambridge home after a several‑month illness, with a private funeral and a later memorial service planned; he founded the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and led it for about 30 years across six continents, producing over 200 recordings—including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a 1980 Handel’s Messiah with Emma Kirkby that BBC Music Magazine named among the top 20 recordings of all time—while also serving as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, teaching at Harvard, Cambridge and Cornell, and earning praise for his generosity, scholarly brilliance, and lasting influence on generations of musicians.

In the year to the end of March 2016 Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims—a five‑person drop from the previous year, the lowest 12‑month total since 1976 and half the figure nine years earlier—with only one case remaining unresolved; sharp instruments were the leading method, accounting for 51 % of killings (29 cases, 26 involving knives), and 31 % of the accused were identified as under the influence of alcohol or alcohol and drugs, while the majority had unknown substance status; Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted the continued decline in homicides and stressed the need for ongoing education, enforcement, and support for at‑risk communities, whereas Scottish Labour’s justice spokeswoman Claire Baker warned that past “record‑low” figures had been revised upward, noted a 45‑year high in sexual crime and a 27 % rise in attempted murder and serious assault, and pointed out that the previous year’s homicide count had been adjusted from 59 to 62 after three cases were reclassified.

Bournemouth fell 2‑1 to Sunderland, becoming the Black Cats’ first Premier League defeat of the season, with Dan Gosling’s goal their first in three games; manager Howe said the loss wasn’t due to a lack of confidence, noting they had scored six against Hull and created many chances, but despite Sunderland’s Victor Anichebe strike and a Jermain Defoe penalty, and Bournemouth playing with ten men after Steven Pienaar’s dismissal, they failed to equalise, and he emphasized that while they had enough opportunities, football sometimes unfolds unfavourably and the key is moving on.

Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Abbott argued that preventing deaths at sea requires stopping migrant boats, citing Australia’s policy of detaining and offshore processing of boat arrivals as effective, though the New York Times called the approach “brutal,” “inhumane,” and legally dubious, warning against similar European policies. Abbott also expressed sympathy for the image of Syrian child Alan Kurdi and, controversially, claimed the Islamic State is worse than the Nazis because it openly boasts its evil, a comment condemned by the Executive Council of Australian Jewry as “injudicious” and a false comparison to the systematic genocide of the Holocaust; Abbott later defended his remarks while stating he does not rank evils.

Washington accused Russia and the Syrian government of escalating attacks on civilians in Aleppo, warning it would suspend talks unless Moscow stopped bombing the city, and subsequently halted bilateral channels that had supported a cease‑fire, citing Russia’s failure to enforce the truce, protect hospitals and aid convoys, and ensure Syrian regime compliance; Russia denied involvement in the aid‑convoy strike, expressed regret over the U.S. decision, blamed Washington for not meeting humanitarian conditions and for failing to separate jihadist groups from moderate opposition, leading to the cancellation of a planned Geneva meeting and the withdrawal of U.S. personnel, though both sides said they would continue counter‑terrorism discussions while hundreds of civilians, including children, remain trapped in eastern Aleppo after the truce collapsed.

Downing Street endorsed a Policy Exchange report proposing that councils sell vacant high‑value social homes—defined as properties worth more than the regional average, which make up 21.8% of the UK’s 3.78 million social‑housing stock (about 816 000 homes and over £70 bn in London)—to raise roughly £4.5 bn a year after debt repayments, a sum the think‑tank says could fund 80 000 to 170 000 new social homes and cut the current 1.8 million‑strong waiting list by about 500 000; the report estimates 3.5% of the stock becomes vacant each year, allowing the sale of around 28 500 homes annually and potentially generating up to £159 bn in total, while its director Neil O’Brien argues this would give more families a roof rather than one “lucky” family a costly house, a view supported by a poll showing 73% of respondents oppose council houses above the local average price. Labour criticised the plan as a means of displacing low‑wage families and creating segregated neighbourhoods, urging instead a bank‑bonus tax to fund 250 000 affordable homes and protect mixed communities, while the government’s housing minister highlighted broader reforms and a £19.5 bn affordable‑housing programme aimed at delivering up to 170 000 homes and using fixed‑term tenancies to target those in greatest need.

Gareth Colfer‑Williams, a 25‑year‑old from Swansea where a measles epidemic has reached 942 cases, died at his flat after being discharged from Morriston Hospital for asthma and developing a full‑body rash; although Public Health Wales confirmed he had measles, an examination could not determine if the disease caused his death, prompting an inquest and further tests, while his family, including a vaccinated three‑year‑old daughter, said no close relative had measles, and since the outbreak began in November, 83 people have required hospital treatment.

Vincent Hudson, a 54‑year‑old resident of Loweswater Avenue in Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence involving a boy under 16, with the alleged attack reported to have occurred in 2001, and he is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates’ Court, according to Cumbria Police.

In a National League match between promotion‑chasing hosts Neil Aspin’s Gateshead and Adam Lockwood’s Guiseley, Guiseley opened the scoring after 15 minutes when a James Hurst throw‑in was squared to Jake Lawlor for the first goal; Gateshead equalised in the 62nd minute as Wes York curled a shot into the top‑right corner after a slip by substitute Derek Asamoah, and the game finished 1‑1, allowing both sides to continue their unbeaten runs (Gateshead nine matches, Guiseley five) amid several substitutions and yellow cards.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of the football club, plans to replace two stands to boost capacity as an alternative to a delayed new‑stadium project at Ashton Vale, which is held up by a town‑green application; the redevelopment was approved by Bristol City Council in November, and majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced at a shareholder meeting that the club will soon sign the section 106 agreement, wait the six‑week judicial‑review period, and, if no review occurs by March, begin the stand‑replacement work in May.

Cuadrilla halted its fracking operations after a 1.5‑magnitude tremor—the second in two months—to review data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume, noting that the April 1 quake near Poulton‑le‑Fylde shared a similar location and mechanism with a prior 2.3‑magnitude event; the BGS, which is monitoring the activity, explained that injecting pressurised water can fracture rock and trigger earthquakes, reporting that the latest tremor occurred about 2 km from the Preese Hall site at a depth of roughly 2 km and was felt by at least one person, while Cuadrilla’s chief executive said the pause allows for analysis and consultation that may take several weeks, amid broader controversy over fracking’s environmental risks in the US but with UK officials arguing that strict regulation can mitigate such problems.

Angus Carpenter, a 62‑year‑old Liverpool busker who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years, was tried on three fraud counts after playing his bagpipes with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner in April 2015; a jury found him guilty of one count and cleared him of the other two, noting that while a police sergeant said he appeared to be collecting money for the charity, Carpenter maintained he was merely busking, had permission to display the banner as a tribute to the victims, and was not attempting to raise funds, with sentencing scheduled for January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3‑0, with Grant Ward opening the scoring, Luke Varney adding a second after QPR keeper Alex Smithies mis‑cleared, and Tom Lawrence finishing the rout; the win lifted Mick McCarthy’s side to 14th, four places above QPR who fell to 15th, while both managers lamented defensive lapses—McCarthy praised Varney’s effort and noted the team’s recent poor form, and Ian Holloway blamed his defenders for the second‑goal error and called for greater mental toughness.

Wells, a 23‑year‑old player, had a standout T20 Blast season with 373 runs at an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66, and he praised the club’s direction and the elite, performance‑focused environment fostered by the coaches, which he says motivates the players to be part of it.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive victory by defeating third‑placed Chinnor 29‑12, with standout performances from Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey and Craig Williams; coach Churcher highlighted the team's 70‑plus tackles by the front row and front five as a key factor, noted that while the win was not a flawless performance, it showed dogged effort, and emphasized the need to build on this result as the team faces seven lower‑ranked opponents and league leaders Old Elthamians in their next eight games.

Police say 28‑year‑old Nazrul, also known as Nazu and identified as a Bangladeshi citizen, was the man who raped a 74‑year‑old nun during a March 14 attack on a convent school in Ranaghat, where thieves also stole money and ransacked the building; he was arrested at a Kolkata railway station after a tip that he was returning from Bangladesh, marking the sixth arrest in the case, with eight suspects identified overall and two still at large, while five previously detained suspects have named Nazrul as the rapist and earlier police had arrested Milon Sarkar, described as the gang’s leader though his exact role remains unclear.

The passage explains that an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discusses why consumer purchasing habits change—citing the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports as influences on UK product popularity—and examines shifts in ownership and rankings of major UK brands; it notes the video may not work on older browsers, works best in full screen, and offers a non‑interactive version plus links to related information such as China’s brand ownership, food‑freezing tips, a BBC Good Food survey, and the top 20 UK consumer brands.

Two recent scams involved callers posing as BT technical support: a 71‑year‑old woman from Sandyhills was deceived on 15 September, and a woman in Stranraer fell victim a week later, when the fraudster claimed internet problems, gained remote access to her computer, and stole cash; PC Siobhan Pellett warned that such remote‑access scams are frighteningly easy, can involve substantial sums, and urged people never to give banking details over the phone, noting that banks, building societies and reputable businesses never request this information.

Duffy, 37, has signed a one‑year contract to coach the third‑placed Championship side Featherstone, taking charge for their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers; chairman Mark Campbell praised his remarkable work at Swinton Lions, where he left after a 16‑year playing career with Leigh, Widnes and Salford and was succeeded by his former assistant Stuart Littler.

At 12:50 GMT on Sunday, a Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and a coastguard search‑and‑rescue helicopter responded to Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve, where a rider was found unconscious on wet sand with head injuries and severe cold; after treatment, she was flown to Cardiff’s University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from more than 160 countries agreed to allocate a radio frequency for satellite‑based tracking of aircraft, enabling automatic dependent surveillance‑broadcast (ADS‑B) signals—currently sent only to other aircraft and ground stations—to be received globally and provide real‑time tracking, a move prompted by the 2014 disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which exposed that about 70 % of the world’s airspace lacks coverage; the decision, announced by the International Telecommunication Union’s Radiocommunication Bureau and praised by its Secretary‑General, follows Malaysia’s call for better real‑time data transmission and precedes the International Civil Aviation Organisation’s November 2016 deadline for new guidelines requiring aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who vanished at age five in August 2002 after his father claimed he was taking him to preschool, has been found at 18 living with his father Bobby Hernandez in Cleveland; a tip received by the FBI on 30 October led the agency, Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity and notify his mother, while Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested, charged with tampering with records to obtain a 2012 driver’s licence and suspected of involvement in the disappearance, and is being held at the Cuyahoga County Jail on $250,000 bail.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site after a 2 March blaze that disrupted train services, while the Environment Agency suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Ltd from accepting waste and decided to revoke its environmental permit effective 7 August, giving the company until then to appeal and requiring it to remove all waste; although the firm, run by Asset and Land Group, was deemed “broadly compliant” with fire safety legislation and had been visited nine times by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service in the past year, the agency acted after fire service concerns about impacts on residents, transport and the environment, and the fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Pro‑Kremlin party A Just Russia has introduced two Ukraine‑linked bills: one would let Russia incorporate territory from a neighboring state that is “disintegrating” without a treaty, arguing that a local referendum or leaders’ plea should suffice—an approach framed as an update to laws drafted for “peaceful times” and echoing Russia’s 2008 annexations of Abkhazia and South Ossetia—while the other fast‑tracks Russian passports by eliminating taxes, residence and financial requirements, allowing applicants to keep Ukrainian citizenship, apply at diplomatic missions before 1 August and obtain citizenship in two months, a measure presented as support for Russian‑speaking Ukrainians “defenceless in the face of the ‘brown threat’”; the passport plan was announced in Sevastopol by A Just Russia leader Sergei Mironov, with several MPs and Russian celebrities visiting Crimea.

McLaren, a team that has won 182 Grand Prix races (a 23.18% win rate), 12 drivers’ world championships and eight constructors’ titles, is currently struggling after a slump that began in 2013 when chassis design faltered despite a strong engine, and now faces further problems with its Honda power‑unit; historically the team enjoyed its greatest successes with Honda in 1988‑91—winning 15 of 16 races with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost—and later with Mercedes in 1998‑99, securing its last constructors’ title that year, but subsequent years brought scandals (the 2007 Ferrari‑data breach and the 2009 “lie‑gate” incident) and a gradual decline, leading Ron Dennis to repeatedly take control of the outfit; despite the downturn, McLaren believes the 2024 car is among its best, has two world champions (including Fernando Alonso, who returned in 2015 hoping the revived Honda partnership would deliver a third title), and Dennis maintains that success will return, aiming to break Mercedes’ dominance and win future championships.

Thomas Baker, a 44‑year‑old man from Everton, was shot in the head and chest outside the Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool’s Old Swan area on 27 January after leaving Phoenix Gym, and later died in hospital; police have arrested three local men, aged 29, 29 and 32, who remain in custody, are searching for a silver VW Polo that fled the scene via Balmoral, Molyneux and Queens Roads, and are urging witnesses captured on nearby CCTV to come forward.

The passage outlines several modern, digital ways to celebrate Christmas while staying spiritually connected: Everyday Church Online, a UK‑launched virtual service that streams recorded sermons (including a Star Wars‑themed “Hope Awakens” series) and hosts a global chat room with participants from 61 countries; the free‑to‑play game Guardians of Ancora, created by the Scripture Union, which offers Bible‑based quests for children and added two Christmas‑themed missions about Jesus’ birth; viral online nativity videos such as Viral.de’s “The Digital Story of Nativity,” viewed nearly six million times, and the Churches Advertising Network’s “Christmas Starts with a Baby’s Giggle,” seen about 250,000 times but blocked from cinemas for being “too religious”; Next Manga’s “Manga Messiah” app/e‑book, now in 33 languages with 25,000 Arabic copies sent to Syrian and Libyan refugees; and the broader use of social‑media platforms (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram) by Christian groups to share brief spiritual messages, as noted by media figures Kevin Bennett and Jules Middleton.

The eight‑day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to appropriate 250 hectares (600 acres) of common land, with supporters—including Blaenau Gwent council—offering about 320 hectares (800 acres) of replacement land; experts have disputed whether the development would harm habitats, Natural Resources Wales finds it difficult to confirm the replacement’s equal value but does not oppose the project, while developers claim a net biodiversity gain from nearby habitat enhancements—a claim challenged by the Gwent Wildlife Trust—and the Planning Inspectorate for Wales will issue a recommendation before Welsh government ministers make the final decision.

Chechen Muslim clerics convened on 3 April, condemning a Novaya Gazeta report that exposed the detention of over 100 men suspected of homosexuality and the killing of at least three, and declared that “retribution” would fall on the report’s authors, a statement the newspaper interpreted as a call for reprisals against journalists; while the Russian LGBT Network confirmed the abuses—torture, beatings and electric shocks in a prison near Argun—and is assisting victims and threatening to take the case to the International Criminal Court, Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov and his spokesman denied any gay presence, and the mufti warned that Allah would punish those who slandered the Chechen nation, even as Novaya Gazeta’s editor pledged to continue investigating human‑rights violations despite past murders of reporters linked to Chechen investigations.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency founded in 2002 by Samir Patel, and the charity Fresh Start Housing, set up by Patel in 2010, have been receiving large housing‑benefit payments by placing single homeless men over 35 in private‑sector properties, often putting several unrelated tenants in one house and claiming benefit for each occupant, which yields higher payouts than the rent passed to landlords and generates substantial profit (e.g., £2,114 claimed versus £1,150 paid to an owner, giving a £11,568 annual gross profit on one property); both organisations operate from the same south‑London storage unit, serve seven boroughs, and have housed hundreds of people (Fresh Start reports 788 total, 222 in the past year), while critics such as the homeless charity Crisis describe the arrangement as “a new low,” noting poor living conditions reported by tenants like Nigel McCann, and highlighting that nearly half of Investing Solutions’ recent income—over £2.1 million—has come from Wandsworth Council, which claims to safeguard private‑sector housing, whereas the Department for Communities and Local Government stresses local authorities’ responsibility to protect taxpayers’ money.

London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence scored 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon added 13 as Great Britain led most of the first three quarters before the Netherlands overtook them in the final ten minutes to win 71‑60, despite a late GB comeback; the Dutch were propelled by Worthy De Jong’s 18 points, while Gordon’s three‑point streak in the third quarter earned coach Joe Prunty praise, and GB now head into their Eurobasket qualifying campaign with a midweek game in Hungary, emphasizing the need to execute on every play and maintain intensity.

The former five‑weight world champion Conor McGregor filed a required waiver with the Nevada Athletic Commission just before the deadline to allow a 154‑lb bout against Floyd Mayweather, whose Instagram post announced he will wear 8‑oz Grant gloves—a weight not previously used at that limit, though NAC rules permit 8‑oz gloves for 135‑147 lb fights if waivers are signed and safety is justified; the commission will publicly debate the request on 16 August, emphasizing fighter health above all, while NAC executive director Bob Bennett, after reviewing McGregor’s UFC record (including 4‑oz gloves and a 2016 win over Nate Diaz) and consulting trainers such as Virgil Hunter, cited McGregor’s durability, youth, size and recent sparring footage as reasons to approve the fight, and has advised hiring Hall of Fame referee Joe Cortez, who later described a chaotic sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi that led to McGregor’s former two‑weight champion trainer leaving the camp.

Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, long‑time staff of the Dundee‑based Sunday Post, have become the last journalists to leave Fleet Street as the paper’s London office closes, with Smith turning freelance and Sherriff writing memoirs; their recollections evoke the street’s heyday—smoke‑filled newsrooms, bustling pubs like El Vino, and the daily rush of paper rolls—contrasted with today’s sandwich bars, while veteran Robin Eßer, who spent six decades on Fleet Street and later edited the Daily Mail, notes that the area once delivered 85 % of public information before television and social media, and that its decline began when Rupert Murdoch moved his titles to Wapping in 1986, prompting a union battle and a shift to computerized printing that emptied the historic offices, now repurposed for businesses such as Sainsbury’s and Pizza Express; authors like Liz Hodgkinson have chronicled the street’s culture, including its heavy drinking and gender dynamics, marking the end of an era that once defined British journalism.

J.K. Rowling said abusive Twitter comments reminded her of how many decent people exist, noting that being a famous woman online isn’t always fun and that she stands up to bullies. She recalled earlier criticism after donating £1 million to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum (and the same amount to Labour in 2008), and said she was called a “traitor” for her views, blocking some abusive users she believed supported the SNP while also engaging positively with other SNP supporters and finding common political ground. She joked about bringing marshmallows after a suggestion her books be burned, and noted that the SNP won 56 of 59 Scottish seats, becoming the UK’s third‑largest party.
