The Edinburgh Study of Youth Transitions and Crime, which has tracked 4,300 young people in Edinburgh since 1998 and was funded by the Economic and Social Research Council, the Nuffield Foundation and the Scottish government, found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action as better‑off children who commit the same offence and that poverty markedly raises the likelihood of violence for both boys and girls; a history of police trouble was the strongest predictor of being not in education, employment or training by age 18, poorer youths were about five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision, and household poverty increased offending even after accounting for other risk factors, with extreme poverty linked to higher rates of both victimisation and perpetration; gender was also a strong predictor, with boys three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts and girls from poorer households twice as likely as those from affluent homes to be involved in violent crime, despite controls for truancy, substance abuse and parental supervision. A related Scottish Justice Matters report showed that the recent decline in overall crime has not benefited the most chronically affected areas, as crime remains highly concentrated in deprived neighbourhoods that also have the highest levels of chronic health problems and unemployment, prompting questions about the adequacy of inequality‑addressing policies. The Scottish government, while highlighting record low crime rates, homicide levels and increased police presence, asserts it is tackling poverty and inequality through initiatives including a £296 million investment to mitigate the effects of UK welfare cuts.

Mr Haugh, 25, was stabbed in the back during an early‑morning altercation in the Marian Estate, Kilkee, shortly after 01:00 on Sunday and died at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00; Garda recovered knives, golf clubs, a knife handle and a blood‑stained blade at the scene, and Detective Sergeant Padraig Frawley said three men entered the estate looking for Haugh, encountered him and another man, and a fight involving weapons ensued with additional individuals joining; Robbie Walsh of Island View, Kilrush, was charged with assault causing serious harm, remanded in custody and scheduled to appear again in court, while two other arrested men were released without charge pending DPP review, and a judge ordered Walsh to remain in custody until 14 August.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan posted a tweet accusing MP Tom Elliott—who served ten years in the UDR from 1982 to 1992—of having “harassed and shot” people, a claim the High Court later found to be false; the tweet was removed within an hour, and Flanagan must issue an apology on Twitter stating his allegation was “untrue and wholly without foundation,” while the court awaits a decision on compensation, noting that the Stormont indemnity insurer has refused to cover Flanagan’s costs, a refusal he is contesting separately, and Elliott has said he feels vindicated by the outcome.

Hawick Knitwear, a company founded in 1874 and now employing over 230 staff, was purchased by managing director Benny Hartop in November of the previous year and has recently expanded its output to 9,500 sweaters weekly—up from about 7,500—to meet strong demand driven by better‑than‑expected sales of its own Hawick Knitwear‑branded range launched in January and growth in its long‑standing private‑label business; the firm supplies markets across Europe (including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy and Spain) as well as the USA, Canada, Mexico and Japan, and Hartop expressed confidence that the company’s future remains very positive.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72‑year‑old lollipop lady of 20 years, was seriously injured in December when Brian Wright, 55, of Kempston, drove his VW Golf through a red light and struck her as she escorted a woman and her six‑year‑old daughter across Bedford Road Lower School; Wright claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall the light’s colour, denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, expressed remorse in court, and the case remains ongoing, with Blackburn now receiving residential care.

The NATO anti‑submarine exercise “Dynamic Mongoose” was staged as a response to heightened Russian submarine activity, with the German U‑33 acting as a simulated enemy trying to strike the US command ship USS Vicksburg and an oil tanker while evading ten NATO warships, including Britain’s HMS Portland; the drill highlighted the difficulty of detecting a hidden submarine, the use of ASW helicopters, French Atlantique maritime patrol aircraft, and for the first time NATO research‑vessel‑deployed underwater drones (Harpo and Groucho) to scan the seabed, and underscored a “gaping hole” in Britain’s defences—its lack of any maritime patrol aircraft since the Nimrod, forcing reliance on allies and prompting calls for the gap to be addressed in the upcoming defence review amid concerns over Russia’s expanding fleet of around 60 advanced, quiet submarines.

UN officials now warn that genocide and ethnic cleansing may be occurring in South Sudan, where violence that erupted in Juba in July spread to the southern Equatoria states, prompting 340,000 people to flee into neighboring Uganda—more than any other country this year, with an average of 2,500 South Sudanese becoming refugees each day; the conflict, rooted in ethnic rivalry between the Dinka‑led government, Nuer forces and Equatorian groups, has involved killings, rapes and attacks on civilians, as recounted by refugees such as Nelson Ladu Thomas, Otima Amos and Faida Sarah, who describe soldiers murdering men, raping women and targeting children; Uganda has responded by rapidly allocating 30‑square‑metre plots and tarpaulins for shelter and allowing refugees to plant crops, turning the former village of Bidi Bidi into one of the world’s largest settlements with over a quarter‑million people on 250 km², but the massive influx—now approaching a million refugees, half of them children—has strained resources like water and education, prompting UNHCR senior coordinator Nasir Abel Fernandes to call for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to halt the civilian massacres.

McKenzie, a 38‑year‑old former footballer who turned professional in 2013, will face Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on 12 November for the English super‑middleweight championship; he holds an 8‑win, 0‑loss, 1‑draw record, is the son of ex‑British and European champion Clinton McKenzie, and is trained by his uncle, three‑time world champion Duke McKenzie.

The £33 million Bridgwater Community Hospital, part of a £330 million coalition investment for new NHS facilities in England, will replace the cramped 1813 building with a modern facility offering 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery‑led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X‑ray and space for mobile scanners; funding comes from NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust, and the project aims for completion by autumn 2014 on land at Bowers Lane pending planning permission, while three of Somerset’s 13 community hospitals have been replaced in the past five years and work has begun on the new Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital, with staff praising the anticipated benefits for patient care.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe around 13:35 GMT; he was near a black Mercedes, suffered a chest wound, was taken to Northern General Hospital and died, while family members gathered nearby for a celebration and attempted to help, prompting armed police to seal off the area, and the incident follows a series of recent Sheffield shootings, including a 25‑year‑old injured in Shiregreen, an elderly couple shot through a window in Southey Green (believed to be mistaken identity), and house shootings in High Green earlier in January.

The passage describes three prominent hacker groups active in the Ukraine‑Russia conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Kiev programmer Yevhen Dokukin, who claim to have breached Russian interior ministry servers and police email accounts, leaked over 35 GB of data suggesting Russian soldiers were evacuated after being wounded, use DDoS attacks as “artillery” against rebel sites, target rebel payment accounts, hack public CCTV and network printers in eastern Ukraine and Crimea to display pro‑Ukrainian messages, and assert that their intelligence has been used to guide artillery fire (though officials deny this); the anti‑Western Cyber Berkut, named after riot police, which seeks to thwart Ukrainian military plans, has hacked Ukrainian government websites during Joe Biden’s Kiev visit, posted propaganda on electronic billboards, claimed to obtain confidential US assistance documents, disrupted election vote‑counting systems, leaked defence‑ministry data, blocked President Poroshenko’s site, and circulated a disputed hacked Facebook conversation about the downing of MH‑17; and the Russian‑linked Anonymous International (also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay), which publishes leaked Kremlin documents, including a letter from a Russian fighter in eastern Ukraine and emails from former FSB colonel Igor Girkin, while its exact source of material remains unclear and its website is blocked in Russia.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond delivered their farewell speeches before the election on 5 May, with both also stepping down as MSPs; Salmond’s valedictory address emphasized Scotland’s diversity, a broad consensus for greater parliamentary responsibility, welcomed the Scotland Bill’s power transfers while noting unmet unionist pledges, and included light‑hearted jokes before concluding with a tribute to public service, while McNeil warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster’s committee system, stressing the need for accountability and scrutiny and recalling Robin Cook’s visit, and former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also announced her departure, humorously noting she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

Older People’s Commissioner for Wales Sarah Rochira is launching a review of residential care that will gather testimonies from pensioners, their families and carers to inform recommendations for providers and public bodies, assessing quality of life through physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care‑home environment; while she stresses the need to highlight both good and poor care, the chair of Care Forum Wales, Mario Kreft, criticised the advisory panel for lacking any current or former care‑home providers, arguing this omission hinders full sector partnership.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, increased its pre‑tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5 million for the year ending June 2016 despite a £1 million drop in turnover to just over £100 million, with international sales expanding in Europe and new markets; the Turriff‑based firm produces feeds for beef, sheep, dairy, pig and poultry sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland that supply farming and rural goods such as fireside supplies, clothing and footwear, while noting that agricultural outlooks remain unpredictable, the past 12‑18 months have been challenging, and the full impact of Brexit is still unclear though the board believes the group is well positioned for future challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house on Nettleden Road in Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, while a man in his 80s was taken to hospital, and detectives are seeking 55‑year‑old Ian John McLoughlin (also known as Ian John Baker) for questioning in connection with the murder, describing him as a white, average‑built male about 6 ft tall with straight greying collar‑length hair, wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three‑quarter‑length trousers and a dark‑blue, light‑blue and white checked short‑sleeved shirt, with police urging anyone with information to contact them or Crimestoppers and increasing patrols in the area for resident reassurance.

David Lipton, the IMF’s second‑in‑command, warned in a Washington speech that the fund’s latest assessment shows a weakening baseline for the global economy and a “delicate juncture,” noting that China’s recent trade data revealed a 25% year‑over‑year plunge in exports; consequently, the IMF is expected to lower its global growth forecast from the current 3.4% when it updates its predictions in April, a downturn that poses ongoing challenges for businesses and industries reliant on China’s growth story.

At a council scrutiny meeting, leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes chain ferry crossing would remain free until 2 July as “recognition of the problems” and to gather feedback, and that auditors had been tasked with reviewing the project after a “frustrating and disappointing start.” Since its late‑May launch, the ferry has broken down, run aground, been suspended by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues, and caused car damage during loading, prompting local businesses like Angie Booth’s Valu‑4‑U to fear severe losses and question compensation. Transport councillor Ian Ward said compensation is under discussion, emphasized that the vessel is a prototype with inevitable teething problems, noted that electrical faults have been fixed, and reported that the council has approved ramp extensions to stop vehicles scraping the concrete and that seamanship‑related groundings have been resolved.

A multi‑vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, killing a 32‑year‑old man at the scene; a 33‑year‑old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention, and the road between Thursley and Liphook remained closed until early evening while police investigated.

Matching Models in London, an “international temp agency for beautiful and talented people,” posted job ads that specified physical attributes such as a “classic look, brown long hair with b‑c cup” for a personal assistant and a “sexy female driver” for a Knightsbridge businessman, prompting the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) to label the ads “appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women,” with chief executive Rebecca Hilsenrath warning the agency to clarify its hiring practices; women’s‑rights groups and the Fawcett Society’s Sam Smethers called the ads retrograde and likely illegal under the 2010 Equality Act, which bans discrimination based on appearance, age, sex, disability and other protected characteristics, while employment lawyer James Lynas warned that phrases like “beautiful and attractive” could be deemed discriminatory and expose the agency to unlimited compensation claims; the agency’s founder Nathalie Jansen defended the focus on looks, citing client demands for specific outfits and a “Jackie O” look, and highlighted high‑profile clients such as MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca‑Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team and Harrods, claiming to have placed 5,000 people worldwide, whereas the EHRC urged the firm to abandon such sexism in the 21st century.

A shooting took place at the hostel of the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where office assistant Mahesh entered an 18‑year‑old student Gautami’s room and shot her in the head, then wounded another student, Sirisha, who is now out of danger; Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt, remanded until 12 April, and the incident highlights the rarity of gun crime in Indian schools, though a similar fatal school shooting occurred in 2007 near Delhi.

Glaad’s analysis of scripted broadcast, cable and streaming series shown or cast between June 2016 and May 2017 identified 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender roles increasing from seven to 16, while more than 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters—such as Poussey Washington and Bea Smith—were killed off; the report also noted a record‑high proportion of Black characters on broadcast television, driven largely by shows like Empire, Luke Cage and How to Get Away with Murder, and Glaad president Sarah Kate Ellis described the progress as “heartening” but cautioned that the numbers tell only part of the story.

Conservative MP David Mackintosh, who has represented Northampton South since 2015, announced he will not seek re‑election, saying it is time for a new representative, after a local party meeting was expected to oppose his candidacy; the BBC reported that a £10.25 million public loan he approved as council leader for Northampton Town FC’s Sixfields stadium redevelopment has largely vanished, prompting a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities, leaving the stadium stand half‑built, and a majority of the local party’s executive council indicated they would vote to deselect him, though Mackintosh has denied any wrongdoing.

Roy Oliver, a 37‑year‑old officer, fired a rifle into a car leaving a Balch Springs house party in April, killing 15‑year‑old Jordan Edwards and injuring four other teenagers, including two of Edwards’s brothers, for which he faces four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon; although police initially claimed the vehicle reversed aggressively toward him, video showed it driving forward away, and Oliver was later dismissed for policy violations, now free on bail and facing a potential five‑to‑99‑year prison term that would make him the first Dallas County police officer convicted of murder since 1973, while no trial date has been set and the district attorney’s office asserts that justice is proceeding thoroughly.

The president‑elect has said Melania Trump and her 10‑year‑old son Barron will relocate to Washington “very soon, after he’s finished with school,” though no date was given, prompting social‑media criticism and jokes about the move’s impact on their marriage, while supporters argued it is a responsible parental choice; historically only two first ladies—Martha Washington and Anna Harrison—did not live in the White House, but many presidents’ children have delayed moving or attended school elsewhere, as seen with Grover Cleveland’s Frances Cleveland, John Tyler’s children, Dolley Madison’s son, and more recent examples like Chelsea Clinton and the Obama daughters, who either moved early or balanced school with White House life; the first‑lady role is largely ceremonial but has evolved into a public platform for initiatives, with notable figures such as Lou Henry Hoover, Eleanor Roosevelt, and Nancy Reagan shaping its visibility, and Melania Trump has hinted she may focus on cyber‑bullying, possibly sharing duties with Ivanka Trump, while past families have adapted the White House to maintain normal family routines despite the historic setting.

A 72‑year‑old man died in Inverness on 27 October, prompting the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service to order the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner, Kate Frame, to examine the initial police response to his call; Police Scotland said it is fully cooperating with the inquiry, and a report of the commissioner’s findings will be submitted to the COPFS in due course.

A yellow wind warning was issued for gusts up to 75 mph (120 km/h), especially west of the mountains, with an unusual easterly direction expected to intensify the impact and likely cause travel disruptions on roads and at sea across Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion and Powys; overnight gusts knocked down a tree in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route, and Telford Road was expected to stay closed most of Monday for cleanup.

The Giants opened short‑handed with player‑coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen tied the game; in the second period Mike Forney’s power‑play breakaway gave a 2‑1 lead before Andy Bohmback equalized, then Mike Radja scored from an acute angle and James Desmarais extended the lead to 4‑2, though Nottingham’s David Ling replied, and the teams will meet again Saturday night in the second match of their double‑header, with Nottingham atop the league on 28 points, Sheffield Steelers close behind on 27, and Belfast with 25.

World champion Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one and made five pit stops, leaving him third‑from‑last and facing a 36‑point deficit with 18 races remaining; despite his misfortune, he hopes to erode Rosberg’s lead, who after an early safety‑car period and a puncture to Ricciardo’s left‑rear wheel took and kept the lead to win his first title, while Ferrari’s Vettel finished second after colliding with teammate Raikkonen on the first lap, and Raikkonen recovered to fifth thanks to a soft‑tyre final stint that out‑performed Hamilton’s medium tyres, with the race marked by multiple first‑lap collisions, safety‑car deployment, and strategic tyre choices that shaped the final order.

Thomas Hitzlsperger publicly came out as gay to spark discussion on a topic he said was “simply ignored” in German football, becoming the most prominent player to do so; his announcement was praised by former teammates Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, football officials such as former DFB president Theo Zwanziger and Bundesliga president Reinhard Rauball, clubs like Bayern Munich, and public figures including Gary Lineker, John Amaechi and Chancellor Angela Merkel’s spokesman, and is viewed as a watershed moment against homophobia in German football, contrasting with earlier reluctance exemplified by Philipp Lahm’s 2011 comments and the limited visibility of earlier gay players such as Marcus Urban.

Sidwell, 34, has made 32 Championship appearances this season, playing a key role in Brighton’s promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years and currently sitting four points clear of Newcastle with a chance to clinch the title in the final two games; with his contract expiring at season’s end, the midfielder, who previously played for Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham and Stoke and joined Brighton on a one‑year deal in June 2016 after a loan spell, is eager to earn a new contract and remain in the top flight.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1‑1, with Jamille Matt giving Colchester the lead after 12 minutes from a Nathan Delfouneso chip, and Kurtis Guthrie equalising for Blackpool from a corner three minutes later; the match featured several notable saves by Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe, missed chances including an unmarked Tom Aldred header, and ended with Colchester reduced to ten men when substitute Sean Murray received a straight red for violent conduct in injury time.

A 29‑year‑old player who made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues during their relegation from League One—having previously played for Charlton, Bradford and Preston—may debut for Colchester United in their EFL Cup first‑round match against Championship side Aston Villa, after the club began the season with a 3‑1 defeat to Accrington; the latest football transfers are listed on a dedicated page.

PC Keith Palmer’s murder outside Parliament spurred a push for a permanent police memorial, leading the UK Police Memorial Trust to seek £1.5 million for a site at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire, which will honor over 1,400 officers and staff who have died in the past 250 years; the design includes a brass screen with leaf‑shaped cut‑outs for families, and Home Secretary Amber Rudd pledged £1 million toward the £4 million total, with completion expected by 2019.

Manchester United remain 15 points clear at the top of the Premier League with eight games left after a 1‑0 victory over Sunderland, having recorded 25 wins in their first 30 matches and earning 50 of a possible 54 points in their last 18 league games; manager Sir Alex Ferguson emphasized focusing on upcoming fixtures, noting the next league challenge is the derby against Manchester City with a 15‑point cushion and that United aim to surpass Chelsea’s 95‑point record from 2005, while also preparing changes for the FA Cup quarter‑final replay at Chelsea due to injuries to Rafael, Anderson and a knock to goalkeeper David De Gea, and awaiting the fitness of returning England players such as Wayne Rooney, with Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernández available for selection.

Mr Schmidt told the BBC that Google complied with legal tax obligations, having paid £10 million in UK corporate taxes from 2006 to 2011, and argued that any increase in taxes would require a change in government policy which the company would follow; he emphasized that taxes are not optional and that the UK should decide its tax laws. Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee chair Margaret Hodge proposed creating a new committee to scrutinise major firms’ tax arrangements in secret, preventing companies from hiding behind confidentiality. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland, is criticised for structuring its affairs to minimise UK tax, while EU leaders have agreed on an automatic information‑exchange system to combat avoidance. The Google chairman has advocated that corporate taxes be levied where economic activity and risk occur rather than where products are consumed, calling for a political debate on international tax reform and stressing that politicians, not companies, should set the rules.

NHS Improvement is pressing the NHS to cut its £3.6 billion agency‑staff bill by £1 billion before the end of the financial year, after the service fell behind schedule; a cap introduced in October limits payments to no more than 55 % above normal shift rates (saving about £600 million so far) but exempts senior managers, and the regulator says progress is “promising” yet still about 10 % short of target, with unclear effects on other pay‑bill items and exclusions for “bank” staff and overtime; it will soon publish league tables ranking trusts on agency spending and collect data on the 20 highest‑earning agency workers per trust after uncovering cases where hospitals were quoted double the capped rates, such as £130 an hour for a surgeon versus the £76 cap and £70 an hour for a junior doctor versus the £35 cap, prompting chief executive Jim Mackey to warn that the NHS cannot continue to fund excessively costly agency staff.

The Longford Town Centre, once a symbol of the Celtic Tiger boom, now stands as a reminder of Ireland’s economic collapse, yet local traders are beginning to see a modest recovery: Matt O’Brien’s family men’s‑clothing shop, which fell 30% during the downturn and had to lay off staff, reports rising sales after expanding into children’s wear and dress‑hire, while Fianna Fáil criticises the Fine Gael‑Labour coalition for misallocating a half‑billion‑euro water‑meter investment that won’t be operational for years and for the IDA’s failure to attract any foreign investors to Longford in four years, urging instead that funds be used for broadband; the government counters by highlighting the planned Center Parcs tourism development in Ballymahon, projected to create about 1,000 jobs and costing €200 million on 340 acres, though it still awaits planning permission, and local Fine Gael TD James Bannon praises the region’s scenery and infrastructure; nevertheless, traders like O’Brien argue that issues such as street‑parking charges hinder further growth, indicating that while the midlands are showing early signs of economic recovery, additional measures are still needed.

The competition, held in a single stadium, concludes with the final on 29 May after a double‑round‑robin among eight teams—each playing the others twice—with the top four advancing to the play‑offs; BBC Sport provides live scores, fixtures and results, and the schedule runs from 25 April (Kings XI Punjab vs Mumbai Indians) through a series of matches each day, culminating in Qualifier 1 (24 May), the Eliminator (25 May), Qualifier 2 (27 May) and the Final (29 May). Leading run‑scorers are Warner (294), Kohli (267) and De Villiers (249); the most sixes are tied between Warner and De Villiers (12 each) with Kohli (8); highest individual innings are De Kock (108), Warner (90*) and Gambhir (90*); top wicket‑takers are McClenaghan (9), Kumar (8) and Rahman (7). Four current or former England players feature: Eoin Morgan (Sunrisers Hyderabad), Jos Buttler (Mumbai Indians), Sam Billings (Delhi Daredevils) and Kevin Pietersen (Rising Pune Supergiants).

DEFRA reports a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, noting that many are non‑recyclable and often end up in landfills and rivers, harming the environment; starting in October, England will impose a 5p charge on plastic bags to promote reuse, following similar charges in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland that have already reduced bag usage, and campaigners hope the new fee will further decrease waste and benefit the environment.

A windstorm in Wales ripped part of a school roof in Rhosgadfan, caused power cuts to hundreds of homes, train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and prompted a yellow “be aware” wind warning until midnight Friday; the strongest gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey, leading Irish Ferries to cancel six fast Holyhead‑Dublin sailings, Arriva Trains Wales to impose speed restrictions between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead, and the National Trust to close Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle, while restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge were later lifted and Rhyl’s Boxing Day Dip was postponed to Tuesday, 27 December.

Michael B. Jordan expressed excitement about an upcoming film where he will reunite with Creed director Ryan Coogler, noting he wants to bring a fresh spin to his role, and looks forward to working with Coogler, Oscar‑winning actress Lupita Nyong’o, and Chadwick Boseman, who is currently portraying Black Panther in Captain America: Civil War; Jordan previously played the Human Torch in the 2015 Fantastic Four reboot, Nyong’o voiced CGI character Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and the Black Panther film is slated for release in February 2018.

The 1875‑founded theatre, which still retains much of its original décor and stage machinery, is planned to host theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy and live music, while the BBC studios at the palace’s eastern end will be repaired and refurbished, with a hoped‑for reopening in 2018 contingent on fundraising; the theatre and studios are part of a larger east‑wing restoration to transform Alexandra Palace into a new cultural destination, including converting the glazed east court into a public and exhibition space, funded by £18.8 million from the Heritage Lottery Fund, £6.8 million from Haringey Council, and a £1 million commitment from the Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust to be raised by summer 2017, bringing the total east‑wing refurbishment cost to £26.6 million.

James Milner, the 30‑year‑old former Manchester City midfielder, earned 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, was selected for two World Cups and two European Championships (playing only three minutes at Euro 2016), and scored his sole international goal in a 5‑0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers; he also holds the record for most England Under‑21 appearances with 46 caps since 2004 and recently commented that a recent decision was “common sense,” wishing Sam Allardyce, the players, staff and supporters success.

Marcy Smith and her children escaped a rapidly spreading house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, after their son David woke them; the blaze, caused by rubbish burned in a wood stove and undetected by the alarm, destroyed the home and killed their dog and cats, while the family fled in pajamas, and the community has since rallied to provide clothing, shoes and a bike, with Mrs. Smith emphasizing her pride in David’s heroic actions.

The passage notes that an energy‑drink giant has been reported to be weighing a £200 million bid for West Ham United, whose majority stake was bought by Sullivan and Gold in 2010 for a £105 million valuation; they now control over 85 % of the club. Since the team’s relocation to the London Stadium, it has also attracted interest from Qatari and Chinese investors. Sullivan has said that, while a minority share could be sold to reduce debt, the ultimate plan is for the club’s ownership to be passed on to their children.

The ceremony, described by Jillian Bell as “definitely not the Oscars,” featured fan‑voted categories such as best kiss and best shirtless performance while also serving as a promotional platform for upcoming summer blockbusters; the biggest winner was The Fault in Our Stars, which took best movie and saw Shailene Woodley earn best female performance, the Trailblazer Award and best kiss with Ansel Elgort, while Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, Channing Tatum received best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, Meryl Streep was named best villain for Into the Woods, and other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen and Rose Byrne, with Kevin Hart accepting a comedic‑genius award alongside his children and Robert Downey Jr. receiving the Generation Award flanked by his Avengers co‑stars; clips of the upcoming Pitch Perfect sequel, Judd Apatow’s Trainwreck and Marvel’s Ultron were shown, and the event was promoted on BBC Newsbeat’s social‑media channels.

The Dons loaned 21‑year‑old Scotland Under‑21 international Cammy Smith to Dundee United in July, where he has already scored five goals this season; he debuted for Aberdeen in 2012 and has four goals in 89 appearances for the Pittodrie club, and St Mirren manager Jack Ross praised the signing as a “brilliant acquisition,” noting Smith’s maturity, versatility and added attacking option, while St Mirren, currently bottom of the Championship, are set to host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council announced that, with the weather now warm enough, its Jetpatcher machines will be used to fill an estimated 145 potholes each day over the next four months, while additional staff will be deployed to repair drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and clear debris from gutters.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest’s Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework, a dose later described as less than 1 % of the level that must be reported to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE); EnQuest reported the incident to the HSE, added precautionary steps, and said its control measures are designed to prevent such exposure, while Wood Group removed the workers for medical assessments and supported a joint investigation, though the workers, led by rigging supervisor Steve Innes, claimed they lacked proper protective equipment, faced cancer fears, and accused EnQuest of breaching its duty of care; the Unite union condemned the treatment of the workers, calling for transparency, and the HSE confirmed awareness of the incident but noted it was not reportable under RIDDOR and therefore no separate investigation was launched.

The Asian Civilisation Museum purchased a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari for $650,000 (£420,000) from New York dealer Art of the Past in 2007; the dealer’s manager later admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities, and the piece is believed to have been taken from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu, prompting its return after discussions between Singapore’s National Heritage Board and India’s Archaeological Survey (ASI), which formally requested the repatriation in May; although the museum bought 30 objects from the dealer, only this sculpture is suspected of being stolen, and the museum plans to pursue legal action for compensation.

A magnitude‑4.8 earthquake struck at 15:48 GMT on a shallow depth of 15.5 km, with its epicentre in Garfagnana about 35 km north of Lucca, causing the tremor to be felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna and Modena; no immediate injuries or damage were reported, though phone lines and power were disrupted in Garfagnana, schools were evacuated, and residents gathered in the streets of Lucca, while top floors of Milan office towers swayed. The event was followed by several lower‑magnitude aftershocks across a wide area. Italy, a seismically active country, previously suffered a deadly 2009 L’Aquila quake that killed nearly 300 people, and in May the same region experienced two quakes, including a magnitude‑6 tremor that killed over 20, leading to the 2012 conviction of six scientists and a former official for providing misleading risk assessments before the 2009 disaster.

On 8 September 2016 at 15:33 BST, a fruit was still attached to the plant and not yet ripe, and 62‑year‑old Austin Grant of Sheffield, who had doubted South Yorkshire’s climate suitability, finally saw positive results and exclaimed that he was “literally jumping for joy.”

Rockstar announced that the release of the open‑world adventure has been pushed from 27 January to 24 March to allow extra testing and polish, emphasizing that the decision was made in the best interests of the game and its fans; the company also revealed that eagerly‑awaited online heists will arrive on consoles before the PC launch, and released PC screenshots showing higher detail with Los Santos and Blaine County viewable in 1080p at 60 fps, up to 4K resolution and support for triple‑monitor setups, alongside newly published minimum PC specifications, while noting that Grand Theft Auto V became the fastest‑selling entertainment product ever after its 17 September 2013 release, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days.

The 76‑year‑old artist Simpson won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work Squint (19) at Liverpool’s Walker Art Gallery, a piece he had previously shortlisted for in 1991 and long‑listed three other times; the painting, about 7 ft (2.1 m) tall, depicts a “leper squint” – holes in medieval churches that allowed the undesirables to view services – and was praised by judge Ansel Krut as “quite extraordinary,” a subtle, minimal “tone poem” that builds a sympathetic picture despite being difficult to look at, and Simpson plans to spend the prize money on stretches, canvas and high‑quality paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain’s oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig, and its patron Sir Peter Blake, who won the junior title in 1961.

The daily Yeni Safak reported that four masked assailants attacked its building, shattering windows with gunfire and starting a blaze that firefighters quickly extinguished, while nearby Yeni Akit offices, located 20 km away, were hit almost simultaneously early Thursday, also sustaining shattered windows and numerous spent bullet casings; no casualties were reported, police cordoned the areas and are hunting the perpetrators, no group has claimed responsibility, and both papers support President Erdoğan’s AK Party, echoing a September incident when pro‑government protesters attacked the Hurriyet offices over alleged misquotations of the president.

A 24‑year‑old player, currently contracted to the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot’s Mariners on a free transfer, becoming Bignot’s first signing; after spending the season’s first half on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances, he will officially transfer on 1 January.

Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger, whose contract runs until summer, has been linked with the England job, but he says he is focused on his club duties while noting that Southgate, who succeeded Sam Allardyce, has “accumulated experiences” and is a good observer of the national team; Southgate, 46, must impress the FA in a World Cup qualifier against Scotland on 11 November and a friendly versus Spain four days later to secure a permanent role. Wenger also said 21‑year‑old right‑back Héctor Bellerín will be offered a new contract despite interest from Barcelona and Manchester City, describing the transfer speculation as surprising and affirming Bellerín’s long‑term future at Arsenal, and he confirmed that midfielder Aaron Ramsey, 25, will miss “one or two” more games after a hamstring injury suffered in Arsenal’s opening‑day loss to Liverpool.

A local worker at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker at about 13:45 GMT on Thursday, prompting Lincolnshire Police to launch a joint inquiry with the Health and Safety Executive, while the company is fully cooperating with the investigation.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced that a new charter arrangement, set to begin early next month pending final financial and regulatory details, will end the long‑running dispute over seafarers’ pay on the freight vessels Hellier and Hildasay by returning contracted services to operator Serco Northlink and guaranteeing that all crew members receive at least the national minimum wage; the dispute arose after the RMT union claimed some workers were paid under £4 an hour, with Seatruck—who operates the vessels under contract to Serco—arguing the minimum wage did not apply to many non‑UK residents, despite Serco’s repeated offers to bridge and backdate the pay gap, and Serco Northlink, awarded a six‑year £243 million Northern Isles contract in 2012, runs three ferries and two cargo boats on a heavily subsidised route to the Northern Isles.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after a confrontation at the Rockley Park holiday site in Poole; Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Dickie and his mother, was visibly shaking after a jury verdict at Winchester Crown Court, and had pleaded guilty to common assault for the fight, while he and his mother Samantha, 57, also admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by initially giving false statements about the incident; the court heard that Dickie and his partner were in a “down phase” when Mitchell visited his mother on 7 May, got heavily intoxicated, and that the altercation outside the park bar led to Dickie’s “tragic accident,” with sentencing set for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the “Invisible Man” of pop songwriting, died in London at 66 after a brief aggressive battle with cancer; his family requested privacy following a private funeral. Born in Cleethorpes and initially working in a frozen‑food factory, he joined the disco group Heatwave in the 1970s, penning hits such as “Boogie Nights,” “Always & Forever,” and “Groove Line.” His work caught Quincy Jones’s attention, leading to three songs on Michael Jackson’s breakthrough album Off The Wall (including the title track, “Rock With You” and “Burn This Disco Out”) and three on Thriller (“Thriller,” “Baby Be Mine,” “The Lady in My Life”), contributing to Thriller’s status as the best‑selling US album. Temperton also wrote for artists like Anita Baker, Donna Summer, Aretha Franklin and The Brothers Johnson, won a Grammy in 1990 for “Birdland,” and earned two Oscar nominations in 1986 for The Color Purple soundtrack. Tributes poured in from Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, Mark Ronson, Chaka Khan, Gilles Peterson and others, highlighting his prolific, low‑profile genius that shaped a funkier musical world.

Researchers led by Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof. Alayne Street‑Perrott, together with colleagues from Exeter, Reading, São Paulo and Belém, have uncovered more than 450 large, geometrical earthwork “geoglyphs” in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon, likely dating back around 2,000 years. The ditched enclosures, hidden for centuries by bamboo‑dominated rainforest and revealed after recent deforestation, appear not to be villages or defensive structures but may have served sporadic ritual or gathering functions, akin to Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. Soil analyses of phytoliths, charcoal and carbon isotopes indicate the geoglyphs were built among tall vegetation, invisible above the canopy, and reveal a long‑term human influence on the forest: a diverse assemblage of plant species cultivated over 6,000 years, suggesting ancient “agroforestry” or a “prehistoric supermarket” of useful trees whose legacy may persist in Acre’s remaining forests.

The 21‑year‑old Australian, ranked a career‑high No. 12, defeated world No. 29 Steve Querrey 6‑4, 6‑4 in 53 minutes to reach the second round, while noting he felt bored and very tired after a demanding schedule that included winning the Japan Open and traveling to the Qi Zhong Stadium near Shanghai, which left him with poor sleep and a rough ride to the courts; he also recalled being fined $1,500 at the previous year’s Shanghai Masters for a foul‑mouthed outburst in which he called the tournament a “circus.”

Scientists and charities are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination, currently given to 12‑ and 13‑year‑old girls to prevent cervical cancer, to boys in order to curb rising head and neck cancers, which are increasingly affecting younger, non‑smoking men with an average age of 55; they note that HPV accounts for 5% of global cancers and that 85% of Welsh girls have been vaccinated since the 2008 school programme, but the government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before deciding on any changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15‑year‑old West Calder High School pupil, battled a rare gamma‑delta T‑cell lymphoma diagnosed in August and chronicled his treatment and positive outlook on a Facebook page, “Jak’s Journey,” which garnered over 28,000 likes and highlighted his love of Rangers FC, meetings with former players, hospital stays in Edinburgh and Glasgow, and personal moments such as playing the tuba and visiting classmates; after his cancer spread throughout his body in January and doctors ceased treatment, he posted a farewell message, his family urged donations to Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research, and he briefly attended a school prom in his honor, receiving a Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy before passing away, with a charity football match at Livingston FC’s Energy Assets Arena planned to raise further funds.

Egypt edged Uganda 1‑0 thanks to an 89th‑minute strike by Abdallah El Said, set up by Mohamed Salah after a largely uneventful match in which Uganda’s earlier goal was ruled out for off‑side; the win keeps Egypt’s Group D top spot in contention as they prepare to face Ghana, while Uganda’s defeat ends their tournament run, leaving Ghana already through to the quarter‑finals and Uganda to play Mali in their final group game.

Lancashire County Council has earmarked land on the former Glenburn Sports College and the unused Westbank campus of Skelmersdale College for a new railway scheme, following a Network Rail comparative study of these sites and another near the Concourse shopping centre; the plan, developed with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, would provide Skelmersdale—designated a new town in 1961 and the largest north‑west town without its own station since the original one closed in 1956—with two direct trains per hour to Liverpool, and the council will now begin acquiring the land, citing the preferred location’s size, good highway access, connectivity and potential for future expansion, as highlighted by County Councillor John Fillis.
Police discovered plants in an elaborate grow house while searching a warehouse near Ashbourne on Saturday morning, and a man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

Police in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, reported that a 28‑year‑old German woman of Kurdish origin was found seriously injured on a pavement on Sunday after being dragged by the neck through several streets; she underwent emergency surgery and was flown to a specialist clinic, while her 38‑year‑old ex‑partner from nearby Bad Münder turned himself in and is now in custody, with prosecutors saying the motive remains unclear, the area secured and witnesses urged to come forward.

A study of 4,600 Australian workers using 2013‑14 workplace‑relations data found that women ask for pay rises as often as men but are 25 % less likely to receive one, disproving the “reticent female” theory; the analysis compared full‑time with full‑time and part‑time with part‑time employees and controlled for employer size, industry, parental status and qualifications, showing that the disparity persists across comparable groups and appears to reflect pure gender discrimination, while younger workers under 40 of both sexes ask for and obtain raises at similar rates, suggesting a shift in negotiating behavior among younger women.

Oxford City Council has spent money on ground investigations for new burial sites but has found none suitable, leaving only the Wolvercote and Botley cemeteries, which are expected to be full by 2018 and 2021; despite this, the council continues to explore options, though board member Linda Smith notes that all council‑owned sites identified have been ruled out due to size, ground conditions, high water tables, or restrictive covenants, and once the two remaining cemeteries close, only the reopening of family plots, a few reserved plots, and ash interments will be possible, with the last expansion of burial space in Oxford dating back to 1932.

Visitors to the Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway, Isle of Lewis, from 19–22 July can use a new augmented‑reality app that links signs and posters to online content such as videos, band interviews and ticket purchasing, viewable on phones and tablets; the lineup includes The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean, and director Caroline Maclennan says the feature enhances the onsite experience while allowing people worldwide to interact with the festival, receive updated information before and during the event, and capture its atmosphere at any time.

A 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day; veterinary staff pronounced him dead and the British Horseracing Authority identified a “severe pulmonary haemorrhage” as the cause, noting such episodes are rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues, though Many Clouds had previously shown post‑race ataxia and a tendency to overheat, had been closely monitored, and had earlier victories in the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, with trainer Oliver Sherwood calling him the “horse of a lifetime.”

A 15‑year‑old girl who met a man named David Ayrton in a Portsmouth garage in autumn 2004 is now 34 and, under the name Davina, has denied a rape charge for which she will be sentenced on 4 March; Judge Ian Pearson remanded her in custody, likely to a male prison in Winchester, citing substantial risk to herself and potential non‑attendance, and noted the case’s unusual nature, while the court heard that Ayrton, who has learning difficulties and attempted suicide last summer, has had protocols arranged for her detention, discussed her sexuality without having made physical changes or taken medication, changed her name in 2012, and was accused of raping the teenager in the garage while two others slept, an incident the victim recalled after drinking a can and a half of Foster’s and reporting to a care‑home worker in 2014.

The Serbian pair were defeated 6‑4, 6‑4 by Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, a loss that followed Djokovic’s singles exit at the hands of Argentina’s Juan Martin del Potro; the 29‑year‑old world No. 1 had earlier suffered a surprise third‑round Wimbledon defeat to American Sam Querrey, but then captured his 30th Masters title in Toronto ahead of the Olympics.

More than 20 competitors from Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada and the US will take part in a chainsaw‑only carving competition in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where they shape logs into animals and people, and last year’s champion, Pete Bowsher of Moffat, will return to defend his Claymore Trophy title.

Webb, 27, is nearing a comeback after a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm‑up with Italy in September, aiming to be fit for Wales’ Six Nations start against Ireland on 7 February and possibly returning a few weeks earlier with physiotherapists’ approval; he is currently in a pre‑season phase, has been capped 16 times, and has renewed his dual contract with the Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with his home region—where he debuted in 2007—over offers elsewhere to keep himself in the best position to play for his country.

Border agents stopped two men with backpacks five miles east of Sumas, Washington, after they attempted to smuggle 58 lb (26 kg) of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco; one man fired at agents and fled, while the other, Jeffrey Laviolette, was arrested, and a fugitive, Nathan Hall, was later captured in British Columbia. Inside the backpacks was also a California driver’s licence bearing Hall’s picture but another name. Police also arrested a Bellingham woman, Kali Henifin, who planned to pick up the men, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, who was to be paid $11,000 to drive the drugs to San Francisco. The three U.S. defendants face conspiracy, possession and distribution charges, highlighting the area’s reputation as a major drug‑smuggling route.

The NSPCC’s Childline service reported counseling over 4,500 children in the past year—up from about 2,400 in 2011‑12—and warned that the true number of online abuse victims is likely far higher, with some as young as seven describing torment, abuse and fear of school; the charity highlighted that online trolls cause widespread misery and humiliation, prompting Childline president Dame Esther Rantzen to call the figures a wake‑up call, stressing that bullying now follows children beyond school gates, can become relentless cyber‑persecution, and requires urgent intervention by adults, parents and teachers, while schools must treat the issue seriously and encourage children to seek help; the report coincides with the start of Anti‑Bullying Week coordinated by the Anti‑Bullying Alliance, which collaborates with parents, schools and other groups to combat the problem, and includes a young person’s account of being urged to kill themselves online and feeling misunderstood by parents, underscoring the need for effective strategies and advice from peers on dealing with bullying.

Following a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office, Israel’s Jerusalem Planning and Housing Committee postponed a vote on authorising 492 new homes in the Ramat Shlomo and Ramot settlements to avoid further straining relations with the United States ahead of U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry’s speech on the Israeli‑Palestinian conflict; the postponement came after the U.S. abstained—rather than veto—a UN Security Council resolution condemning settlement construction as illegal under international law and a major obstacle to a two‑state solution, a move that infuriated Netanyahu, who summoned the ambassadors of the U.S. and the 14 Security Council members that voted for the resolution, recalled Israel’s envoys to New Zealand and Senegal, cut aid to Senegal and cancelled a visit by Ukraine’s prime minister, while the resolution was welcomed by Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas as paving the way for a forthcoming Middle‑East peace conference in France.

In a BBC interview on the eve of her 90th birthday, the Queen was praised as a “guiding example” of a good monarch, while a new stamp set featuring four generations of the Royal Family was released; celebrations at Windsor included a visit to the Royal Mail delivery office marking the service’s 500th anniversary, the opening of a bandstand in Alexandra Gardens with schoolchildren singing “Happy Birthday,” and the unveiling of a plaque for the 6.3‑km Queen’s Walkway commemorating her record reign, followed by an evening beacon lighting across the UK and worldwide, with U.S. President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama slated to join her for lunch the next day. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed admiration for the Queen’s dignified service, and Prince William, addressing recent “work‑shy” headlines, affirmed his commitment to duty, citing the Queen as his best role model while acknowledging criticism without letting it affect him. The republican pressure group Republic condemned the BBC’s coverage as overly celebratory and unbalanced.

West Ham United defeated Cheltenham Town 2‑0 in the EFL Cup, with Diafra Sakho scoring his first goal since November from a Sam Byram pass and Andre Ayew adding a second shortly after, both before half‑time; despite several chances for both sides, including efforts from Harry Pell, Jordon Forster and James Collins, Cheltenham could not test goalkeeper Adrian and were eliminated, ending League Two’s representation in the competition, while the match marked the teams’ first meeting since a 2‑1 Hammers win at Upton Park four years earlier.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl, 36, was killed in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when 46‑year‑old Andreas Werner of Leipzig failed to see the motorcyclist as he turned his VW Transporter right; Werner pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving at Llandudno Magistrates’ Court, received a £1,000 fine and a two‑year UK driving ban, while prosecutor Sarah Marsh noted the victim’s family saw no merit in imprisonment, accepting it as a momentary lapse, and defence lawyer Craig Hutchinson described Werner as remorseful and unable to explain the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a 27‑year‑old from Southall, left the UK in January to join the IS‑affiliated group Rayat al Tawheed in Syria, where he posted masked propaganda videos, appealed for donations, and was featured in gruesome images—including one of him holding a bag with a Syrian soldier’s head—while claiming the fighter alias Abu Daigham al‑Britani; after MI5 surveillance, he attempted to return to Britain in June with the help of his cousin Tahir Bhatti, faking his own death online and trying to slip through Dover, but was arrested at the border, charged with four offences (including a now‑filed solicitation‑to‑murder charge) and faces up to life imprisonment, while Bhatti has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender and Khawaja has been held in the high‑risk unit at Belmarsh prison.

Jackson, a 22‑year‑old who netted four goals in 36 appearances as Wrexham finished eighth, has become Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season after rejecting a new contract from Wrexham; caretaker manager Paul Heckingbottom praised his pace and attacking style, noting he will fit well into the team ahead of Barnsley's League One play‑off final at Wembley.

Bottles of the detergent “Vanish” began washing up on Poldhu Cove and nearby beaches in Cornwall, prompting National Trust volunteers to clear them because of potential wildlife risk; although the bottles are sealed, some may have leaked, and the Maritime and Coastguard Agency notes that while the MV Blue Ocean lost a container near Land’s End in May, there is no definitive evidence linking that loss to the bottles, which are thought to have come from a container that went overboard during stormy seas; the Cornwall Wildlife Trust expressed strong concern for sensitive marine life, Cornwall Council and partners will monitor the area, and the public is advised to keep children and dogs away and not attempt to retrieve the bottles.

The incident occurred around 14:00 on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness, causing several minor injuries, leading to the road’s closure and the implementation of diversions via the A897 Helmsdale‑to‑Melvich route, with Police Scotland confirming that inquiries into the crash are ongoing.

Dervite, a 28‑year‑old French centre‑back who joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances for the club, played 14 games last season, helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion; praised by manager Phil Parkinson for his late‑season contribution, he has now signed a new contract alongside David Wheater, Gary Madine and Jem Karacan as Bolton move up to the Championship.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of offering “false hope” after the two parties, which had previously teamed up to defeat the government on EU‑citizens’ rights and parliamentary approval for a Brexit deal, fell out when MPs rejected those amendments—Lib Dems insisting on them while Labour deferred to the Commons; a Labour source in the Lords called the Lib Dems’ stance “grand‑standing” aimed at campaign leaflets and criticised the false hope given to worried citizens, while Lib Dem Europe spokesperson Baroness Ludford blamed Labour for “waving through the government’s plans” and aligning with the Conservatives on a hard Brexit, noting that despite their history of joint opposition on issues from higher education to housing, the Lib Dems will continue to work with peers on shared goals, though the Labour source predicted lingering tensions and doubted any “progressive consensus” gatherings will materialise.

The passage explains that defence has become a low‑priority election issue in the UK, with polls placing it only just inside the top ten concerns behind the economy, NHS and immigration, a trend reinforced by public fatigue from recent overseas interventions; meanwhile the armed forces are shrinking—regular army numbers are set to fall from 102,000 to 82,000, the Royal Navy to 19 warships and the RAF to seven front‑line fast‑jet squadrons—creating capability gaps such as the loss of maritime patrol aircraft, and the country’s defence spending has slipped from fourth to sixth globally and is projected to drop to 1.5‑1.7 % of GDP by decade’s end, jeopardising the NATO 2 % benchmark; major parties offer little protection for the MoD budget, with the Conservatives pledging to replace Trident, raise the equipment budget by 1 % annually and halt army cuts, while Labour avoids firm commitments, the Lib Dems propose ending continuous at‑sea deterrence, and the SNP and Greens would scrap it, leaving the future of the nuclear programme and the costly new aircraft carriers (which face manning and equipment shortfalls) uncertain and highlighting the risk of a “hollow force” despite Britain’s desire to “punch above its weight.”

Barcelona maintains it committed no offence regarding Neymar’s transfer, stating the aim is to address possible interpretations of the contracts and denying any tax‑related crime while filing a voluntary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56; the club originally paid €57 million (£48.6 million) for the striker, with total costs—including fees, wages and taxes—reaching £106.8 million, and a Spanish judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigations, while former president Sandro Rosell, under separate scrutiny, has denied wrongdoing; Neymar has scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three goals in seven Champions League matches this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27‑year‑old delivery driver from Nottingham, was killed when a van he was in was struck by a Mazda Premacy driven the wrong way on the motorway by Albert Kenneth Newman, who also died; his family and colleague Andy Harrington, who was seriously injured, called for regular driving tests and medical examinations for older drivers, arguing that age‑related reaction slowdown contributes to accidents, while the DVLA noted that drivers over 70 already renew licences every three years via a self‑assessment form without a medical test and said there is no evidence older drivers cause more serious accidents, and Age UK’s Caroline Abrahams emphasized the importance of supporting older people to drive safely for independence; the story was featured on BBC One East Midlands’ Inside Out on 25 January.

Many women have raised safety concerns about transvaginal mesh implants used for incontinence, citing painful and debilitating side effects, and two original review‑group members quit in protest over a perceived watered‑down final report; an independent expert, Professor Alison Britton of Glasgow Caledonian University, has been tasked with examining how the report’s conclusions were reached and identifying future lessons, while the report itself recommends that mesh procedures not be offered routinely for pelvic organ prolapse, that patients receive a range of treatment options and be given information for informed choices, and that adverse‑event reporting be mandatory; the health secretary noted that a ban is beyond the Scottish government’s authority and lies with the UK Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, and chairwoman Tracey Gillies apologized for failing to achieve consensus among panel members amid resignations and public criticism, after Olive McIlroy, Elaine Holmes, and a consultant left the group over concerns the final draft had been altered; over the past 20 years more than 20,000 Scottish women have received mesh or tape implants, with over 400 now pursuing legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

Laura Muir, 23, shattered Paula McColgan’s 25‑year‑old British indoor 5 km record by 14 seconds, clocking 14:49.12 at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow; although McColgan questioned whether the mixed‑gender race met UK Athletics’ record criteria and if doping controls were in place, British Athletics confirmed the time should be ratified, noting no drug‑test requirement for record attempts, and McColgan praised Muir’s 1,500 m speed and potential to run faster, calling her world‑class and predicting future medal success, while noting Muir also holds the British 1,500 m record and reached the Olympic final in Rio 2016.

Jung claimed victory on Sam, a late replacement after Fischertakinou fell ill, while France’s Astier Nicolas earned silver and American Phillip Dutton took bronze; GB’s William Fox‑Pitt, competing ten months after an induced coma from a fall, finished 12th after a flawless show‑jumping round but a costly cross‑country phase that dropped him from the dressage lead to 21st, and Ireland’s Jonty Evans placed ninth on Cooley Rorkes Drift.

Andy Murray defeated Italy’s 29th seed Fabio Fognini 6‑2, 4‑6, 6‑1, 7‑5 in a two‑hour‑39‑minute match that ended at 20:57 BST, securing his 11th appearance in the last 16 and setting up a fourth‑round clash with Frenchman Benoît Paire; fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week for the first time with a 6‑4, 6‑1 win over Greece’s Maria Sakkari.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, and police later found patrons still inside while till receipts showed alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST; the magistrate ordered the bar’s closure for three months and fined license holder Colleen O’Neill £3,000 for two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and James Thomas £1,000 for one count, noting O’Neill’s “appalling record” and expressing concern over the lack of power to impose a custodial sentence.

Mike Nesbitt closed his manifesto launch with the line “Domination doesn’t work, partnership does,” positioning the Ulster Unionist Party’s election as a referendum on the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal and accusing the government of “incompetence, arrogance, cronyism and the strong whiff of corruption.” When asked about colleague Danny Kennedy’s public distancing from his remarks, Nesbitt praised Kennedy’s listening, drew laughter from the audience and insisted he had no regrets, urging voters to back the Ulster Unionists and any candidate who will do the right thing locally and nationally. He said that if the party entered Stormont Castle it would be with a nationalist party, preferring the SDLP to Sinn Féin, and recounted door‑knocking in unionist areas that yielded “very little criticism and a lot of support.” Confident about vote‑transfer arrangements, he warned that voters would remember the daily £85,000 loss and a decade of DUP‑Sinn Féin rule, noting “leopards can’t change their spots.” The “Real Partnership” manifesto calls for tackling waiting lists, expanding the PSNI to 7,500 officers, prioritising the York Street interchange, supporting the LGBT community and guaranteeing no group is disadvantaged by Brexit, while a “Cleaning Up Stormont” section pledges further reforms.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced that a motion will be presented to the Northern Ireland Assembly to align the region with England and Wales by introducing automatic pardons—known as “Turing’s Law”—for men convicted of now‑abolished sexual offences, allowing both posthumous pardons and applications from living gay and bisexual men; she has secured executive agreement for a legislative‑consent motion and aims to implement the provisions as soon as possible to ensure equal treatment, with the motion now proceeding to assembly consideration.

Laura Muir, a 23‑year‑old from Kinross, ran 4:19.12 to finish second behind Kenya’s Faith Kipyegon, breaking Yvonne Murray’s 1994 Scottish record and moving to second on the British all‑time list behind Zola Budd; the performance also secured her as the holder of the Scottish 1500 m and mile records after a fifth‑place finish at last year’s World Championships, and she now aims to earn a place for Great Britain at the Olympic trials in Birmingham (24‑26 June) following an 800 m win in Montbeliard and with a 1500 m race in Stockholm scheduled, all while balancing her training with her fourth year of veterinary studies.
The passage notes that it includes some of your photos featuring the 26 Scottish beaches that have been ranked as “most excellent” for water quality.

Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC argued that suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill Alexander Litvinenko and that the Russian state was “likely to have been the sponsor of this plot,” citing the fatal polonium‑210 dose in tea they gave him in 2006, which caused his death three weeks later and suggests state participation, though Horwell stressed this does not prove President Vladimir Putin ordered the murder; possible motives include Litvinenko’s 2000 defection to the UK, his accusations against the FSB, and his personal attacks on Putin. Horwell warned that the public risk from polonium exposure is unknown, noted that Litvinenko was poisoned twice, and said the suspects left a “trail of polonium” with no credible scientific rebuttal. Attempts to extradite the men have failed, they remain in Russia, and the inquiry—though the force wanted them tried for murder—was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, has been appointed captain of Australia’s one‑day side and will also lead the Twenty20 team in Aaron Finch’s absence, with fellow batsman David Warner, 28, named his vice‑captain; national selector Rod Marsh praised Smith’s talent and suitability as Michael Clarke’s successor after Clarke, 34, retired following the Ashes defeat that gave England a 3‑1 lead, noting that Smith had already captained three Tests against India while Clarke recovered from injury and has amassed 2,952 runs in 32 Tests at an average of 54.66, while Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, is recognized for his maturity and senior role, and the duo will steer Australia in the limited‑overs matches following the final Ashes Test at the Oval beginning 20 August.

Earlier this week, Liberal Democrat leader Mr. Farron declined to label homosexual sex a sin, repeatedly responding that “we are all sinners,” but affirmed his strong support for LGBT‑plus rights, stating that defending equal marriage and extending marital rights to transgender people would be a top priority; he explained that he voted against the 2007 Equality Bill—despite supporting equality—because the Liberal Democrats had tabled an amendment over concerns for individual liberties, and he highlighted the current “spousal veto” that prevents transgender individuals from accessing marriage without their partner’s consent, urging broader legal equality for all sexualities.

Sanofi shut its Fawdon drug‑manufacturing site in 2015, eliminating 450 jobs, and Accord Healthcare will now occupy the plant, aiming to re‑employ many former Sanofi workers and expecting an “extremely positive” effect on the area; Newcastle City Council leader Nick Forbes called the move “fantastic news” that strengthens the region’s reputation in science and healthcare and provides highly skilled, long‑term jobs, while Accord Healthcare produces and distributes over 130 pharmaceutical products to roughly 60 countries worldwide.

The local authority announced that Richard Ellis will leave on Friday at the end of his contract, while Ciaran Monaghan and Ewan Sutherland are opting for a voluntary redundancy and early‑retirement scheme; Ellis has served as interim director of corporate governance and acting deputy chief executive, Monaghan heads the chief executive’s office, and Sutherland leads human resources and customer services. Opposition SNP leader Stephen Flynn said the exits highlight the council’s failure to retain senior staff and warned more departures are likely, and council chief executive Angela Scott thanked the three for their dedication and professionalism.

Militants armed with guns and grenades detonated explosives at the gate of Kabul’s Sardar Daud 400‑bed hospital at 09:00 local time, entered the building and opened fire on staff, patients and guards, wounding more than 50 people; after several hours of fighting, commandos killed all four attackers, an act claimed by the Islamic State (IS) group while the Taliban denied involvement, prompting President Ashraf Ghani to denounce the assault as a violation of human values and a threat to Afghanistan’s sanctity; the attack marks the first time IS fighters have directly engaged security forces in the capital, using a Taliban‑style gate‑blowing tactic that suggests expanded resources and training, and follows a series of IS‑linked bombings in Kabul and Pakistan since its 2015 declaration of a Khorasan Province, as well as recent Taliban suicide attacks, indicating a possible increase in high‑profile assaults in the coming months.

The English rider Martin crashed at this year’s TT, where his Fireblade bike suffered mechanical problems, leading him to say he was quitting road racing but later clarify on Facebook that he has not given up on racing, though he has no plans to race Hondas this year; he missed the North West 200 after teammate John McGuinness crashed in practice and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix, describing the TT as a “bloody disaster,” noting that testing showed the bike would be uncompetitive, and that his team withdrew him from the Ulster event, after which he said he wants to focus on classic and oddball races.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of the 28 governorships in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999, while the PDP won only eight, mainly in the south‑east, and retained Rivers State; the APC also retained Lagos, giving President‑elect Muhammadu Buhari—who defeated Goodluck Jonathan and will be inaugurated on 29 May—the first president whose party controls the commercial capital, though it failed to win any of the five oil‑producing states, a concern given militant threats to oil revenue; elections were marred by 66 violent incidents, especially in Rivers and other southern areas, but were overall more peaceful than previous polls, and the PDP faces a period of introspection after losing key northern states such as Katsina, Kaduna and Adamawa and amid allegations of corruption and ineffective handling of the Boko Haram insurgency.

Mighty’s report accuses Singapore‑based agricultural trader Olam and its majority shareholder, state‑owned Temasek, of enabling unsustainable palm‑oil practices that fuel regional haze, claiming Olam creates a “secretive market” for rogue suppliers and that Temasek’s investment finances this “black box” of environmentally harmful production; both firms reject the allegations, with Olam asserting a zero‑burn, no‑deforestation policy, having disclosed 14 suppliers and pledging to vet all sources over several years, while Temasek says it does not direct portfolio companies and supports no‑burn policies, and the report also flags similar concerns over Olam’s joint ventures in Gabon, where it is alleged to clear rainforests for monoculture plantations, a claim Olam counters by emphasizing responsible, transparent public‑private partnerships.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant began serving puppy platters after a new law allowed dogs to eat outdoors at restaurants.

Fernando Forestieri is doubtful with a knee issue after only featuring from the bench in his last two games, Derby County striker David Nugent may return following his absence in Monday’s draw with Huddersfield due to a groin problem, and midfielder Jacob Butterfield is seeking a recall after scoring a late equaliser off the bench against the Terriers.

Pakistan’s telecom regulator lifted the Supreme Court‑imposed YouTube ban after Google launched a Pakistan‑specific version of the site, prompting ISPs to restore access and a welcome message from Pakistan Telecommunication Company Ltd; while many young users celebrated the move, activists demand transparency about the deal’s terms, and the ministry of information technology noted that Google now offers a web process for the PTA to request blocking of offending material, which Google will restrict after review, though YouTube’s spokeswoman emphasized that government removal requests are not automatic, are subject to community guidelines, and are recorded in its Transparency Report; the ban, originally enacted in 2012 following the controversial “Innocence of Muslims” video that sparked deadly protests, reflected Pakistan’s strict blasphemy laws, and Google recently introduced local YouTube versions for Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA’s Ad‑Hoc Electoral Committee and a Swiss‑Italian like candidate Gianni Infantino, has been urged by Liberian FA chief Musa Bility to step down from the committee before the February 26 presidential election, with Bility threatening to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw within three working days; the demand cites Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations, which bars members with a conflict of interest, noting that Scala previously withdrew in 2015 when his nationality matched incumbent Sepp Blatter’s, while his spokesman argues that with no incumbent president among the five candidates there is no conflict; Bility, who was denied eligibility to run after a failed check, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali and is urging other Africans to do the same, as the election—featuring candidates Prince Ali, Gianni Infantino, Jérôme Champagne, Sheikh Salman and Tokyo Sexwale—will be decided by FIFA’s 209 members at its Zurich headquarters in 18 days.
