Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, were killed shortly after 09:00 BST on Monday while working in a paint‑spraying area at Harford Attachments on Spar Road, a company that manufactures buckets for diggers; their bodies were removed the following Tuesday, and a forensic search indicated a flash‑over explosion caused by a buildup of toxic fumes and an ignition source, prompting significant forensic progress, witness statements, and the involvement of Health and Safety Executive inspectors and electrical safety experts.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologising for a letter of complaint stemming from a contentious 2015 quarter‑final loss to Equatorial Guinea, where a disputed penalty sparked a furious response but no corruption accusations; Morocco, whose 2015 hosting duties were withdrawn after it refused to stage the tournament over Ebola fears and was initially fined $1 million, had its ban lifted and fine reduced to $50,000 by the Court of Arbitration for Sport, allowing it to enter the 2017 qualifying draw, and both nations were placed in the 2017 groups—Tunisia in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti, and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé—while Tunisia eyes a record thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup appearance.

A mass fracas in the 95th minute of Chelsea’s 3‑1 win at Etihad Stadium led to a charge, with City’s Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho sent off; Aguero received a four‑match ban for a second violent‑conduct dismissal after a late challenge on David Luiz, while Fernandinho was given a three‑match ban after clashing with Cesc Fabregas, who faces no further action, and Pep Guardiola apologised for his team’s role, with both clubs required to respond by 18:00 GMT on 8 December.

Wales and other parts of the UK have some of the world’s highest cancer mortality rates, prompting a pilot scheme in the Cynon Valley and Castleford that targets patients whose family doctors suspect cancer despite a lack of clear symptoms; after doctors visited Denmark and observed its improved diagnostic services, Welsh health officials noted that delayed diagnoses occur because asymptomatic patients do not fit easily into existing treatment pathways, leading to multiple weeks of testing and late‑stage treatment, so the pilot will allow family doctors to refer such patients directly to a diagnostic centre at Prince of Wales Hospital in Llantrisant within seven days, aiming to see about six patients per week and increase the current 35 % diagnosis rate for concerning symptoms; a similar clinic will be established at Castleford Port Talbot as part of another test programme developed after Welsh experts returned from Aarhus, and Dr Gareth Davies and GP Gareth Jordan both stress that the plan should reassure patients, accelerate diagnosis, and, if successful after six months, be rolled out to other health boards in the region.

England secured a dominant victory at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a 589‑8 declared and 173‑1 declared total, marking their second‑largest win over Pakistan by runs; Joe Root, promoted to number three, earned man of the match with a 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, also taking four catches and a wicket, while captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76 not out, and England’s bowlers dismissed Pakistan for 198 and 234 on a pitch offering little assistance, prompting praise from commentators and former players, and setting the stage for Pakistan’s two‑day tour match against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston.

Warren Gatland heads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with interim coach Rob Howley on his staff, while forwards coach McBryde steps in as head coach for the third time after previously leading Wales tours in 2009 and 2013; the Welsh Rugby Union will add assistant coaches for the summer tour, with chief executive Martyn Phillips saying the full management team should be confirmed next week, and union chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions’ selection panel, argues that the involvement of Welsh coaches offers a valuable development opportunity that will benefit Welsh rugby overall, citing past Lions experiences as invigorating and the New Zealand tour as a crucial test to inspire individuals.

Hull City overturned an early Charlie Austin penalty to beat Southampton 2‑1, with substitute Robert Snodgrass scoring in the 61st minute and setting up Michael Dawson’s header, while Sam Clus made a last‑minute goal‑line clearance; despite losing strikers Abel Hernandez and Will Keane to first‑half injuries, Hull secured their first league win since 20 August, ending a six‑game losing run but remaining in the bottom three as the international break approaches, in front of 17,768 fans at the KCOM Stadium, and both managers reflected on concentration and injury issues ahead of Hull’s next match at Sunderland and Southampton’s clash with Liverpool.

A collision occurred at about 14:15 BST on the B1191 at Thornton near Woodhall Spa, killing a locally‑resident motorcyclist while the tractor driver escaped injury; Lincolnshire Police have closed the B1191 in both directions between the B1192 Tattershall Road junction in Woodhall Spa and the A158 Jubilee Way junction in Horncastle and are appealing for witnesses to come forward.

President Ivanov halted an investigation into abuse‑of‑power claims revealed by covert recordings, saying he wanted to “end the agony” before June’s early elections, a move condemned by opposition leader Zoran Zaev, who called it illegal and urged protests, and by EU Enlargement Commissioner Johannes Hahn, who warned it jeopardized Macedonia’s EU membership; the crisis stems from 2015 recordings that appear to show ministers plotting vote‑rigging, covering up a murder, and wire‑tapping about 20,000 people—including politicians, journalists and religious leaders—while Zaev has released a steady stream of such recordings alleging high‑level corruption, mismanaged funds, politically motivated prosecutions and cover‑ups, accusations the government denies, instead accusing Zaev of trying to destabilise the nation.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea’s Saturday match against Bournemouth after the sacking of Bob Bradley, while the club aim to appoint a new permanent boss—ex‑Derby manager Paul Clement being the frontrunner—to steer them out of trouble and avoid relegation, acknowledging the difficulty of returning to the Premier League even if they drop down; the Swans, promoted in 2011 after a remarkable rise from near bankruptcy and a 2003 threat of exiting the Football League, have historically been praised for their well‑run, possession‑based style under managers like Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Michael Laudrup, but Curtis, a long‑time player, says the club has lost its “Swansea Way” since Laudrup’s 2014 departure amid frequent managerial changes and player turnover, though he believes the current squad is capable of staying up and reminds new signings of the club’s historic journey and its importance to the community.

Dagenham & Redbridge, who had reached League One in 2010, were relegated after a 2‑1 loss to Leyton Orient in which Armand Gnanduillet scored the winner, leaving the Daggers back in the National League under manager John Still, the coach who previously guided them from the Conference to League One and who pledged to push for promotion next season; the club now hold League Two’s worst goal difference, have conceded 20 more goals than the same point last term and struggled offensively despite veteran striker Jamie Cureton’s nine goals, while Leyton Orient’s victory kept their play‑off hopes alive, two points shy of the spots, shortly after player‑manager Kevin Nolan was dismissed and interim manager Andy Hessenthaler stressed the need for professionalism and wins, and Still warned that a lack of organisation and discipline had doomed his side.

Steven Gerrard, the 36‑year‑old former Liverpool captain, will return to Liverpool in February as a youth coach, marking his first job since retiring as a player; Jürgen Klopp praised the “wonderful news,” noting Gerrard’s desire to become a manager and his bright future, while highlighting that he must learn the role. Gerrard debuted for Liverpool in 1998, left the club after the 2014‑15 season for LA Galaxy, and retired in November after a 19‑year career that included Champions League, UEFA Cup, FA Cup and three League Cup victories. He was linked to the MK Dons managerial vacancy after leaving Galaxy but said it came “too soon,” and he is now working toward his UEFA A coaching licence, required for Premier League management.

McManus opened the scoring early, followed by a deflected strike from Ross Forbes to double the hosts’ lead; Kyle McAusland’s shot reduced the deficit for Alloa before halftime, but a second goal from McManus and a late finish by Denny Johnstone secured a comfortable victory for the home team.

Ofsted has shut three Birmingham sites where children were taught in squalid conditions, investigating the owners for running illegal schools that could carry up to 51 weeks in jail, and it has visited 18 unregulated schools—mostly in Muslim communities—amid concerns that children are at risk of abuse or radicalisation; any venue teaching more than 20 hours a week must register, yet some “flexi schools” exploit home‑education rights to operate unlawfully, prompting a government‑funded team of six inspectors to probe across all religious groups, while the education secretary plans to seek prosecution consent for identified unregistered schools and a consultation on tighter regulation runs until mid‑January.

Lilliard Gin, operating from a cowshed at the Born in the Borders visitor centre in Jedburgh, is the region’s first new distillery since 1837 and precedes several whisky‑distillery proposals; lead distiller Kate Macinnes highlights its tiny production still, focus on local Teviot‑valley botanicals and the aim to showcase Borders “terroir,” while John Henderson of Born in the Borders notes its natural partnership with the on‑site brewery and commitment to local sourcing, and the brand name honors Lilliard, the legendary heroine of the 1545 Battle of Ancrum Moor, reflecting both the landscape and the strong female production team.

Harry Whitlam was killed in August 2013 at Swithens Farm, Rothwell, when 51‑year‑old Gary Green, who was more than twice the legal drink‑driving limit and had consumed the equivalent of 13 pints of beer, reversed his vehicle into Whitlam at about 09:15 on 9 August; Green was prosecuted under health‑and‑safety legislation for failing to ensure safety on private land, was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks in jail, and the Health and Safety Executive described his behaviour as reckless, while Whitlam’s mother Pam, a farm café worker, said the tragedy has forever changed their close‑knit family and expressed hope that Harry’s memory will endure.

Luis Suárez, the 27‑year‑old Uruguayan striker who joined Barcelona for £75 million, has been cleared by the Court of Arbitration for Sport to train with the first team and play in friendly matches, though he remains barred from “organised” games and must still serve the remaining eight fixtures of his nine‑match international ban; his competitive Barcelona debut is expected in the 26 October El Clásico, and he will be available for Uruguay’s friendlies against Japan, South Korea and Saudi Arabia, while he can also attend matches and take part in promotional activities; the CAS ruling deemed FIFA’s original suspension for his bite on Italy’s Giorgio Chiellini at the 2014 World Cup excessive, noting that preventing training would unduly affect him after the ban, but it upheld the sanctions overall, a decision that disappointed FIFPRO, which had hoped for reduced penalties in exchange for treatment, and highlighted his prior disciplinary record, including earlier bites on PSV’s Otman Bakkal and Chelsea’s Branislav Ivanovic and a 2011 eight‑match ban for racially abusing Patrice Evra.

On 18 March 2014, Richard Blake‑Smith and his partner Anna won a 380‑metre obstacle race—featuring hay‑stack hurdles, a steep slope and water‑pistol dodging—by carrying Vytautas Kirkliauskas of Lithuania, who was transporting his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene; Blake‑Smith noted a week of training on a nearby athletics track and strong competition from the Lithuanians, and noted that the event allowed mixed pairings (men carrying women, men carrying men, and a woman carrying a woman). The duo will next compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

Stephen Hammond told Swansea East AM Mike Hedges that the scrapping of paper car‑tax discs in October and the shift to an electronic, monthly direct‑debit system will likely change DVLA job roles and reduce refunds, but any staff reductions will be handled by redeploying workers to other growth areas rather than making redundancies; Hedges, who had raised concerns about the future of the agency’s 5,000 employees after Chancellor George Osborne’s Autumn Statement announced the change, welcomed the minister’s assurances, acknowledging the advantages of the new system while expressing disappointment that fewer job opportunities will remain at the DVLA.

Hungarian minister Peter Szijjarto told Reuters that the EU should not intervene in “domestic issues,” noting Poland’s pledge to veto any move to strip Hungary of its voting rights, which require unanimous approval; the EU has objected to Hungary’s strict asylum‑seeker controls, a draft NGO law that would label groups as “foreign‑backed,” and a higher‑education law that could force the closure of the Central European University founded by George Soros, prompting thousands of protests, while the government under Viktor Orbán remains firm that it will not backtrack on any of the three contested laws.

The film, directed by Bill Condon, began filming at Shepperton Studios in May and is set for U.S. release on 17 March 2017; its cast includes Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and a star portraying Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper turned teapot originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury.

Adrian Gill, a celebrated Sunday Times journalist since 1993 known for his daring, witty prose and dictation style due to dyslexia, was diagnosed with an extensive array of cancers he described as the “full English” and died suddenly after chemotherapy, prompting heartfelt tributes from editors, writers and broadcasters who praised his brilliance, compassion and influence on the paper; his career, marked by both acclaim and controversy—including provocative remarks about a baboon, the Welsh, various locales, and a televised cyclist—was preceded by art‑review work in the 1980s, education at St Christopher’s, Central Saint Martins and the Slade, and a personal life that included marriages to Cressida Connolly and Amber Rudd (with whom he had two children) and, later, an engagement to long‑time partner Nicola Formby, with whom he had twins.

Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar, a Mongolian rapper known as Amraa and lead singer of Khar Sarnai, was attacked while performing in Ulan Bator, reportedly struck on the head with a bottle and repeatedly kicked in the face, leaving him in a coma for about ten days with serious brain injury; he had been wearing a red deel embroidered with a swastika, a traditional Mongolian symbol of eternity that predates its Nazi association, and his father and lawyer denied claims that he shouted “Heil Hitler,” while the Russian embassy said it was investigating the assault but called local reports “distorted,” and a police spokesman identified the suspect as a Russian diplomatic officer whose detention was deemed unnecessary because the injury was not serious, though the lawyer insisted the case must be pursued under Mongolian law regardless of diplomatic status.

Campaigners from the action group Plane Stupid demonstrated against the airport’s expansion on the northern runway at 03:30 BST on Monday, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a security‑restricted area; they are scheduled to appear in court on 19 August, and the Metropolitan Police said airport security would be reviewed.

Nick Selman’s mature 101 off 144 balls anchored Glamorgan’s total, his second first‑class century after an early drop, while seamers Matt Taylor and Craig Miles kept wickets falling regularly in cloudy Cardiff conditions; Gloucestershire, hampered by the bowlers, managed only a modest chase with Aneurin Donald’s quick‑fire 36, Graham Wagg and Timm van der Gugten salvaging a consolation bonus point, leaving the day evenly balanced as Glamorgan, captained by Michael Hogan in Jacques Rudolph’s absence, celebrated Selman’s return to form and Taylor praised his bowling effort and new red‑ball opportunities.

Craig Hughes, a 33‑year‑old from Flint, was arrested by North Wales Police in August after contacting the Hope Line Crisis Centre in Tennessee and planning a false police report that would lead officers to the Dee Estuary where he intended to ambush and shoot them; he made the threats twice while drunk, admitted two charges at Mold Crown Court, and, despite a prior 2009 firearm conviction, was remanded in custody pending sentencing next week, with his legal team asserting he never intended to carry out the threats, while the Hope Line centre provides confidential support and counselling.

Surrey recovered from 8‑2 to post 255‑7, anchored by a 130‑run partnership between Davies (90) and Ben Foakes, while Meaker’s three‑wicket burst (including Bairstow and Ballance) helped dismiss Yorkshire for 236 despite Tim Bresnan’s 68, with Meaker finishing 3‑61 and Matthew Waite taking 3‑48; Yorkshire’s chase faltered after early losses, a dropped catch by Waite, and a late surge of 27 runs in the final three overs, leading to a defeat that left captain Alex Lees and Surrey skipper Gareth Batty reflecting on missed opportunities and the bowlers’ strong performances.

A 56‑foot converted trawler, located six miles west of South Stack, radioed Holyhead coastguards at 07:00 BST reporting that its pump could not handle incoming water; the RNLI lifeboat crew responded by installing a pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

Veterinary student and middle‑distance runner Catriona Muir, 24, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on the Gold Coast because her final‑year exams aren’t until May and the Games are in April, forcing her to prioritize her degree; she expressed disappointment but remains optimistic about future Olympics and is eyeing the World Indoor Championships in March as a possible target, while noting she feels in good shape and would like to race in Birmingham. At the recent World Athletics Championships she placed fourth in the 1500 m and sixth in the 5,000 m, setting a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the latter, and praised her performance despite a heavy racing schedule, while Hellen Obiri won the 5,000 m gold in London with Sifan Hassan third.

Robbie Savage argues that Liverpool are far from replicating last season’s title challenge, citing a loss of goals after Luis Suarez’s sale and Daniel Sturridge’s injuries, an inadequate front‑three of Balotelli, Lambert and Borini, and a reduced work‑rate that has cut their first‑half scoring dramatically; he also notes a sharp decline in set‑piece effectiveness and a defence that, despite heavy spending on players like Sakho and Lovren, still lacks leadership and a commanding goalkeeper, leaving the team struggling to compete with a dominant Chelsea, while emphasizing that Steven Gerrard, despite his age and the psychological blow of his infamous slip, remains fit, vital and likely to stay at Anfield, needing to adapt his game to maintain his long‑term role.

A £45 million educational campus on Sutherland Drive in Kilmarnock will include primary and secondary schools, a Gaelic school and a childcare centre, and East Ayrshire Council intends to seek permission from the McIlvanney family to name the site after the locally born writer William McIlvanney; the council leader praised his passion for education. McIlvanney, originally an English teacher after graduating from Glasgow University, became a full‑time author in 1975, gaining immediate acclaim with his debut novel *Remedy Is None* and earning the title “Godfather of Tartan Noir” for works such as the Laidlaw trilogy, *Docherty* and *The Big Man*, as well as being a poet, journalist and broadcaster who contributed to Scotland’s political and sporting discourse, before his death at his Glasgow home on 5 December.

An area near Gourock’s swimming pool was evacuated on Monday after a British sea mine from the 1940s‑1950s was discovered, prompting residents within 500 m to keep windows closed, stay indoors and avoid going outside, while an exclusion zone was imposed on the river and a half‑mile sea zone that barred small boats and disrupted Caledonian MacBrayne ferry services from Gourock and Rothesay; the mine, deemed deteriorated and of uncertain explosive content, was to be moved to a safer location by the Royal Navy’s Northern Diving Unit, and local police chief Ch Insp Elliot Brown emphasized the precautionary nature of the evacuation, with Inverclyde Council thanking residents and businesses for their patience during the operation.

UK Sport will invest £345 million in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports for Tokyo—£2 million less than the Rio allocation—and has set Team GB targets of 51‑85 Olympic medals and 115‑162 Paralympic medals; however, funding cuts mean archery, fencing, weightlifting, wheelchair rugby and cycling (reduced by more than £4 million to £25.98 million) have missed out, and badminton, which earned a bronze men’s‑doubles medal, has lost all its £5.74 million support, prompting Badminton England’s chief executive to call the decision “catastrophic”; judo’s funding was slightly increased, while UK Sport’s chair and the sports minister stress the need to prioritise medal potential after Rio’s historic success, and note that £9 million of the total budget remains to be allocated, with investment for new Olympic sports such as baseball/softball, karate, skateboarding, sport climbing and surfing, as well as para‑taekwondo and para‑badminton, still to be confirmed.

Three Victorian hotels on East Cliff in Bournemouth—Bay View Court, The Cottonwood and the Ocean View—will be demolished to make way for a six‑storey, four‑star, 90‑room hotel and two assisted‑living apartment blocks (nine‑storey and seven‑storey, totaling 122 apartments); despite strong objections from English Heritage and the Ancient Monuments Society over the development’s scale and potential “severe harm” to the designated conservation area, councillors approved the plan by a 7‑3 vote, with Chair David Kelsey noting the need to preserve tourism while improving housing for older residents, and the council receiving 246 letters of support versus 49 objections.

Private Matthew Boyd, a 20‑year‑old soldier from the Royal Gibraltar Regiment originally from Carrickfergus, was found unconscious and later died after being punched, beaten and dragged from a bar called The Cellar in Brecon on the night of 8 May while off‑duty from training at the infantry battle school; CCTV showed the attack by 24‑year‑old Jake Valleys, who had been on a seven‑hour drinking binge and boasted he was the “hardest man in Brecon,” and Valleys’ friend Aaeron Evans was cleared of manslaughter after the jury heard he had left before any violence began, with Valleys scheduled to be sentenced on 8 December; senior investigating officer Det Supt David Guiney called the assault a “despicable act” that shocked the community, and the family’s tribute described Boyd as a loving, promising “all‑rounder” whose life was cut short, lamenting the void left by Valleys’ actions while noting the strong support from the Brecon community.

Andrew Travers departed the council by “mutual agreement” after an error that left voters at all 155 Barnet polling stations unable to vote because their names were missing from the poll list, prompting an independent investigation; Travers said he enjoyed his time and praised the borough’s growth, while a council spokesperson noted his valuable three‑and‑a‑half‑year contribution as chief executive, and deputy chief executive John Hooton will serve temporarily pending longer‑term arrangements; on election day only three of the first thirty voters were on the register, leading the council to apologise, offer emergency proxy votes, and face questions about the fairness of the result, with Travers blaming electoral registration lists; the council’s review, set to finish by the end of May and report to the General Functions Committee, will assess the “appropriateness” of arrangements for the June EU Referendum, and officials are discussing who will lead the investigation.

Gateshead defeated Wrexham 2‑1, with Josh Gillies opening the scoring from a fine free‑kick before half‑time, Wrexham equalising via Sean Newton’s set‑piece, and Ryan Bowman securing the winner with a header from Craig Baxter’s cross; Gateshead manager Malcolm Crosby praised his side’s second‑half improvement and the quality of the winning goal, while Wrexham manager Gary Mills expressed disappointment with his team’s second‑half performance despite creating chances.

The Global AgeWatch Index 2014, updated on 1 October 2014 at 19:45 BST, assesses the social and economic welfare of people over 60 in 96 nations, ranking Norway as the top country and Afghanistan as the lowest, with Mozambique next worst; media playback is not supported on the device.

The OneWeb project plans to launch a broadband satellite constellation of at least 600 spacecraft initially, eventually exceeding 2,000, to provide global internet access—including to every school—by deploying satellites in a 1,200 km orbit using more than 20 Soyuz rockets that will carry 32‑36 units per launch, targeting roughly 300 satellites by the end of 2020, 600 a year later and over 800 by mid‑decade; to achieve the required high‑volume, low‑cost production, Airbus has introduced automotive‑style assembly lines in Toulouse (with two more in Florida), aiming to build three satellites per shift at under $1 million each, a shift from traditional “gold‑plated” satellite manufacturing, and has already raised $1.7 billion in equity while seeking additional financing; OneWeb, registered in the UK’s Channel Islands, works with the UK Space Agency, emphasizing the economic benefits for the UK and committing to aggressive debris mitigation by de‑orbiting satellites within two years and adding hardware for possible retrieval, positioning itself as a first‑mover amid competing mega‑constellation plans from SpaceX, Boeing, ViaSat and others.

John Swinney warned that the UK government’s recent spending review adds “unprecedented pressure” on Scotland’s public finances, noting that cuts imposed since 2010 will leave the Scottish discretionary budget 12.5% lower in real terms by 2019‑20, with 4.2% of that reduction occurring now and more than £1 billion of cuts still to come by the end of the decade; despite this, he pledged to protect schools, hospitals and police services and highlighted recent improvements such as more police, lower crime, better schools, tuition‑free university and a record health budget, while the UK Scotland Office countered that Scotland will receive £390 million extra spending next year (rising to £750 million with its own underspend) and a block grant of almost £30 billion, arguing this is a better deal than independence, and Labour’s Jackie Baillie criticised Swinney’s anti‑austerity stance as insufficient and called for a long‑term budget with alternative tax policies.

Many people with severe disabilities and their carers face isolation because standard accessible toilets lack the space and equipment—such as benches and hoists—required for complex care, prompting campaigns to make Changing Places facilities compulsory in larger venues; currently 893 such toilets exist in the UK, yet they are only recommended (not mandated) in Building Standards (BS 8300:2009), leading activists like Lorna Fillingham, Alison Beevers and Bethan Folen to push for regulatory change, while architects note that compulsory rules would give clear expectations, and businesses cite logistical and financial challenges due to the larger size (12 m² versus 3.3 m²); nevertheless, examples such as Arsenal Football Club’s successful conversion of existing toilets into a Changing Places unit demonstrate positive public response and the feasibility of adaptation when supported by the Changing Places group.

Italian consumer organisations have lodged a formal antitrust complaint with the European Commission accusing McDonald’s of forcing its franchisees to pay above‑market rents, high fees and to sign unusually long contracts that block them from switching to competitors, thereby reducing consumer choice and raising prices in franchised outlets; McDonald’s responded that its model shares risk and reward with licencees and supports them, while the Service Employees International Union and European unions, including the UK’s Bakers Food and Allied Workers Union, have backed the complaint and urged an investigation, and the Commission said it will review the submission and may open a probe; franchisees operate 73 % of McDonald’s restaurants in Europe, and the company earned $9.27 bn (£6.40 bn) from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A poster bearing the hashtag #prayforjosh appeared in Holywood’s A2 playing fields after a mystery donor funded it, promoting a social‑media campaign for 13‑year‑old Joshua Martin of Donaghadee, County Down, who was diagnosed with cancer on Christmas Eve when doctors discovered a large primary tumor and five smaller growths during an intended appendix operation at Belfast’s Royal Victoria Hospital; the hashtag, created by Bangor Elim Church where his father serves, quickly went viral, with a Facebook update shared 948 times and viewed by over 79,000 people, drawing worldwide support and extensive Twitter activity from his classmates and others, while the church’s senior pastor Gary Beattie expressed amazement at the global outpouring of prayers and encouragement for Josh’s recovery.

The UK is reshaping its military estate, closing historic Brecon Barracks—home since 1805 to troops such as those at Rorke’s Drift—despite its 85 civilian and 90 military staff, with MP Chris Davies condemning the move as disrespectful to the town’s heritage, high unemployment, and thriving military tourism, and launching a petition while noting nearby Sennybridge training and Dering Lines infantry school will remain unaffected; Defence Secretary Sir Michael Fallon announced a new specialist light‑infantry centre at St Athans, while Cawdor Barracks in Pembrokeshire will close in 2024 and a Sennybridge storage depot in 2025, and Labour’s shadow defence secretary Nia Griffith acknowledged the restructuring but warned it will create “gnawing uncertainty” for many livelihoods.

The House of Lords EU Committee warns that, despite the fishing sector’s small economic weight (about 0.5 % of GDP and 12,000 workers), it must not be marginalised in Brexit talks, as the UK may have to permit EU‑registered vessels in its waters and retain elements of the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy—such as science‑based quotas and international cooperation—to preserve market access for the majority of UK fish, which are exported mainly to the EU, while also managing shared stocks; the report notes the risk of four separate fisheries regimes across England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland if the CFP framework collapses, but industry leaders remain optimistic, citing recent EU quota increases and the prospect of full control over the 200‑mile exclusive economic zone to achieve fairer catches and sustainable management, a view echoed by the government’s aim to maximise trade freedom while reviewing fisheries policy for fair access and environmental health.

Edward Snowden, a former CIA technical worker, disclosed that the NSA’s Prism program gives the agency massive access to individual chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers and social‑networking information, including “backdoor” entry to the servers of nine major tech firms—Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, PalTalk, AOL, Skype, YouTube and Apple—though the companies deny involvement and the program’s exact mechanics remain unclear; the U.S. government confirmed requests for millions of Verizon phone records and argues the surveillance is necessary for security, while officials such as Director Keith Alexander claim details cannot be shared lest terrorists evade detection, and others like President Obama and Senator Feinstein contend that monitoring is justified and limited to suspected threats; privacy experts question the scope of the access, noting it may be more targeted than a full backdoor, and point out that data‑protection laws vary internationally, with many services storing data in the U.S. and thus subject to the Patriot Act and FISA, allowing U.S. authorities to obtain foreign users’ cloud data with little transparency; the EU has expressed concern, the UK government has not confirmed GCHQ’s involvement, and privacy advocates warn that anyone using popular online services risks having their information accessed without recourse, reflecting Snowden’s motive of opposing a society where all actions are recorded.

The venture is backed by Elon Musk (Tesla and SpaceX), Peter Thiel, Infosys, and Amazon Web Services, and has pledged $1 billion—though only a small portion will be spent soon—to conduct research free from financial pressures aimed at a “positive human impact.” While scientists such as Musk and the late Stephen Hawking have warned that AI could become an existential threat by rapidly redesigning itself, other experts consider the danger remote. OpenAI’s statement emphasizes advancing digital intelligence to benefit humanity, keeping AI an extension of individual wills, widely and safely distributed, and unconstrained by the need for profit.

Ben Parkinson, a Doncaster resident who suffered a serious brain injury in a 2006 Afghanistan bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch on 26 June, walking for nearly half an hour with an assistant’s support; despite his injury having taken his speech, he now speaks unaided and remains witty and caring, spending 12 hours daily in the gym and rehab, raising money for military charities and serving as patron of the Pilgrim Bandits. Since the torch run, he has received thousands of Facebook friend requests—exceeding the platform’s 5,000‑friend limit—prompting his mother Diane to note over 19,000 hits on a single update, massive email traffic, and numerous invitations to appear with the torch, while Facebook suggested he switch to a public page or subscription model. A total of 8,000 people will carry the flame on its 8,000‑mile, 70‑day journey to the London Olympic Games opening ceremony on 27 July.

In 2011 the U.S. poverty rate held at 15% (46.2 million people) after three years of increases, while real median household income fell 1.5%; the average poverty line for a family of four was $23,021, income inequality rose 1.6% on the Gini index—the first annual increase since 1993—and the share of uninsured Americans dropped to 15.7% from 16.3%, following a record‑high poverty level of 15.1% in 2010.

The 25‑year‑old Jos Buttler, a short‑format specialist who moved from Somerset to Lancashire (the Red Rose) in 2013 and has a contract through 2019, has scored England’s three fastest ODI centuries—including a 46‑ball ton against Pakistan—and was credited by director Ashley Giles for his talent, impact in the T20 Blast final win, and positive influence in the dressing room; after playing for the Mumbai Indians in the IPL, he is set to return to Lancashire for a T20 Blast home match against Durham.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates—HMS Cumberland, HMS Campbeltown, HMS Chatham and HMS Cornwall—are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders having until 23 January to register interest; although no preservation proposals have been submitted, interested parties are finalising bids and viewings are slated for late February and March, with a decision expected in the spring. The government’s Disposal Services Authority, which is handling the sale, aims to award at least one ship to a UK recycler to test domestic capacity, while MP Penny Mordaunt urges that a frigate be saved from scrapping, preferably turned into a reef and diving attraction to generate tourism revenue and showcase UK recycling capability. The Ministry of Defence says it will consider all options to secure the best financial return for taxpayers, but a spokeswoman declined to comment on the number or nature of bids for commercial sensitivity. Originally designed as specialist anti‑submarine vessels, the Type 22s evolved into powerful surface combatants with anti‑surface, anti‑submarine and anti‑aircraft weapons, excellent command, control and communications facilities, and a crew of about 280; for context, the aircraft carrier HMS Ark Royal was sold for £3 million last year.

Since 1987 Fiji has been plagued by recurring racial and political crises, beginning with an indigenous Fijian coup that ousted an Indian‑led government and led to a contested constitution, followed by a 2000 coup in which businessman George Speight held the first ethnic Indian prime minister and his cabinet hostage, and culminating in a bloodless military takeover in 2006—the country’s fourth coup in two decades—resulting in international isolation, Commonwealth suspension in 2009, and eventual restoration of diplomatic ties after free elections were promised for 2014. The population, concentrated on Viti Levu and Vanua Levu, is split between indigenous Fijians (now a slight overall majority after many Indo‑Fijians emigrated) and Indo‑Fijians, with minimal intermixing and deep social segregation, alongside small Chinese and Rotuman minorities. Fiji’s economy relies heavily on sugar and tourism but also includes mining (gold, silver, limestone), services, and light manufacturing, yet persistent trade and budget deficits make it one of the world’s largest per‑capita aid recipients.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that Syria is “doing its best” to meet the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, though it missed Wednesday’s deadline to hand over the entire stockpile and a second shipment to the coast was reportedly intercepted by fire from “terrorist groups.” He condemned US Secretary of State John Kerry’s criticism of barrel‑bomb attacks in Aleppo, where the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights says 246 people, including 73 children, have been killed in the past five days, and the Aleppo Media Centre reports 14 deaths in a recent strike on the Masaken Hanano district. Mekdad denied that the government bombed civilian areas and accused the US of still supporting terrorists. Meanwhile, the Syrian government rejected reports that rebels seized most of Aleppo’s central prison, though the Observatory and rebel groups claim the Islamic Front coalition captured it, freeing hundreds of detainees. Syria’s declared chemical‑weapons stockpile is about 1,300 tonnes, with the US estimating only 30 tonnes (4 %) have left the country; the US and Russia have expressed concern over delays, and the OPCW acknowledged security issues have slowed the destruction process, while Mekdad affirmed Syria’s commitment to its OPCW and UN obligations, with a deadline to complete removal by 1 March and total destruction by the end of June.

The 46th Booker Prize, now open to any author writing in English, will announce its winner at London’s Guildhall on Tuesday night with the Duchess of Cornwall presenting the award on BBC; the shortlist—judged by AC Grayling, Sarah Churchwell, Jonathan Bate, Daniel Glaser, Alastair Niven and Erica Wagner—features Mukherjee’s politically charged “The Lives Of Others” (5/2 favourite), Howard Jacobson’s futuristic love story “J”, Ali Smith’s dual‑timeline “How To Be Both”, Joshua Ferris’s “To Rise Again at a Decent Hour”, Karen Joy Fowler’s best‑selling “We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves” (over 55,000 copies sold), and Richard Flanagan’s World‑War‑Two love story “The Narrow Road to the Deep North”; sales spiked after the final‑six announcement, with Mukherjee’s book jumping from 97 to 507 weekly copies, and each shortlisted author receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition, while critics debate the prize’s focus on literary merit versus readability.

He is appealing a Court of Appeal decision that lifted a ban on naming him in the media in England and Wales; the Supreme Court will now hear arguments on whether to allow or dismiss the appeal, with an interim injunction remaining in force until the hearing concludes. The Sun on Sunday seeks to publish details of alleged extra‑marital activities involving the celebrity (referred to as PJS), his partner AB and AB’s partner CD, including a three‑way encounter, but PJS claims a right to privacy. Earlier, a High Court judge refused an injunction, but PJS won on appeal, preventing his identification. News Group Newspapers asked the Court of Appeal to lift the ban, arguing the story had already spread in the US, Scotland and online; the judges ruled the ban should stay but noted that the information was now so widespread that confidentiality was likely lost, making a permanent injunction unlikely.

Fosse Park, opened in 1989 near junction 21 of the M1, was purchased in August for £345.5 million, and new owners are preparing plans to improve parking, traffic congestion and the appearance of its units; council leader Ernie White noted meetings to resolve planning questions and emphasized the park’s role as a gateway to the city, while Crown Estates director Paul Clarke highlighted concerns about parking, congestion, the park’s aging condition and the quality of common areas, walking routes and facilities.

The live‑action remake of “Beauty and the Beast” was delayed in Malaysia after Disney announced a “gay moment” involving LeFou’s feelings for Gaston, prompting the Malaysian Censorship Board (LPF) to place the film under review; the board later approved it with a minor edit, granting a P13 parental guidance rating but noting it does not control screening dates or venues, while the country’s tourism minister called a ban “ridiculous” and local cinemas began offering refunds, and netizens criticized the decision as “stupid and laughable.”

Landlords letting properties to more than three unrelated people must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) licence, which can cost around £1,000, but failure can result in fines up to £20,000; Southampton City Council estimates about 1,500 unlicensed HMOs locally, with tenants frequently fearing eviction and poor maintenance, especially amid a severe shortage of affordable homes. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to houses of three storeys or more housing five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, the licensing regime covers properties in Bargate, Bevois, Portswood, and Swaythling (Designation 1, introduced 2013) and in Shirley Freemantle, Millbrook, and Bassett (Designation 2, introduced 2015). While most landlords have complied, a small minority have resisted, leading the council to prosecute one firm and 13 individuals so far.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny (Fine Gael) and Micheál Martin (Fianna Fáil) are seeking to avoid a second election, with Martin saying his party will enable a minority government but will not back a programme for government; the principal obstacle is water charges, prompting proposals such as a commission to review Irish Water, while Fianna Fáil demands their immediate removal and Fine Gael favours retaining them, and after the recent election the seat distribution was Fine Gael 50, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23 and Labour 7, leaving no party with a majority and TDs still unable to elect a Taoiseach.

The Sorrento ferry, owned by Italy’s Atlantica di Navigazione, caught fire on a car deck while 27 km off Mallorca en route to Valencia, prompting a full evacuation; passengers and crew were transferred to lifeboats and rescued by the ferry Puglia, with three injured individuals air‑lifted to hospital, one seriously, and psychologists dispatched to the Palma de Mallorca port where survivors were expected to arrive within hours, while authorities warned the damaged vessel could sink at its current location.

The Electoral Commission reported that 38 MPs have raised concerns about alleged double voting, a criminal offence, and called for better integration of council‑run electoral registers to detect duplicate entries; a record 46.8 million people were registered for the 8 June election—500,000 more than in 2015—and 68.7 % voted, the highest turnout since 1997, after a surge of 2.9 million registration applications in the six weeks following the snap poll announcement, with some constituencies seeing electorate growth of over 10 %. However, the lack of a direct link between the 381 local registers and the online registration system has led to a high proportion of duplicate applications—estimated at 30‑70 %—resulting in significant administrative and financial burdens, prompting the watchdog to recommend clearer information and a verification function similar to those used in Australia, New Zealand and Ireland. While voting twice in a general election is punishable by an unlimited fine, the commission noted that some people (e.g., students or those with second homes) may lawfully register in two constituencies and urged them to choose one in advance; Labour’s Cat Smith warned against a blanket ban that could disenfranchise young voters, emphasizing the need for police resources to prosecute genuine offences without making registration harder for students.

Lawrence Phillips, a former University of Nebraska star who played for the St Louis Rams, Miami Dolphins and San Francisco 49ers until 1999, is believed to have killed himself early Wednesday at age 40; after a troubled NFL career he faced multiple legal problems, including convictions for assault after driving his car into teenagers and attacking a former girlfriend, and was serving a more‑than‑30‑year sentence when he was placed in a solitary cell following accusations of killing his cellmate, with a judge later finding sufficient evidence to try him for the death of inmate Damion Soward, while the exact method of his suicide remains unclear.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram officially classified as a soldier, was promoted to lance corporal at a Chester ceremony marking eight years of the Mercian Regiment, receiving the honour from Brigadier Andrew Williams for “good behaviour.” He is the 30th mascot ram in a line dating back to the Indian Mutiny in the mid‑19th century; the first Private Derby was acquired in 1858 by the 95th (Derbyshire) Regiment of Foot and became the Mercian Regiment’s mascot when the regiment formed in 2007. Derby joined the regiment in February 2014, has his own army number, is paid for his rations and takes holidays during the mating season on the Chatsworth Estate in Derbyshire. His duties have included switching on the Christmas lights in Ashbourne and meeting Prince William at the unveiling of a memorial to the 1914 Christmas Truce.

Liverpool staged a dramatic 4‑3 Europa League comeback win over Borussia Dortmund at Anfield, with Dejan Lovren’s injury‑time header sealing the victory and moving the Reds closer to Champions League qualification; the match featured an electrifying atmosphere, a minute’s silence for the Hillsborough disaster, and a shift from early doubt—after Dortmund’s early two‑goal lead through Henrikh Mkhitaryan and Pierre‑Emerick Aubameyang—to belief inspired by Jürgen Klopp’s passionate touchline leadership, culminating in goals from Divock Origi, Philippe Coutinho, Mamadou Sakho and Lovren; the article highlights Klopp’s mantra of turning doubters into believers, the contributions and emerging stature of players like Origi and the mixed form of Emre Can, lingering defensive frailties at left‑back, and the broader significance of the win as a potential springboard toward a Champions League return and further European success.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK Minister Mr Davis pledged to keep Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland informed about Brexit talks, proposing monthly “two‑way information flow” meetings to let devolved administrations voice their views as Westminster shapes its negotiating strategy and works toward the best deal for the whole UK. He described the meeting as constructive and affirmed ongoing cooperation with the three nations. Scottish Minister Mr Russell welcomed the involvement of the Scottish government but criticised the lack of clear UK strategic intentions more than four months after the referendum, especially regarding whether the UK will remain in the single market or customs union, calling single‑market membership essential for Scotland’s prosperity and demanding greater transparency. He noted that the UK hopes a High Court judgment on triggering Article 50 will be overturned on appeal to the Supreme Court, while Scotland intends to oppose the UK government in that appeal, with Lord Advocate James Wolffe seeking to be heard in the case.

Veterinary surgeon Dr Sandra Corr is examining Daisy, one of 13 cloned sheep at the University of Nottingham’s Sutton Bonington farm, including four clones (Debbie, Denise, Diane and Daisy) that share the same adult ewe as Dolly, the first cloned mammal; the study, led by Prof Kevin Sinclair, aims to determine whether cloning causes premature aging by assessing co‑morbidities such as cardiovascular disease, diabetes and osteoarthritis through joint X‑rays, full‑body fMRI scans and other health checks, since Dolly died at six and a half years with osteoarthritis and a lung virus, raising concerns that “age‑memory” from adult donor cells might accelerate senescence; the nine additional clones come from different cell lines, and while the results—due next week—could impact the future of cloning, the current findings show the clones, now approaching nine to ten years old, appear to be in good health.

Trainer John Gosden walked the course before letting his unbeaten 4‑7 favourite race, where she beat Vintage Folly by a length and three‑quarters and will head to Chantilly rather than the Epsom Oaks, while stablemates Enable and Coronet remain top contenders for the longer classic; Tasleet (14‑1) captured the Duke of York Stakes for William Haggas with Jim Crowley riding, finishing ahead of Magical Memory and Comicas; Shutter Speed, who previously beat Enable at Newbury, secured Gosden and Dettori’s fifth Musidora win, with Dettori praising her class despite the very soft ground and noting she’ll improve on firmer going; Gosden is monitoring the ground for his colt Cracksman ahead of Thursday’s Dante Stakes and will walk the course before deciding on a Derby trial, acknowledging the tight 16‑day gap to the Derby may keep Cracksman out of the Dante, and he is pleased to have a month to prepare Shutter Speed for the French Oaks at Chantilly.

The pound slipped against the dollar and euro before a brief mid‑afternoon recovery and then fell again, ending the day down 0.2% at $1.4226, 0.6% at €1.2605 and 1% against the yen, while the volatility index reached 2008‑crisis levels as data suggested a lower chance of a Remain vote and global economic worries added pressure; polls with ten days left showed the Leave camp ahead and Betfair’s implied Remain probability dropped to 68.5%, prompting analysts to expect more aggressive pound moves and heightened volatility, hedge funds to short sterling, and markets to react nervously, with the FTSE 100 ending 1.1% lower at 6,044.9, Lloyds down 4.2%, and Asian indices falling sharply, even as Leave leader Nigel Farage claimed the pound had been strengthening since March and that a weaker pound benefits exporters, noting a recent narrowing of the UK trade deficit due to a jump in exports.

The Iron sit sixth in the National League, just one point and one position shy of the play‑off places, after a loss to Barrow, who stretched their unbeaten league run to nine games; Braintree’s losing streak grew to three, yet manager Cowley remained upbeat, praising the team’s remarkable progress, acknowledging the difficulty of their toughest challenge as a part‑time side, and saying they will embrace and enjoy the journey ahead.

From April 2015, responsibility for most planning decisions in Northern Ireland will move from the Stormont Planning Service to local councils, allowing elected politicians to accept or reject developments in their areas; supporters like Michael Corr of the architecture centre PLACE view this as a democratic opportunity for councils to shape community and regeneration plans, while critics—including Friends of the Earth and those recalling 1960‑s housing discrimination—warn that without strict codes of conduct and transparency about political donations, the shift could revive biased favouritism, close developer‑party ties, and unfair planning outcomes.

A one‑year‑old cat named Teenie was found on 14 March in NiddryView, Winchburgh, after being shot three times—twice in the shoulder and once through the left back leg, which had to be amputated—by an air gun powerful enough to pierce the leg; her owner Sarah Nisbett reported the cat is relearning to walk and expressed concern for other children in the housing estate, while Scottish SPCA Superintendent Mike Flynn called the incident alarming and urged urgent implementation of a licensing regime for air guns, noting that a recent Scottish government consultation on such licensing saw 87 % of respondents reject the proposal as “draconian” or “heavy‑handed,” though a few argued the measures were insufficient, and the SPCA appealed for information about the perpetrator.

Christian Benteke became Liverpool’s second‑most‑expensive signing on a long‑term deal after the club triggered his release clause, joining as their seventh summer acquisition following the £49 million sale of Raheem Sterling and a season in which Liverpool struggled for goals after Luis Suárez’s departure. The 24‑year‑old Belgian forward, who scored 49 goals in 101 Premier League games for Aston Villa and returned from an Achilles injury to net 15 and help Villa stay up, said he is happy to be at Liverpool and aims to win trophies, while manager Brendan Rodgers added him to revive the attack alongside other new forwards Danny Ings, Roberto Firmino and the returning Divock Origi. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert praised Benteke as a “brilliant number nine” who will thrive with service, and ex‑Liverpool striker John Aldridge highlighted his physical presence and optimism for a stronger forward line after a low‑scoring previous season.

The study, commissioned by Tablets for Schools and led by Barbie Clarke, found no clear evidence that tablet use improves academic results, though head teachers report positive impacts such as increased motivation and family involvement; tablets are used in 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools, with 9% of schools providing an individual device for every pupil and the highest usage in academy schools, and the number of tablets is expected to rise from about 430,000 to nearly 900,000 between 2014 and 2016; researchers cannot isolate technology’s effect on attainment, but note that tablets help engage disengaged pupils and that taking devices home boosts family involvement, while a separate National Literacy Trust and Pearson study showed touch‑screen computers aid boys and poorer pupils in learning to read; the research also highlighted extensive personal use, with a quarter of secondary pupils in fully tablet‑equipped schools describing themselves as internet “addicts,” about two‑thirds taking devices to bed for social media or videos, and roughly 70% of 5‑ to 15‑year‑olds having tablet access at home; headteacher Simon Mason of Honywood Community School advocates tablets for their portability, empowerment value, and alignment with modern life, even though their benefits are hard to capture in league tables.

The Museum of Liverpool’s exhibition “Growing Up in the City” showcases 25 photographs that span from the 1880s to the 1990s, offering a visual social history of Liverpool childhoods—including both joyful street play and the reality of child labor—through images such as an 1887 portrait of the Rollo children at a mayoral fancy‑dress ball and a circa‑1900 portrait of a nervous young maid; the display was curated by Kay Jones, Curator of Urban Community History, who selected the works from the National Museums Liverpool collections, and it runs at the museum until 25 September.

Anderson, a 27‑year‑old centre‑back who previously played for Aldershot, Exeter and in Italy, has terminated his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join a National League rival and could face his former club on 18 February; meanwhile 21‑year‑old striker Keating, recommended to Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson by former Port Vale boss Micky Adams and previously with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, is awaiting international clearance, while Nicholson praised centre‑back Myles for his stature and leadership and described young forward Ruairi as raw but eager, as the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone after winning only one of their last six games.

Bolivia’s new law, signed by Vice‑President Álvaro García Linera while President Evo Morales was abroad, permits 12‑year‑olds to be employed with parental consent, imposes harsher penalties—including a 30‑year jail term for child homicide—and aims to balance national realities with rights and international treaties; the measure responds to the fact that over 500,000 Bolivian children work to support families, often in informal jobs or harsh conditions, and is intended to help eradicate extreme poverty, though the International Labour Organisation, which recommends a minimum working age of 14 for developing nations, is reviewing the legislation for compliance with global child‑labour standards.

A 50‑year‑old actress, O'Donnell, experienced a “widow‑maker” heart attack after feeling chest pain, nausea and feverishness while helping a woman out of a car; she searched “women’s heart attack symptoms” online, took aspirin, and saw a cardiologist the next day who placed a stent in an artery that was 99 % blocked. In a blog post titled “my heart attack,” she warned women to recognize symptoms and call 911, noting she had not called emergency services herself. O'Donnell, known for roles in *Drop Dead Diva*, *Will & Grace* and *Nip/Tuck*, recently hosted *The Rosie Show* on the Oprah Winfrey Network, which was cancelled in March due to low ratings.

Che Labastide‑Wellington, a 16‑year‑old from Harrow, was attending a well‑run party on Belvedere Way in Kenton when a group of youths denied entry fought with attendees; although he was not involved in that early altercation, he was later targeted and stabbed in an alley between Belvedere Way and Tylers Gate at about 00:30 GMT and died roughly an hour later, while another 16‑year‑old was also stabbed and remains in stable condition in a north London hospital; police are seeking anyone near the alley at the time and have arrested a 21‑year‑old on suspicion of murder, two boys aged 15 and 16 also on suspicion of murder (bail until mid‑December), and a 14‑year‑old on suspicion of possessing an offensive weapon.

A team of Welsh cancer specialists, GPs and public‑health experts visited Aarhus, Denmark, after learning that long waiting times for patients with vague or non‑obvious cancer symptoms had contributed to poor survival rates; Denmark responded by introducing a three‑route model of care—fast‑track pathways for “alarm” symptoms with strict time targets and a legal 30‑day investigation rule, diagnosis centres that quickly provide tests and scans for cases GPs cannot readily identify, and “yes‑no” centres for minor symptoms that offer rapid simple testing—thereby reducing diagnostic delays, preventing “ping‑pong” referrals, and improving survival without overwhelming the system, results that suggest valuable lessons for Wales.

The UK government has disbanded the Office of Fair Trading and awarded Powys the contract to enforce estate‑agent regulations, providing the council with £170,000 annually to issue warnings and banning orders against dishonest agents and to investigate breaches of the Estate Agents Act; complaints will still be made to local authority trading standards, which will refer relevant cases to Powys, and James Munro, leading the new team, said the role could help Powys secure additional contracts, a point he discussed on Radio Wales.

NHS Employers approved a plan, after advisers suggested that additional training could enable staff to take on extra tasks, and a Nuffield Trust review highlighted examples such as nurses covering for hospital doctors and pharmacists for GPs; however, unions cautioned that this should not become a quick, cheap fix for chronic staffing shortages. The review, commissioned to explore reshaping the NHS’s 1.3 million‑strong workforce amid documented gaps in junior‑doctor rotas and growing GP pressures, identified existing experiments and argued that, as doctors comprise only about one‑tenth of the workforce, more support from other health staff is needed—though funding must be set aside for training. Report author Candace Imison and NHS Employers chief Danny Mortimer see “huge opportunities” to improve patient care and create more rewarding roles, while the BMA’s Mark Porter warned that expanding staff skills must not compromise doctors’ long‑term training, and Unison’s Christina McAnea stressed that limited funding often leaves no money for training courses.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road at Rackfield Place in Bath after a crash at 03:00 GMT, shutting the A36 until 14:00 GMT and causing commuter and bus delays, while investigations into the collision continue; First reported that some services have resumed and expects a full schedule by the evening commute, thanking the public for their support and staff for their efforts.

NRW estimates that the Swansea tidal lagoon could cause the annual death of 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout during migration, a claim Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) rejects as lacking scientific basis and argues that the regulator has not shared its methodology; TLP’s own modelling predicts a worst‑case impact of only 2% of all fish species, while NRW maintains confidence in its evidence, which has been reviewed by independent and internal experts, and both parties dispute each other’s figures as the £1.3 bn project, seen as a test bed for larger schemes, awaits a UK government review of its viability, with Wales’ Environment Secretary expressing support but calling for clear government guidance soon.

Stormont’s Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the creation of a new industry‑led agri‑food marketing body, to be developed by the Agri‑Food Strategy Board and modelled on Scotland Food and Drink, aiming to provide strategic leadership for government and private sector marketing in a sector that supports almost 100,000 jobs across farming, fishing, retail and distribution; Agriculture Minister Michelle O’Neill welcomed the move as a positive step for export‑led growth and better coordination of marketing activities, while noting it could affect other organisations, including her department, and said she would discuss the plans with the AFSB.

On Saturday afternoon the Woodland Trust is inviting the public to help plant 40,000 native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, a site about seven miles outside Derry, as part of a four‑year, UK‑wide programme to create four new woods and plant “millions” of trees in memory of the millions who died in World War I; the Brackfield project specifically honors the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives, with volunteers provided saplings and advised to wear sturdy footwear, while the site will also feature wildflower carpets, including poppies, and become a space for wildlife, walking, relaxation and reflection.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award in Harrogate, with judges praising her thriller Someone Else’s Skin for its emotional power, tight writing and atmospheric handling of domestic‑violence and honour‑crime themes as the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome; US author Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honour for her 23‑year career creating the groundbreaking female private‑investigator VI Warshawski, a character celebrated for changing readers’ views of female protagonists and for founding the Sisters In Crime organisation, while festival programming chair Ann Cleeves highlighted the strong shortlist and the award ceremony’s place at the start of the town’s annual crime‑writing festival.

Santner, a 24‑year‑old left‑arm batting spinner who debuted in Tests in 2015, broke his finger in his second county game for Worcestershire in 2016, prompting director Steve Rhodes to note unfinished business after the loss of Mitch hurt the team’s qualifying hopes; Santner plans to rejoin the Rapids after the June ICC Trophy in England, hoping to make up for lost time, while Worcestershire bolstered their 2017 squad by signing Australian fast bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player across all formats.

Barry Pring, 47, was killed in 2008 on a Kiev dual carriageway when a speeding, unlit car struck him as he tried to hail a taxi; the Exeter coroner, Dr Elizabeth Earland, recorded an unlawful killing verdict, noting the difficulty of investigating a death abroad and expressing condolences to the family, while police testimony described the incident as a deliberate act by a vehicle traveling 75 mph with stolen plates that did not brake. His wife, Ganna “Anna” Ziuzina, 19 years his junior, quickly sought to claim his assets, sold his Range Rover, moved funds from his accounts, and was alleged by his mother and a close friend to have been involved in a staged hit‑and‑run to inherit his wealth, with evidence of an affair and false claims about her occupation; despite repeated attempts, she did not attend the inquest, stating she had already given statements to Ukrainian police. Ukrainian authorities closed the original inquiry but reopened it as a murder investigation in 2011; the case remains active but is not being actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns’ son Charlie, a Merseyside child who has been ill since age three, must travel to Seattle Children’s Hospital for experimental T‑Cell therapy after his third relapse and a failed transplant left no treatment options in the UK; an anonymous donor has paid for the costly procedure, prompting overwhelming gratitude from his parents, who received confirmation of the funding via email and are awaiting the treatment start date now that the hospital has granted financial clearance.

Third‑party software such as Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker was used to steal iCloud photos of celebrities, prompting Apple to tighten its security by expanding two‑factor authentication (2FA) to protect iCloud backups; the opt‑in system now requires a four‑digit code sent to a trusted device after entering a username and password on a new device, blocks access and purchases if the code isn’t entered, and offers a 14‑character recovery key for account recovery, while also emailing users when a backup download starts. Experts argue the 2FA should be enabled by default, noting that the recovery key can be lost or stolen and that relying on passwords alone is insecure, and Apple’s Tim Cook says the company will more aggressively encourage 2FA and stronger passwords and raise user awareness.

Dan Groves noted that details of a possible deal in which Wright could purchase a 20% stake and become a director of Billericay Town have not yet been released; the club, now eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points off the play‑offs, was recently taken over by multi‑millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who said he is comfortable spending £10,000 a week, and has signed former England international Paul Konchesky, while Wright—known from “I’m a Celebrity…Get Me Out of Here” and a former non‑league player for clubs such as Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds—may soon join the club’s ownership.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence on his workers’ treatment following a BBC investigation into the Derbyshire company’s warehouse practices, and must reply by 21 March to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee; the letter notes that Ashley invited the committee to meet at the company’s Shirebrook base to discuss low‑paid workers and minimum‑wage enforcement, that the committee normally meets publicly at Westminster but agreed to this location, that several alternative dates were offered but none accepted, and warns that failure to attend could lead to a contempt complaint, while Sports Direct has not commented and the firm has previously pledged a review of worker rights under Ashley’s oversight, who also owns Newcastle United Football Club.

The passage describes how Ilya Yashin and other colleagues of the murdered opposition politician Boris Nemtsov completed a Russian‑language report titled “Putin. War,” which compiles publicly known facts from 2014 onward to argue that President Vladimir Putin is personally waging war in Ukraine for his own ends; it asserts that Russian soldiers and equipment, not just “volunteer” separatists, were decisive in major victories in Donetsk and Luhansk, that volunteers acknowledge direction by Russian generals and receive salaries of $2,000‑3,000 a month, and that Russia has spent about 53 billion roubles on the conflict, while also documenting unit names and weaponry despite verification challenges; the report, initially limited to 2,000 copies and seeking donations amid publisher reluctance, aims to expose what the opposition sees as Putin’s manipulation of the war to boost his waning popularity, a narrative that may face the same suppression as Nemtsov’s earlier anti‑corruption publications.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34‑year‑old from Wath‑Upon‑Dearn, was found dead at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday, with a post‑mortem confirming death from head injuries, and a 41‑year‑old man and a 23‑year‑old woman were arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and remain in custody.

Carwyn Jones criticised the UK government for not showing him the Article 50 letter before its release, saying the devolved administrations had been treated with disrespect despite common ground on free‑trade issues, while Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns defended the process, noting the prime minister’s recent visits to Wales and the government’s aim to act for the whole UK and include Wales in the letter; May pledged full consultation on which powers would remain at Westminster versus be devolved to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, promising a significant increase in devolved decision‑making but without specifying which powers or accompanying funding, prompting Jones to warn that no money may follow the powers after 2020, a concern partly tied to Labour’s pledge to maintain EU regional aid, while some Whitehall officials argue that past EU spending in Wales justifies returning powers to Westminster, though this is politically unlikely, and further details may emerge in a forthcoming Great Repeal Bill white paper, leaving the exact powers to be devolved still unclear.

Two cars were damaged during a Friday‑night incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry, prompting Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin to say he was “appalled by mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community,” while a PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook post noted that police were “carrying out duties” when attacked and appealed to parents to know where their children are and what they are doing.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was removed from his position last year after employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds, and the board stated it does not expect him to return; while his lawyer claims many allegations are false and accuses the company of privacy invasion, court filings reveal illicit emails to female employees, racially derogatory remarks, and repeated violations of the firm’s sexual‑harassment and anti‑discrimination policies, leading the board to argue that hiring him would pose excessive risk to shareholders, and a recent restraining order bars him from making negative press statements or attempting to remove board members.

The match will be streamed on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app, with GB facing Greece at the Copper Box in London; Greece, who beat GB 92‑64 in Patras earlier this month, will be missing three players, giving GB a chance for revenge, and guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing at his hometown venue as preparation for EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September after a qualifying group in Istanbul and a final warm‑up tournament in Poland.

The passage recounts a journalist’s experience covering the 2007 unveiling of the iPhone by Steve Jobs, describing how he obtained the device from Apple’s marketing chief Phil Schiller, showcased it on the BBC, and faced criticism for giving the product prominence; he later reflected on the iPhone’s revolutionary impact, likening it to the Model T’s effect on society, noting how smartphones have placed powerful computers in the hands of over two billion people, transformed photography and other activities, and paved the way for further innovations from companies like Amazon and Google, marking the start of the mobile‑connected era on a sunny January morning in San Francisco.

Tests confirmed that all cats near Victor Avenue in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, ingested antifreeze, resulting in multiple deaths—including seven‑month‑old Meereen, who died three days after showing symptoms, three other cats in the past week, and another two weeks earlier. An RSPCA spokesman said it is unclear whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate, and inspector Andy Bostock urged residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, especially to check for antifreeze leaks and clean up spills promptly.

Despite looming VAT hikes, pension cuts, reduced farm subsidies, privatisations and market opening, Greeks are not protesting as the Syriza government prepares to accept a third €86 billion bailout from the eurozone and possibly the IMF, a move that contradicts its earlier anti‑austerity stance but is justified by the July banking closures and economic collapse that left the country with no viable alternative. Tourism is booming, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals, yet the economy remains strained by partial bank closures that limit credit, threatening retail orders and deepening poverty. Although Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras remains popular, his concessionary approach has turned Greece into a “protectorate” of Brussels, Frankfurt and Washington, and the bailout’s success will depend on creditors, especially Berlin, providing substantial debt relief rather than merely imposing further austerity.

Ross Kemp, who last played Grant Mitchell in 2006, confirmed a brief return to EastEnders for Barbara “Peggy” Mitchell’s final episodes, after being approached to film her character’s death from cancer; Peggy reappears to tell her son Phil that her illness has returned and will die in emotional spring scenes, prompting Grant’s return to reunite the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time, a storyline highlighted by executive producer Dominic Treadwell‑Collins as an opportunity to showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best, while noting Grant’s long‑standing role in the soap since 1990 and his past family dramas.

Lance Corporal Trimaan “Harry” Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24‑year‑old Alice Ruggles in October, leading her parents Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles to recall the moment Northumbria Police informed them of her death and their immediate recognition of Dhillon as the perpetrator; the Newcastle Crown Court heard that Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice, while her mother’s attempts to reassure her daughter and dismiss her sister’s warnings later left her feeling guilty, and her father noted that none of them realized the seriousness of the situation despite warning signs. In response, the parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness of stalking dangers and to remember their daughter’s vibrant personality, and Dhillon, who denied murder, was found guilty and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

French firm EDF approved financing for the £18 billion Hinkley Point C nuclear plant at a board meeting, with contracts slated for Friday, but Business Secretary Greg Clark said the government will “consider carefully” before backing it, prompting EDF chief Vincent de Rivaz to cancel a site visit. The project, expected to supply about 7 % of the UK’s electricity, is funded one‑third by Chinese investors and has faced criticism over environmental impact, rising costs and foreign involvement, while EDF’s financial capacity has been questioned, leading to a €4 billion share issue, the resignation of board member Gérard Magnin and former finance director Thomas Piquemal. Industry leaders such as Tom Greatrex and Claire Jacobson urge a swift government decision to avoid energy supply risks and higher emissions, whereas Greenpeace argues the plant offers poor value and calls for more renewable investment. After EDF’s approval, the government launched a further review, raising doubts about post‑Brexit investment momentum and the future policy direction for the two‑administration‑old project.

The newly‑designed divorce form for England and Wales now includes a field asking for “the name of the person your spouse has committed adultery with,” though the Ministry of Justice stresses there is no obligation to provide it and the guidance notes it is “not normally necessary”; family lawyers warn that naming a third party adds conflict and complexity, can make that person a party to the case, potentially delay proceedings and increase costs, and judges view such attempts unfavourably, even though many clients want to involve the new partner, while statistics show that of the just‑over 100,000 divorces granted in 2015, 12,148 were on the ground of adultery and 46,815 on “unreasonable behaviour,” and applicants must still prove the marriage has broken down by citing an accepted reason.
