The passage outlines a tension in Wales between government emphasis on environmental goals—such as increasing native broadleaf trees and improving public access—and the commercial timber sector, which argues that this focus undermines a valuable industry worth over £450 million annually and has already seen the loss of about 16,000 ha of commercial forest since 2001 that needs replanting; while half of Wales’s woodland is managed by Natural Resources Wales and half by private firms, the Welsh government seeks a balanced approach through initiatives like the Glastir scheme and the Woodlands for Wales strategy, yet industry representatives like Martin Bishop of Confor criticize the current system as overly bureaucratic and “sexier” on environmental aspects, noting that only 90 ha were planted last year against a target of 20,000 ha per year despite a strong market demand that could double or triple saw‑mill production if sufficient timber were available.

Police reported that a boy was seriously injured after being struck in Coatbridge; emergency crews responded around 16:40 at Bank Street near Langloan Primary School, and the boy was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow, where his condition is believed to be serious.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Russian Ushakov medals to surviving Arctic Convoy veterans, including 91‑year‑old Able Seaman Charles Lewis, after the Foreign Office granted an exception to its rule barring foreign awards for actions over five years old; the ceremony, enabled by a 2013 exception and marked by President Vladimir Putin’s presentation in London, recognized the WWII convoys that sailed from Britain to northern Russia under constant threat from German U‑boats, aircraft, severe weather and ice, delivering weapons and ammunition that helped the Soviet Union defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front, a campaign that claimed over 120 vessels and thousands of Allied lives, prompting the UK to create its own Arctic Star in 2012 while campaigners continued to seek acknowledgment of the Russian accolade.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation reported that many offenders experience long delays before starting their community‑payback sentences and are often released without penalty for non‑attendance, exemplified by a case where an offender completed only 16 hours in 17 months; the scheme, which can require 40–300 hours of unpaid work for offences such as shoplifting, theft, drug offences or criminal damage, involved about 70,000 participants in 2014, and the inspection of 100 cases and 86 interviews produced 15 recommendations, noting historic attempts to improve the programme—such as the 10,000 orange bibs ordered under Gordon Brown and the 2010 coalition’s push for more physical, rapid work—while highlighting persistent organisational challenges in getting chaotic, often substance‑dependent offenders to attend, the mixed quality of delivery (with some high‑quality work and positive offender attitudes) and the need to stop treating unpaid work merely as punishment; chief inspector Paul Wilson called the current approach a “wasted opportunity” and urged urgent remedial action, and the Ministry of Justice said it accepts all recommendations and is already moving to ensure timely attendance and stronger enforcement.

The Sun ran a front‑page story labeling comedian Russell Brand a “hypocrite” for championing economic and political revolution for the poor while living in a spacious, luxury London home, a charge he has faced repeatedly; when a Channel 4 News reporter asked him about his rent during a protest outside Downing Street, Brand called the journalist “snide” and walked off, later tweeting about the accusation with the hashtag #TheSunLogic but not confirming any legal action, and he has previously acknowledged his wealth and fame, saying he must change personally, share his wealth, and pursue systemic change despite being criticized for hypocrisy.

J. Craig Venter, a biologist‑entrepreneur born in 1946, transformed the human‑genome project into a competitive race, founding Celera Genomics in 1998 and publishing the human genome alongside the public effort in 2001, actions that earned him both criticism for bypassing open‑access norms and wealth that freed him from traditional funding; after leaving the NIH in 1992 he created the Institute for Genomic Research, sequenced the first free‑living organism’s genome (Haemophilus influenzae) in 1995, and later established the J. Craig Venter Institute, which for over a decade pursued synthetic biology, culminating in the creation of the synthetic organism “Synthia” reported in Science, while also conducting the oceanic “Sorcerer II” expedition to sequence marine microbes, all driven by a Vietnam‑inspired sense of urgency and a vision that synthetic microbes could spark a new industrial revolution by producing useful chemicals, reducing oil dependence, and capturing carbon dioxide.

Researchers found that four out of five English children who ate school lunches tried foods there that they had not tried at home, and half of the surveyed parents said their children asked for those school foods to be cooked at home; a survey of about 1,000 parents (628 of whom had children eating school lunches) identified carrots, sweetcorn and peas as the most popular vegetables and aubergine, chickpeas and spinach as the least popular, and was commissioned by England’s School Food Trust after a Mumsnet poll suggested some parents resorted to packed lunches because their children were perceived as fussy; Trust chairman Rob Rees and Mumsnet co‑founder Carrie Longton highlighted school meals as a way to encourage variety and healthier eating amid peer pressure, noting that meals now must meet strict nutritional guidelines, with roughly four‑in‑ten primary pupils (slightly more than secondary pupils) and about 46 % of Scottish pupils eating school lunches; the online survey was conducted between 26 February and 5 March among parents of children aged 4–17.

Alvaro Morata, a 23‑year‑old 6 ft 3 in striker representing Spain at Euro 2016, moved from Real Madrid to Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with the Spanish club, with a buy‑back clause allowing Real to repurchase him for up to €30 million; during his two years in Italy he netted 27 goals, helped Juventus win two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias, and featured in consecutive Champions League finals—coming off the bench in Real’s 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus’ 3‑1 loss to Barcelona in 2015—while previously being linked with Arsenal and Chelsea, he had already scored three goals for Spain in France and ten league goals for Real, having debuted for the Madrid first team at 18.

Wilson, a 30‑year‑old who rejoined Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5 million in August 2013, made 51 appearances during his second spell at the City Ground after previously spending four seasons at the club before moving to Celtic, and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County; he was released in May and is currently without a team.

Tesco, the world’s third‑largest retailer, is exiting the U.S. market by selling its loss‑making Fresh & Easy chain, which has operated 200 stores in California, Nevada and Arizona since 2007 and has been unprofitable; about 4,000 of Fresh & Easy’s 5,000 employees will move to the new business run by Los Angeles‑based private‑equity firm Yucaipa, which will receive a roughly £80 million loan from Tesco, while the remaining 50 stores are expected to close, costing Tesco about £150 million to dispose of the brand (part of which is the loan that may be repaid) and giving Tesco an option to acquire a stake if Yucaipa makes the business profitable; the move follows Tesco’s report in April of its first annual profit decline in 20 years.

The passage notes that media playback is not supported on the device, describes an athlete who initially faced racial abuse but told BBC Sport’s Nick Hope how he overcame it, briefly considered representing France, and is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics, and it also points readers to a special guide on how to get into martial arts.

The French Alps’ glacier inventory, compiled by Marie Gardent and colleagues using map archives, satellite imagery, aerial photos and manual verification, shows that the ice‑covered area fell from about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to roughly 275 sq km by the late 2000s—a 26 % loss over 40 years—mirroring accelerated retreat reported elsewhere in the Alps; the decline is uneven, with the southern massifs (e.g., Belledonne, where glaciers have nearly vanished, and the Ecrins, retreating three times faster than the Mont Blanc Massif) losing more ice than the northern sector, which benefits from higher elevations, greater precipitation and cloud cover, as illustrated by La Mer de Glace shrinking only from 31.5 sq km to just over 30 sq km.

Scotland’s women have won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, a match that could virtually guarantee their place in next summer’s Netherlands finals if they prevail, with the return leg in Reykjavik also crucial for topping the group; both teams are unbeaten, Iceland sitting one spot higher at world rank 20, while Scotland aim to avoid the heartbreak of past play‑off losses, a goal emphasized by Bayern Munich forward Kim Evans, who highlights the emotional significance and the advantage of a strong home crowd. Evans, one of 12 squad members playing abroad—including five in England, four in Sweden and two in the U.S.—notes that experience in top leagues like Germany’s highly competitive Frauen‑Bundesliga, where she recently won the title with Bayern, improves the national team by exposing players to a different culture and higher standards, complementing the developing Scottish league and bringing Scotland closer to its first major finals.

Stuart Campbell, a former computer‑games reviewer and Scottish‑independence blogger who runs the Wings Over Scotland site, was arrested in the west of England after a woman in south London reported two years of alleged online harassment; he was released on bail pending a mid‑September hearing and says the accusations stem solely from some of his public tweets, which he insists were not threatening, while accusing the media of innuendo and speculation, and he announced on Twitter that he would be posting less frequently for reasons beyond his control.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) is urging that Skegness replace its historic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a modern, animal‑friendly version, proposing a fish and the slogan “Skegness – A Happy Plaice.” The original Jolly Fisherman poster, commissioned by the Great Northern Railway in 1908 for 12 guineas with the slogan “Skegness is so bracing,” has become synonymous with the Lincolnshire resort. PETA’s Dawn Carr argues the mascot evokes animal cruelty, describing graphic scenes of fish and sea animals being harmed, and says a new mascot would allow the town to rebrand as a progressive holiday destination that does not celebrate the mutilation and killing of sea animals. Mayor Carl Macey acknowledges the mascot’s popularity with adults and children, states that he does not view it as portraying cruelty, and notes that the proposal will be considered by the council, but if the Jolly Fisherman is not removed they will not pursue changes.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a one‑sided test, racing to a 38‑11 victory after a first‑half surge that saw tries from Tommy Seymour, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg and Hamish Watson, with Greig Laidlaw adding conversions and penalties; Georgia opened the scoring through Vasil Lobzhanidze but were hampered by a sin‑binned lock, a penalty try and a yellow card for Moray Low, managing only two tries from Lobzhanidze and a late score by Ali Price’s teammate Rory Hughes, while Scotland’s dominance was reflected in 91 % possession and a strong defensive display, prompting coach Vern Cotter to praise their pragmatic approach, improved game management and Laidlaw’s leadership; the match featured line‑ups of Scotland’s back‑four (Hogg, Maitland, Bennett, Dunbar) and forwards (Fagerson, the Gray brothers, Harley, Watson, Wilson) and Georgia’s side led by captain Mamuka Gorgodze and key players Lobzhanidze, Mikautadze and Kvirikashvili.

Widnes defeated Castleford, taking a 14‑6 half‑time lead thanks to tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van and Chris Bridge, and extending the margin in the second half with Paddy Flynn (on loan from Castleford) scoring early, followed by further tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2) and Joe Mellor to make it 38‑12 before Castleford’s Larne Patrick, Luke Gale and Flynn added three quick tries; despite Castleford’s late surge, Widnes held on for the win, moving above Wakefield into seventh place while Castleford stayed sixth, one point clear of the Vikings.

Fawzi al‑Odah, a 37‑year‑old Kuwaiti detained at Guantanamo since 2002 after his arrest in Pakistan on alleged al‑Qaida and Taliban ties he denies, was released after a US Periodic Review Board concluded he no longer posed a “continuing significant threat,” a finding echoed by a US review panel; he had previously challenged his detention before the Supreme Court, boarded a Kuwaiti government plane without bitterness according to his lawyer, and will spend at least a year in a Kuwaiti militant‑rehabilitation centre, reducing the base’s population to 148 inmates, the first release since the May prisoner swap that freed five Taliban detainees for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl, while the facility—opened in 2002 after the September 11 attacks—remains under President Obama’s pledge to close it.

The viral “PP PPAP” (Pen‑Pineapple‑Apple‑Pen) earworm was performed by the animal‑print‑clad fictional DJ Piko‑Taro, a character created by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, and features a simple, addictive beat, silly lyrics and a basic dance; after being uploaded to Piko‑Taro’s YouTube channel (over 4 million views) it exploded on Facebook, where a 9GAG repost amassed more than 44 million views, prompting mixed reactions ranging from amused fascination to irritation, while mainstream Japanese media gave it little coverage despite its global spread, leading to the artist being dubbed the “next Psy” and inspiring hundreds of international tributes, covers and parodies—including vines by Japanese duo Riko & Rika, a heavy‑metal version and a Thai star’s rendition.

Thousands gathered for an early‑morning service at Hyde Park Corner, with up to 400 participants in a parade before a wreath‑laying at the Cenotaph, while a parallel service was held at Westminster Abbey and the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. Anzac Day, marking the first major World War I battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces at Gallipoli, was first commemorated in London in 1916 when King George V attended a Westminster Abbey service; since then the ceremonies have become a key moment for expatriate and visiting Australians and New Zealanders to honour their countrymen’s sacrifices in all wars. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer addressed the crowd, laid a wreath, and reflected on the Gallipoli landings, while veterans, service members, their families, schoolchildren offering prayers, and crowds of ex‑patriates lined the streets, hearing the anthems of the three nations. The eight‑month Gallipoli campaign on the Turkish peninsula was one of the war’s bloodiest, an Allied effort to push the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

Clarkson, a 30‑year‑old forward who rejoined St Mirren in July, is set to make his Championship debut against Alloa after scoring nine goals for Dundee last season and mostly featuring as a substitute this term; he emphasizes his fitness and readiness, having been capped twice for Scotland in 2008 with one international goal and accumulating nearly 400 senior club appearances for former sides including Bristol City, Brentford and Bristol Rovers, while St Mirren sit eighth in the league, seven points above bottom‑placed Alloa, and aim to win games, build confidence and climb the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, and despite fears that the new owners might abandon the workers’ pension scheme, Unite’s regional officer Steve Harley said productive talks secured guarantees that all current agreements will be honoured; the Bernard Matthews final‑salary pension was closed in 2004 and members now have an alternative scheme that remains unaffected, a fact confirmed by Boparan’s private office, which also pledged to continue the existing pension arrangements, and the new owner aims to restore the business to high profitability through greater investment, cost savings and using spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting, leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes chain ferry crossing would remain free until 2 July to address ongoing problems and gather feedback, and that auditors would review the project after a “frustrating and disappointing start” marked by breakdowns, groundings, a Maritime and Coastguard Agency suspension for training issues, and vehicle damage since its late‑May launch; local businesses like Angie Booth’s shop reported severe trade losses and sought compensation, while transport councillor Ian Ward noted the ferry is a prototype with expected teething issues, cited resolved electrical faults, approved ramp extensions to stop vehicles scraping the concrete, and said seamanship‑related groundings had been addressed.

The House of Lords EU Committee warns that while Britain may have to let EU‑registered vessels fish in its waters under any overall deal, fishing communities—though they voted heavily for Brexit—risk being marginalised in broader negotiations despite the sector representing only half a percent of GDP and employing about 12,000 people; the report stresses that continued market access, especially to the EU, is essential for a “successful industry,” but this may require concessions on water access, and it recommends retaining scientific‑based total allowable catches and many elements of the EU’s Common Fisheries Policy to meet international obligations, noting that leaving the EU could fragment management into four separate regimes for England, Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland. Recent EU‑agreed quota increases for plaice, haddock and prawns have been welcomed by the industry as a positive sign, with leaders expressing optimism about full control of the 200‑mile exclusive economic zone and the prospect of fairer quota shares and sustainable fisheries, while the government emphasizes the need to secure maximum trading freedom and use Brexit as an opportunity to review fisheries management for fair access and a healthy marine environment.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or allowing the download of images of partially dressed young boys in erotic poses between April 2004 and February 2014; he received a community payback order, was placed on the sex‑offenders register, and was ordered to attend a special programme for sex offenders. A General Teaching Council Scotland hearing concluded that his conduct—condoning and participating in an industry that abuses children—was fundamentally incompatible with teaching, demonstrated a pattern of behaviour, and posed a strong likelihood of recurrence, leading the panel to deem him unfit to teach, remove him from the professional register, and bar him from re‑registering for two years. He was 69 at sentencing and did not attend the hearing.

Firefighters spent several days at the Duncan Street site after a 2 March blaze that disrupted train services and caused travel delays, prompting the Environment Agency (EA) to suspend Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste; although the firm and its operator, Asset and Land Group, were deemed “broadly compliant” with fire‑safety legislation after nine GMFRS visits in the past year, the EA, acting on fire‑service concerns about impacts on nearby residents, transport and the environment, decided to revoke the company’s environmental permit—effective 7 August, pending any appeal, and requiring removal of all waste—while the fire’s cause remains undetermined.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al‑Mekdad told the BBC that Syria is “doing its best” to meet the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, though it missed Wednesday’s deadline for handing over its entire stockpile and a shipment to the port of Latakia was twice attacked, which he blamed on terrorist groups; he rejected US Secretary of State John Kerry’s condemnation of barrel‑bomb attacks in Aleppo, where the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported 246 deaths—including 73 children—over five days, while the Aleppo Media Centre said 14 were killed in a single strike, and he accused the US of still supporting terrorists; the Syrian government denied rebel claims of seizing Aleppo’s central prison, despite reports that the Islamic Front’s Ahrar al‑Sham and al‑Nusra Front freed hundreds of detainees, though state media said security forces thwarted the attack; Syria holds about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, of which the US says only 30 tonnes (≈4 %) have left the country, and both US Defence Secretary Chuck Hagel and Russia have warned that the UN‑backed removal plan is lagging, with the OPCW citing security concerns, while Mekdad affirmed Syria’s commitment to its OPCW and UN obligations and its intent to complete the transfer by the March 1 deadline and destroy all weapons by the end of June.

England leveled the four‑match series with a dominant win at Old Trafford, declaring 589‑8 and 173‑1 to secure their second‑largest victory over Pakistan; Joe Root, promoted to number three, earned man of the match with a 254‑run first‑innings innings and an unbeaten 71‑run knock in the second, also taking four catches and a wicket, while captain Alastair Cook contributed 105 and 76‑not‑out, and England’s bowlers dismissed Pakistan for 198 and 234 on a pitch offering little assistance, prompting praise from commentators and former players about England’s batting depth and discipline, whereas Pakistan’s limited contributions—only Misbah‑ul‑Haq and Asad Shafiq passing 50 in the first two Tests—were blamed on poor shot selection and low confidence; Pakistan will play a two‑day tour match against Worcestershire before the third Test at Edgbaston on 3 August.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People’s Commissioner for Wales, is launching a review of residential care that will gather testimonies from pensioners, their families and carers to inform recommendations for providers and public bodies, assessing quality of life through physical and psychological health, social relationships and the care‑home environment; while she highlights both exemplary and substandard care and plans to consult care providers, social‑care staff and authorities, Care Forum Wales chair Mario Kreft supports the review’s goals but criticises the advisory panel for lacking representation from anyone with direct experience of living, working in, managing or owning a care home.

Former Dons midfielder Paul Sheerin, 39, who has been player‑manager of Arbroath (the Red Lichties) since 2010, has been appointed to replace Neil Cooper at Aberdeen’s Pittodrie, a decision made by manager Derek McInnes after a “comprehensive process” according to chief executive Duncan Fraser, who praised Arbroath chairman John Christison for facilitating Sheerin’s return despite the club’s recent relegation to Scottish League Two after finishing bottom of League One in 2013‑14; Sheerin’s playing career included spells at several Scottish clubs, a stint with Östersunds in Sweden and a Scotland Under‑21 cap in the mid‑1990s, and he guided Arbroath to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will lead Swansea’s Saturday match against Bournemouth after Bob Bradley’s dismissal, while the club aims to appoint Paul Clement as the new permanent boss; Curtis warned that relegation would make a swift return to the Premier League difficult despite the league’s increased competitiveness, noting past successes under Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers and Michael Laudrup and lamenting a loss of the “Swansea Way” after frequent managerial changes and player turnover, yet he believes the current squad is capable of staying up and reminds new signings of the club’s remarkable rise from near‑bankruptcy and lower‑league obscurity to its 2011 promotion.

J. Craig Venter, a biologist‑entrepreneur, accelerated human genome mapping by turning it into a competitive race, founding Celera Genomics and publishing the human genome alongside the public effort in 2001, after earlier sequencing the bacterium Haemophilus influenzae in 1995; he left the NIH in 1992 to create the private Institute for Genomic Research, pioneered rapid gene sequencing by focusing on RNA rather than whole DNA, and later established the J Craig Venter Institute, which has spent over a decade developing a synthetic organism called Synthia (reported in *Science*) and conducting the ocean‑wide Sorcerer II microbial‑genome treasure hunt, work that, despite controversy and criticism for his commercial approach, has sped genomics, attracted vast private resources, and promises applications such as industrial microbes that could reduce reliance on oil and capture carbon dioxide.

The Sutton Trust report, based on a Boston Consulting Group study, finds that England’s apprenticeships are generally low‑quality and short, with fewer than 200,000 of the 520,000 annual starts rated at level 3 (A‑level equivalent) and 58 % below that level since 2010, while most are aimed at workers over 25; only 20 % of English employers offer apprenticeships compared with 51 % in Germany, which provides 570,000 youth apprenticeships, 90 % at level 3, and has a far simpler qualification framework (330 versus England’s 18,000). The report warns that 11 young people compete for each place and that the current patchwork system confuses employers and lacks societal value, urging a radical expansion to up to 300,000 new starts per year—predominantly three‑year, level‑3 programmes, with limited two‑year, level‑2 courses—while preserving well‑regarded level‑2 routes such as construction, improving facilities, teaching quality, and career guidance; the Department for Education says reforms are already underway to raise standards.

Sarah Storey, a 37‑year‑old British Paralympian, finished more than two minutes ahead of Poland’s Anna Harkowska in Nottwil, Switzerland, positioning herself to claim a 17th title in the upcoming road race; she described the victory as a massive relief and is aiming for further success at the 2016 Rio Paralympics. Storey is Britain’s most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals—11 gold, eight silver and three bronze—earned across cycling and swimming over six Games, including four golds at London 2012, and she has accumulated 21 world titles. She began her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before switching to cycling in 2005.

The Bulls’ (Hereford United) fate hinged on mounting financial troubles that culminated in a series of missed payment deadlines to football creditors—initially set for 5 June and repeatedly extended to 12 June—despite a £148,000 debt and a £225,000 overall shortfall, including over £70,000 in unpaid PAYE tax; after a dramatic final‑day escape that kept them in the Conference Premier, the club was taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar, but failed to meet the final deadline, leading the Conference to expel them on 10 June and replace them with Chester, who had themselves been reinstated after earlier expulsion, while supporters’ attempts to rescue the club—including a £1 offer from the Hereford United Supporters’ Trust to clear £220,000 in debts—were rejected in favor of rival bidders, leaving players unpaid and the club’s future in jeopardy.

The 30‑year‑old former Manchester City player earned 61 senior England caps after debuting in 2009, was selected for two World Cups and two European Championships but played only three minutes at Euro 2016, and scored his sole international goal in a 5‑0 win over Moldova during the 2014 World Cup qualifiers; he also holds the record for most England Under‑21 appearances with 46 caps since his 2004 debut.

Christopher Hogwood died at his home in Cambridge after a several‑month illness, with a private funeral and a later memorial service planned; he was a leading figure in the early‑music movement, founding the Academy of Ancient Music in 1973 and directing it for about 30 years across six continents, producing over 200 CDs—including the first complete Mozart symphonies on period instruments—and earning acclaim for recordings such as the 1980 Handel Messiah with Emma Kirkby, named one of BBC Music Magazine’s top 20 recordings of all time. He studied keyboard at Cambridge with Rafael Puyana, Mary Potts, Zuzana Ruzickova and Gustav Leonhardt, began his career as a keyboardist and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin‑in‑the‑Fields under Sir Neville Marriner, and co‑founded the Early Music Consort of London. He also served as artistic director of the King’s Lynn Festival and Boston’s Handel and Haydn Society, taught at Harvard, held honorary professorships at Cambridge and Cornell, and was remembered by colleagues for his generosity, scholarly brilliance, and lasting influence on generations of musicians.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose family’s identity is being protected, was taken out of mainstream schooling in June because he was not coping, prompting his mother to quit her job to care for him; the family has been waiting for a special‑school place, but in September were told all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were full with no timeline for availability, leaving the child isolated and upset that his siblings can attend school; an extra classroom assistant has now been hired at a local special school with hopes the boy can start there within weeks, though his mother fears the same capacity problems will affect other families, while the Education Authority declined to comment on the individual case citing privacy, noting it is reviewing special‑school needs and working to ensure placements near children, with ongoing efforts aimed at improving provision from 2016 onward.

The Welsh Rugby Union has made a takeover bid for the Newport Gwent Dragons, viewing Rodney Parade as a rugby venue, while Newport County retain a lease that gives them priority for fixtures if they stay in the Football League until 2023; the club’s chairman, Foxall, insists the contract must be honoured and the takeover will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on 9 May. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey notes that County and Newport Squash Club are protected by existing agreements, which the WRU acknowledges, though the WRU plans to install an artificial surface that breaches Football League rules. On the field, County sit two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left, needing a win and a Hartlepool loss to secure survival, while Foxall warns that relegation back to the National League would be a devastating blow to fans and the city.

Last weekend Sierra Leone was declared free of Ebola, a virus that killed nearly 4,000 people in the country over 18 months; the narrator recounts his own journey from being kidnapped at 15 by RUF rebels in 1991, forced into violence and drug use, escaping to Freetown, being jailed where a preacher founded Lifeline Nehemiah to rehabilitate former combatants, and later joining the 2014 Ebola response by educating over 10,000 people in local languages, providing food to 11,000 households, and helping establish a treatment unit that saved many lives, while reflecting on his regret for past atrocities and his belief that investing in youth will build a better future, with the outbreak’s total death toll reported as 11,314 (4,808 in Liberia, 3,955 in Sierra Leone, 2,536 in Guinea, plus cases in Nigeria, the US and Mali).

About 80,000 artworks, ceramics, manuscripts, letters and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum were threatened with auction to cover Waterford Wedgwood plc’s pension debt, but a public fundraising campaign led by the Art Fund met its target within a month, allowing the collection to remain on display in Barlaston and be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned back to the Wedgwood Museum; administrators praised the outcome as a result of goodwill and complex negotiations, noting that without the funds the items could have been sold and dispersed globally, while officials highlighted the collection’s importance to Britain’s cultural heritage and national identity.

Dan Groves said the details of a potential deal in which Wright could purchase a 20% stake and become a director of Billericay Town have not yet been released, though The Sun reported the 30‑year‑old’s appointment; the club, now owned by multi‑millionaire Glenn Tamplin—who pledged to invest £10,000 weekly—is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points shy of a play‑off spot, and has recently added former England international Paul Konchesky, while Wright, a 2011 “I’m a Celebrity…Get Me Out of Here” runner‑up, previously played for non‑league sides such as Lewes, Crawley Town and Rushden & Diamonds.

Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, surprised observers by opting for a one‑year extension of his term rather than the two alternatives of staying until 2021 or leaving as originally planned in 2018; while the Brexit negotiations and market stability were factors, he cited personal family considerations—specifically his daughters’ upcoming exams and a desire to return to Canada’s education system—as the decisive reason for the short extension, emphasizing that the decision was entirely personal and not driven by government pressure or economic forecasts.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1‑1 after Blackpool took the lead in the 12th minute when Jamille Matt finished a Nathan Delfouneso chip, but Colchester equalised five minutes later as Kurtis Guthrie scored from a corner scramble; the match featured several notable saves by Blackpool keeper Sam Slocombe, missed chances, multiple yellow cards, substitutions for injuries, and a straight red card for Colchester’s Sean Murray for violent conduct in injury time.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Northern Ireland charity Action Mental Health, provides interactive workshops for P6 and P7 pupils to build emotional wellbeing, teach coping strategies such as breathing exercises, and encourage help‑seeking, while also giving teachers basic training in wellbeing promotion; after a pilot in five schools, the initiative was launched at Carrick Primary School in Lurgan and aims to be rolled out across Northern Ireland to ease the stress of the primary‑to‑secondary transition and the annual transfer tests (which saw 14,681 entrants this year), with chief executive David Babington and school staff highlighting its role in strengthening resilience amid growing mental‑health pressures identified by the chief inspector of schools.

Developers Fawley Waterside plan to repurpose the disused Fawley Power Station site—closed in 2013 after more than 40 years of operation—into a £1 billion “merchant city” featuring a petal‑shaped glass centerpiece, marina, housing, restaurants and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth, with outline planning permission due later this year and construction potentially starting in 2018; the project would retain the station’s 198‑metre chimney, making it the tallest attraction south of London’s Shard, and highlights the former 2,000 MW, oil‑fired plant (commissioned in 1971, capable of powering one million homes) on the 300‑acre western shore of Southampton Water, which was sold to the developers in 2016.

Britain secured two medals at the Hong Kong championships, with Adrian Teklinski of Poland winning gold and Lucass Liss of Germany silver in the men’s scratch, while 23‑year‑old Latham took bronze after a late sprint, and Elinor Barker earned silver in the women’s scratch; the GB men’s team pursuit missed the podium, losing the bronze to Italy, and Joe Truman was eliminated in the men’s keirin semi‑final, while the GB women’s team pursuit finished fifth in the heats and did not contest a medal, prompting positive remarks from Barker and Joanna Rowsell Shand about the young squad’s progress; former Olympic champions Chris Boardman, Sir Chris Hoy and others praised Latham’s race tactics, and Olympic bronze‑medallist Katy Marchant was knocked out in the first round of the women’s sprint, expressing disappointment but remaining slated for the 500 m time‑trial and keirin later in the competition.

Ross Kemp will make a brief return to EastEnders as Grant Mitchell, a role he last played in 2006, to appear in the final episodes of his mother Barbara (Peggy) Mitchell, who has reappeared after a 2010 departure to tell her son Phil that her cancer has returned and will die in emotional spring scenes; the storyline reunites the Mitchell brothers with their mother for the last time, and executive producer Dominic Treadwell‑Collins says it offers a chance to showcase Kemp and Steve McFadden at their best.

Sadio Mane’s two quick goals led Liverpool to a win over second‑placed Spurs at Anfield, prompting manager Mauricio Pochettino to condemn his side’s lack of desire and poor away form, noting they have won only once in 17 matches against top‑six opponents on the road and just twice away since late September; he warned that such pressure‑free performances hinder their Premier League challenge, while Chelsea can widen their lead by beating Burnley, and former midfielder Danny Murphy criticized Spurs’ defensive shift from a back three to a back four, urging a return to their more effective system and faster, more decisive play.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured 19 of the 28 governorships in the recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999, while the PDP won only eight, mainly in the south‑east, and retained Rivers State; the APC also reclaimed Lagos and won most northern states, but failed to capture any of the five oil‑producing states, a concern for President‑elect Muhammadu Buhari, who will be inaugurated on 29 May after defeating Goodluck Jonathan, and although the polls saw 66 violent incidents—particularly in Rivers and other southern areas—the overall process was calmer than previous elections, prompting analysts to note a shift toward a regionalized PDP and a need for the party to introspect and rebuild after 16 years in power.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) will take place in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from 19 to 22 July, featuring acts such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries and Dougie MacLean, and will offer an augmented‑reality app that lets visitors scan signs and posters to access online content—including videos, band interviews, ticket purchases and festival information—on phones and tablets, a feature described by director Caroline Maclennan as an added enjoyment for attendees and a way for people worldwide to experience the festival’s atmosphere.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, both rated inadequate by Ofsted, are to have their funding agreements terminated, with the Park View Educational Trust warned it may be removed from running the schools; Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock, also inadequate, were similarly cautioned unless they address identified breaches, while a head teacher at a “Trojan Horse” school reported parental intimidation during an inspection. Ofsted released 21 reports alleging a hard‑line Muslim takeover in several schools, naming five as inadequate, and Birmingham City Council will collaborate with Saltley School—currently in special measures—to install a temporary governing board. Education minister Lord Nash sent letters to the trustees of Park View, Nansen, Oldknow and Golden Hillock demanding actions by 4 July, including ending “less favourable” treatment of non‑Muslims, stopping gender segregation, and ensuring a broader curriculum, and warned of further termination if breaches persist. The schools plan to challenge the reports legally, while Ofsted chief Sir Michael Wilshaw described a culture of fear and intimidation, and parents have criticised the inspections as biased.

Nazanin Zaghari‑Ratcliffe, 38, was sentenced in September to five years in Tehran for alleged plotting against the Iranian government, a charge that remains undisclosed, and has spent much of her detention in solitary confinement since her arrest at Tehran Airport last April, while her two‑year‑old daughter Gabriella, whose passport was confiscated, stays in Iran with grandparents and has become fluent in Farsi; her husband Richard Ratcliffe, 41, condemns the UK’s inaction, describes the appeal as a secret trial with an unpredictable outcome that could alter, uphold, or increase the sentence, claims his wife is being used as a diplomatic bargaining chip, notes her recent hunger strike and improved morale after being moved from solitary, and is seeking a visa to visit, while Amnesty International labels her a “prisoner of conscience” and hopes the appeal will lead to her immediate release.

Vincent “Vinnie” Barker died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich, and the prosecution at Ipswich Crown Court alleges that optometrist Honey Rose’s failure to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation was “criminally” below the standard expected of a competent optometrist, leading to a buildup of fluid in his brain, increased skull pressure and his preventable death; Rose denies the charge of gross negligence manslaughter and the trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, a 42‑year‑old from Guthrie near Forfar, was convicted of coercing a woman to have sex with a man he met through an adult website, filming the encounters and sending a sexually explicit clip to the victim’s sister on Christmas Day; he was also found guilty of forcing the woman’s sister and father to view sexual images and behaving threateningly on 25 December 2014, leading to his placement on the sex offenders register, a finding of moderate re‑offending risk, and a sentence to be determined by the High Court after Sheriff George Way remitted the case for its greater sentencing powers.

Ireland posted 165‑5 in Greater Noida, with opener Stuart Thompson scoring 56 and contributions from Gary Wilson (41 not out) and captain William Porterfield (39), but Afghanistan chased down the target, reaching 171‑4 in the final two overs thanks to Samiullah Shenwari’s 56, Mohammad Shahzad’s 47 and a 51‑run opening partnership with Najeeb Tarakai; Afghan spinner Amir Hamza (2‑23) was the only bowler to take more than one wicket, and Porterfield lamented the missed extra 15 runs and sub‑par bowling, while Ireland’s paceman Boyd Rankin missed the T20s with a back problem but is expected to return for the upcoming five‑match ODI series.

Barcelona maintains it has not committed any offence regarding the tax aspects of Neymar’s transfer, despite a judge finding sufficient evidence to continue investigations; the club paid €57 million (£48.6 million) for the striker, with his parents receiving £34 million and total costs—including fees and wages—reaching £106.8 million, and it has now made a voluntary tax declaration of €13,550,830.56 while denying any tax‑related crime, even as former president Sandro Rosell, under separate accusations, resigned; the case’s outcome remains uncertain, and Neymar has so far scored seven league goals in 18 appearances and three goals in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona.

David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found dead on a Koh Tao beach on 15 September; post‑mortems showed Miller died from drowning and a head injury while Witheridge died from head wounds, and DNA on her matched two Burmese migrant workers, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, who have allegedly confessed and are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape and robbery, facing possible death‑penalty sentences. Metropolitan Police officers flew to Thailand to work with Thai police, completed their investigative review, and are now returning to the UK to compile a report and update the victims’ families. The UK Foreign Office summoned the Thai chargé d’affaires over concerns about DNA verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects, while Thai Prime Minister Prayuth Chan‑ocha, after meeting former UK Prime Minister David Cameron in Italy, approved the British delegation’s visit.

VR is increasingly being applied beyond entertainment, with journalists, teachers, healthcare workers and retailers using it to enhance understanding of real‑world issues: the UK’s National Autistic Society created a VR film that lets users experience sensory overload from an autistic boy’s perspective, and Alzheimer’s Research UK released “A Walk Through Dementia” to illustrate daily challenges for people with dementia. Retailers such as estate agents, Westfield and Ikea employ VR for virtual property tours and kitchen design, the latter seeing high download rates and even adding virtual meatball‑throwing as a novelty. In healthcare, VR supports training and therapy, exemplified by Dr Shafi Ahmed’s live‑streamed virtual surgery via Medical Realities, US programs for PTSD and arachnophobia, and studies showing significant fear reduction. Education benefits from Google’s Expeditions cardboard kits, Evanescent Studios’ language‑learning app trialled at Imperial College, and experiments by Chinese firm NetDragon to detect student engagement through headset data, though widespread adoption is hampered by the high cost of hardware and computing power for cash‑strapped schools.

The “black box” of the downed Su‑24 was opened in Moscow, revealing missing flight data that could clarify the jet’s location when it was hit, with an analysis due next week; the aircraft was shot down by F‑16s on 24 November, killing the pilot (who was reportedly killed by militants on the ground) while the navigator was rescued, and a Russian marine sent to aid them was also killed along with a helicopter; Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace, whereas Russia says it was downed within Syrian airspace, prompting President Putin to condemn Turkey’s government and leading Russia to demand an apology and impose sanctions, including a ban on package holidays that could cost Turkey billions of dollars.

Scotland’s women have won all five qualifiers and will host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium, a victory that would virtually guarantee a place in next summer’s Netherlands finals, while Iceland—ranked 20th and unbeaten in four matches—remain the group’s top seed and the Friday match and a return fixture in Reykjavik will likely decide the group winner; midfielder Kim Little and 11 other squad members play abroad, including 24‑year‑old Bayern forward Erin Evans, who after winning the German Bundesliga celebrated with the men’s team and now stresses that experience in top leagues like Germany’s, alongside Scotland’s improving domestic competition, brings new culture and higher standards to the national side as they aim to avoid past play‑off heartbreak and secure their first major tournament.

The Commission on Local Tax Reform, set up by the Scottish government and Cosla, concluded that there is no “magic bullet” for fixing the council tax’s inherent flaws, which have accumulated over time, and that any reform will be complex and tied to past experiences; Professor Kenneth Gibb’s review of international systems found property taxes common and stable but often confusing and perceived as unfair, while local income taxes are seen as fairer but cause revenue volatility and limit rate flexibility, leading the commission to plan a Scotland‑wide public consultation before releasing its autumn report, as ministers deem the current council tax system overall unfair and are seeking fairer alternatives.

Third‑party software, notably Elcomsoft’s Phone Password Breaker, was used to steal iCloud photos of celebrities, exploiting a gap in Apple’s two‑step verification that allowed attackers to download full backups even when the feature was enabled; Apple’s recent update makes the verification step mandatory for new devices, blocks backup downloads without a four‑digit code, sends immediate email alerts when a backup starts, and requires a 14‑character recovery key for account recovery, though experts warn the key can be lost or stolen and argue two‑factor authentication should be the default rather than optional; Apple says it will more aggressively encourage users to enable two‑factor authentication and stronger passwords, and CEO Tim Cook emphasized the need for greater user awareness alongside engineering solutions.

UKIP won the May election, spending £2,956,737 (68p per vote), while the Conservatives spent £2,980,815 (79p per vote), Labour spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote), the Lib Dems £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) and lost 11 of 12 MEPs, the Greens £534,249 (43p per vote), and the SNP £267,372; the six highest‑spending parties together spent £9,347,087, and all except Labour out‑spent their 2009 European election campaigns.

Anderson, a 27‑year‑old centre‑back who previously played for Aldershot, Exeter and in Italy, has terminated his Barrow contract by mutual consent to join a National League rival and could face his former club on 18 February; striker Keating, 21, was recommended to Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson by former Port Vale boss Micky Adams after spells with Sligo Rovers, Galway United and Finn Harps, with his transfer pending international clearance; Nicholson praised centre‑back Myles for his stature, voice and leadership, and described young forward Ruairi as raw but very eager, while the Gulls sit four points above the relegation zone after winning only one of their last six games.

Many Clouds, a 10‑year‑old Irish‑bred gelding, collapsed and died after narrowly beating Thistlecrack to win the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham’s Festival Trials Day, with the British Horseracing Authority confirming a severe pulmonary haemorrhage as the cause; although such episodes are rare and can occur in otherwise healthy sport horses, the BHA emphasized a need to better understand and possibly prevent them. The horse, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, had previously shown post‑race ataxia and a tendency to overheat but had never collapsed before, and had notable victories including the 2015 Gold Cup trial and the 2014 Hennessy Gold Cup, prompting trainer Oliver Sherwood to call him the “horse of a lifetime.”

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick was moved to tears as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former first minister Alex Salmond delivered their farewell speeches ahead of the 5 May election, joining other departing MSPs such as Conservative Annabel Goldie; Salmond’s valedictory address highlighted Scotland’s diversity, a broad consensus for greater parliamentary responsibility, welcomed the Scotland Bill’s transfer of powers while noting it fell short of unionist pledges, and included light‑hearted remarks about a Cheltenham race, whereas McNeil warned Holyrood to learn from Westminster’s committee system to ensure accountability and scrutiny, recalling Robin Cook’s visit, and Goldie humorously noted she would miss Finance Secretary John Swinney’s “faux indignation.”

The film, directed by Bill Condon and set to begin shooting at Shepperton Studios in May, will be released in U.S. cinemas on 17 March 2017 and features a star‑studded cast: Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and a new actress as Mrs. Potts, the housekeeper turned teapot originally voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury.

The Crown Prosecution Service will meet victims' relatives at 11:00 BST in Warrington to announce decisions on 23 suspects—15 from the Operation Resolve inquiry into the 1989 Hillsborough disaster that killed 96 fans and was later ruled an unlawful killing, and eight from an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe of police conduct—after evidence files were referred to the CPS; Sue Hemming, head of the special crime and counter‑terrorism division, will deliver the outcomes, while Margaret Aspinall, chair of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed the families' long struggle, anticipation, and determination for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported a recent surge in incidents where packages are thrown over its walls, prompting concerns from nearby residents who have witnessed multiple occurrences and prompting the prison to invite community discussions; a former inmate described the facility as “notorious” for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis and alleged that drones have been used to deliver contraband, though the Ministry of Justice says there is no evidence of drones at the site and emphasizes that staff are working hard to stop contraband, while the Justice Secretary has called for better tools to tackle the problem and new laws now allow up to two years’ imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72‑year‑old lollipop lady of 20 years, suffered serious head injuries on a Bedford Road crossing in Kempston last December after being struck by Brian Wright, a 55‑year‑old driver whose VW Golf failed to stop at a red light; Wright claimed he was blinded by the setting sun and could not recall the light’s colour, denied causing serious injury by dangerous driving, expressed remorse in Luton Crown Court, and the case remains ongoing as Blackburn receives residential care.

Muir, a 24‑year‑old middle‑distance runner, will miss next year’s Commonwealth Games on Australia’s Gold Coast because her veterinary medicine exams aren’t until May and she must focus on completing her final university year, though she will return to training after a brief break; she previously placed fourth in the 1500 m and sixth in the 5,000 m at the World Athletics Championships, set a new outdoor personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000 m, expressed optimism about future Olympic participation and a possible target at the World Indoor Championships in March, and said she hopes to race in Birmingham, while noting Hellen Obiri’s 5,000 m gold in London and expressing satisfaction with her own performance despite a heavy race schedule.

Trevor Deely, 22, vanished in December 2000 after leaving a Christmas party, and a search of a three‑acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, began early Saturday with excavations expected to last weeks; a team of six detectives reviewing his disappearance enhanced CCTV footage that shows Deely speaking with a man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggut Street before he returned for an umbrella, and the same unidentified man was later captured on CCTV following Deely on Haddington Road, prompting renewed appeals for the man to come forward.

Del Potro defeated a Swiss opponent 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 to move into the next round, where he will face either France’s 32nd seed Lucas Pouille or American Donald Young; the 27‑year‑old Argentine, ranked 165th after more than two years out with wrist injuries, is playing his first Grand Slam since the 2014 Australian Open and expressed joy at returning to form, while fellow draw‑mate Nick Kyrgios overcame Germany’s Dustin Brown in a five‑set, rain‑interrupted match to reach round three and will meet 22nd‑seed Feliciano Lopez, with the winner set to face either Andy Murray or John Millman; other notable results included 10th seed Tomas Berdych beating Benjamin Becker and 12th seed Jo‑Wilfried Tsonga defeating Juan Monaco.

Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologising for a furious letter it sent to CAF following a controversial penalty that cost it a 2‑1 extra‑time loss to Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 quarter‑finals, and after a meeting with CAF president Issa Hayatou resolved the dispute; Morocco, whose 2015 hosting rights were stripped after it refused to stage the tournament over Ebola fears and was initially fined $1 million, was allowed back into the 2017 qualifying draw when the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned its ban and reduced the fine to $50,000, with Moroccan FA chief Fouzi Lekjaa expressing optimism for the future; Equatorial Guinea stepped in as 2015 hosts with only 64 days to prepare, and the 2017 draw placed Tunisia in Group A with Togo, Liberia and Djibouti and Morocco in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya and São Tomé, while a Tunisian appearance in the 2017 finals would mark its thirteenth consecutive Nations Cup participation, a record.

McLaren, a team that has won 182 Grand Prix, 12 drivers’ championships and eight constructors’ titles, fell from past greatness after a chassis‑design slump began in 2013 despite still fielding world champions like Fernando Alonso; while the current car is praised, the Honda power‑unit remains a weakness, contrasting sharply with the dominant Honda partnership of the late 1980s that produced 15 wins in 1988 and multiple titles, and later successes with Mercedes and Mika Hakkinen, whereas scandals in 2007 and 2009 and a prolonged dip in form have left the team struggling; after Ron Dennis reclaimed control following the 2013 disaster, he and his team believe the car’s progress and a more mature Honda engine will soon restore McLaren to championship‑winning form.

Paramedics responded to a sudden death at Joe’s Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014, and police later found patrons still inside while till receipts showed alcohol was being served until 04:49 BST; the magistrate ordered the bar’s closure for three months and charged license holder Colleen O’Neill, 43, with two counts and James Thomas, 44, of the same address with one count of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours, noting that the premises had not been run properly and that O’Neill had an “appalling record,” resulting in fines of £3,000 for O’Neill and £1,000 for Thomas.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most three‑pointers in a season, hitting eight threes (totaling 280) and scoring 45 points as the Golden State Warriors rallied to a 116‑105 win over the Portland Trail Blazers, with Klay Thompson adding 26 points and Curry dishing out nine assists to stave off a three‑game losing streak; for Portland, LaMarcus Aldridge posted 27 points and six rebounds and Damian Lillard contributed 20 points and eight assists as the Blazers clinched the Northwest division. In another game, the Chicago Bulls erased a 19‑point halftime deficit to beat the Miami Heat 89‑78, highlighted by Pau Gasol’s 16 points and 15 rebounds, Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson each scoring 14, and Derrick Rose adding 12 points, while the Heat were outscored 57‑27 after halftime despite Hassan Whiteside’s 19 points and 16 rebounds and Dwyane Wade’s nine points.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert and Lazar Marković were visited at Melwood by YouTube free‑kick specialist Bas van Velzen, who claimed to have won a competition for a dead‑ball masterclass with the Anfield stars; he then demonstrated his free‑kick abilities, scoring into the top corner against a stand‑in keeper and impressing the quartet, while later surprising Balotelli by revealing the forward’s infamous slogan shirt, an experience van Velzen described as amazing and a fan’s dream.

A Canadian study of 676 breast‑cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations found that women who underwent oophorectomy after diagnosis—especially those with a BRCA1 mutation—experienced a marked survival benefit, with a 62 % reduction in breast‑cancer‑specific death and a 65 % reduction in death from any cause; when the surgery was performed within two years of diagnosis, the reduction rose to 73 %. The overall 20‑year survival for the cohort was 77.4 %, and the protective effect was evident immediately and persisted for at least 15 years, particularly in estrogen‑receptor‑negative cancers. No similar benefit was seen for BRCA2 carriers, prompting calls for further research. The findings support considering oophorectomy as part of early‑stage treatment discussions for BRCA mutation carriers, who face a lifetime breast‑cancer risk of up to 70 % and, for BRCA1 carriers, a high risk of ovarian tumors.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by Amtrak Train No. 80, the Carolinian, shortly before 10 a.m. on Easter Sunday in Durham, North Carolina, while lingering on tracks owned by Norfolk‑Southern; the train was traveling north from Charlotte to New York City, and although none of the 166 passengers were injured, one passenger was treated for illness during the resulting delay of about two hours and 45 minutes, after which the train resumed its route, and authorities noted the Lowes may have been living in a homeless camp and had been asking a local man for assistance crossing the tracks.

Carlos Toro, a 66‑year‑old former mid‑level Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, spent the last 27 years as a DEA informant after providing information on his former bosses, helping the agency conduct undercover stings worldwide and contributing to the prosecutions of figures such as Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega; promised U.S. citizenship in return for his service, he never received it, and after retiring due to declining health he now faces deportation, lives illegally, cannot obtain a green card, passport, or Social Security benefits, and fears for his life if returned to Colombia, while the DEA has refused to assist him and a former colleague gave him $5,000 after the agency declined help.

The U.S. regulator ICANN has asked the Federal Trade Commission and Canada’s Office of Consumer Affairs to examine whether the Canadian firm Vox Populi Registry Ltd. is acting illegally by using the newly approved “.sucks” top‑level domain to charge celebrities and companies exorbitant fees—up to about $2,499 a year—to remove or block sites that use their names (e.g., youtube.sucks, bing.sucks, visa.sucks, bankofamerica.sucks, yahoo.sucks, telusmobility.sucks); Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift are among those reported to have paid to have their names taken down, and an ICANN advisory panel, citing industry groups such as Microsoft, Verizon and eBay, has called the scheme a “shakedown” and “predatory,” warning that the threat of opening a “.sucks” site to the public is a coercive element, while Vox Populi maintains its practices comply with ICANN rules and the law and notes it will also offer “.sucks” addresses for as little as $10 a year to consumers.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy’s body was found wrapped in a blanket inside a Sainsbury’s bag floating in the village pond at Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk; DNA from the exhumed remains matched a relative in the national database, leading police to the woman who admitted the baby was stillborn, that she had concealed the pregnancy and placed the infant in the pond, and that no foul play was involved, resulting in the infanticide charge being dropped while authorities consider charges for failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial; the boy, originally buried as an unnamed infant, was re‑buried on the 26th anniversary of his discovery, given the name Peter after the church, and received a new headstone funded by a stillbirth support charity.

A High Court judge ruled that taxi driver Michael Young unlawfully imprisoned passenger Kristopher Hicks, who was forced to jump from a moving taxi traveling over 20 mph after Young mistakenly believed Hicks would “do a runner” and drove him back toward the rank to teach a lesson; the jump caused severe brain injuries, epilepsy, loss of taste and smell, and now requires 24‑hour care from his mother, leading Hicks’s family to seek damages that the court said would be reduced to roughly 50 % of the “hundreds of thousands of pounds” originally requested, plus an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment, with the exact amount to be determined and both parties given permission to appeal.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as storms produced multiple twister reports, including one about 6 miles northwest of Goddard (near Wichita) that moved northeast, and additional sightings near Aetna in southwestern Kansas; nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as especially dangerous. The National Weather Service also noted a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, with accompanying wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage and water‑covered streets, while nearby areas reported dark clouds and baseball‑size hail. The Weather Service warned that more storms are expected Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey, aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a title shot; he plans to dominate by cutting off Machida’s movement, using his striking and ground game to act “the bull” against Machida’s “matador” style, while acknowledging respect for the veteran’s technique. Both fighters come off recent victories—Rockhold over Michael Bisping in Australia and Machida over C.B. Dollaway in Brazil—and each expresses confidence in their game plans, with Rockhold emphasizing his all‑round mixed‑martial‑arts skill set and Machida believing his strategy can upset Rockhold and also earn a title opportunity.

An aerostar light twin aircraft made a gear‑up (belly) landing on a runway in Fort Pierce, Florida, skidding along the tarmac with its propellers and belly striking the surface, producing a memorable “ricocheting” sound; the pilot, 85‑year‑old Chris Georgaklis, quickly applied full throttle, kept the engines running despite propeller damage, and managed to take off again, flying about 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely, while a video‑maker on the flight line described the event and noted the likely cause was human error (failure to deploy the gear), with the FAA opening an investigation.

Manuel Pellegrini said he is disappointed with Yaya Toure’s under‑performance this season but will continue to support the Ivory Coast midfielder until the end of the campaign, despite City’s intention to consider summer offers for him as they look to revamp an ageing squad; Toure, who has two years left on a £220,000‑a‑week contract, insists he does not need a rest and wants to stay, while the club, having earned only 18 points from a possible 39, prepares for a West Ham match without captain Vincent Kompany, who faces a muscle injury, and goalkeeper Joe Hart stresses that the players must take responsibility and backs Pellegrini’s leadership. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce warned West Ham left‑back Aaron Cresswell not to repeat the mistakes of former City players such as Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair as Manchester City express interest in signing him to help meet home‑grown player quotas.

Domenico Rancadore, a 65‑year‑old Sicilian mafia figure who has lived in Britain for more than two decades, was convicted in absentia by an Italian court in 1999 and sentenced to seven years for Cosa Nostra membership, but under Italian law a sentence is extinguished once more than twice its length has elapsed; his case expired in October 2014, leading the Italian court of appeal to agree to extinguish the conviction and the European arrest warrant to be withdrawn, so after a prolonged extradition battle—complicated by Crown Prosecution Service procedural errors that delayed appeals—Rancadore will be allowed to remain in the UK pending a consent order and a magistrates’‑court approval, with his Italian sentence effectively nullified.

Mr Mole, trained by Paul Nicholls, will ride for AP McCoy in the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, where it is one of three 7‑2 co‑favorites in a seven‑runner field that also includes Irish Raider Special Tiara and Nicky Henderson’s Sprinter Sacre (to be ridden by Cheltenham Gold Cup winner Nico de Boinville after Barry Geraghty’s injury). The race gives McCoy six rivals, including Mick Channon’s Somersby, and marks his final ride in a Grade One, with his complete ride tally for the day to be confirmed on Friday; McCoy announced his retirement after riding Mr Mole to a Newbury win in February.

Virginia Trimble Ritter’s daughter Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975; her body was discovered 33 days later, 150 yards from their home in a cluttered garage, showing severe trauma including a blackened mouth, swollen head, fractured neck bone, vomit, pulled‑out hair and blood‑stained scalp, with cookies scattered around her. The murder remained Nashville’s most notorious unsolved case for 33 years, during which a neighbor was briefly charged and then released due to insufficient evidence. In 2006 police matched DNA from Marcia’s clothing to Barrett, who had been arrested for the 1975 murder of Vanderbilt student Sarah Vannatta Des Prez and had a long history of sex‑related convictions. Barrett was convicted of second‑degree murder in 2009 and sentenced to 44 years. After decades of refusing, Ritter finally asked Metro Police investigator Mickey Miller to see the crime‑scene photos; despite his attempts to dissuade her, she viewed them on his laptop, describing the horrific details and expressing a desire for revenge.

Rory McIlroy, the 25‑year‑old world number one, says it is “unthinkable” that he will never win the Masters and is determined to complete a career Grand Slam, joining the only five other players—Gene Sarazen, Ben Hogan, Gary Player, Jack Nicklaus and Tiger Woods—who have won all four majors; he views his 2011 final‑round collapse at Augusta, where a four‑shot lead turned into an 80 and a 10‑shot loss, as the most important day of his career because it taught him valuable lessons that helped him later win the US Open and PGA Championships, and despite having only one top‑10 finish in six Masters appearances (a joint eighth last year), he feels a strong connection to Augusta as a “sanctuary” and is eager to claim his first green jacket while also overcoming personal distractions such as calling off his wedding to Caroline Wozniacki and a costly legal dispute with his former management company.

The week’s top trending stories included four rainbows appearing over New York after heavy rain, the growing practice in rural China of hiring exotic dancers for wakes amid a vice crackdown, Robert Downey Jr.’s irritation during a UK interview about his private life, a new lip‑plumping craze dubbed the “#kyliejennerchallenge” that involves sucking on a jar, 102‑year‑old Alice Barker’s “time‑travel” video with filmmakers, a controversial prom‑posal that referenced bombs and sparked accusations of racism, Ewan McGregor’s casting as Lumière in “Beauty and the Beast,” Johnny Depp’s dramatically altered look in the “Black Mass” trailer, a pregnancy announcement that referenced “The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air,” and a military father’s photobomb of his son’s picture.

In the past year, 272 children in England were hospitalized with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS), a figure that may underestimate the true scale of harm from maternal drinking, as World Health Organization research suggests at least one in 100 UK babies—about 7,500 annually—could suffer learning, behavioural, physical, and organ‑related problems such as deformed limbs, liver, kidney and heart issues, cerebral palsy, sight loss and epilepsy; experts describe FAS as a lifelong, under‑diagnosed condition, exemplified by 15‑year‑old Niamh Brown who requires constant assistance and will never live independently, and while government guidance permits up to two units of alcohol no more than twice a week during pregnancy, advocates like Elizabeth Mitchell call for a total abstinence recommendation.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31‑year‑old former juvenile offender nicknamed “Boomerang Boy” for repeatedly returning home after crimes, burst into the Shildon post office and stores in County Durham on 15 March, brandishing an axe and demanding cash from employee Andrea Brighty; owner Sab Dhillon tackled him, dropping him to the floor, while Dhillon’s wife Sam struck McKerry twice with a baseball bat, forcing him to drop the weapon, after which police arrived and arrested him; McKerry, who began shoplifting at age 12 and had amassed around 80 arrests by age 15 for offenses including aggravated vehicle‑taking, indecent letters and burglary, was later sentenced at Durham Crown Court to six years’ imprisonment for attempted robbery.

Four Royal Navy sailors – Joshua Finbow (23, submarine engineer), Simon Radford (31), Craig Stoner (24) and Darren Smalley (35) – have been charged in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, with group sexual assault and sexual assault causing bodily harm after an alleged gang‑rape at an alcohol‑fueled party on April 10 at a Canadian barracks following a Royal Navy ice‑hockey tournament at Shearwater base; each was released on bail of over £2,000, required to surrender their passports, remain employed by the navy, stay on the Stadacona naval base in Halifax and not leave Nova Scotia or contact the victim or six witnesses, with a further hearing set for May 27, while the investigation continues and forensic results could lead to additional charges, and the British High Commission is cooperating with Canadian authorities.

Valerie Jackson, a Las Vegas mother, cares for her four‑year‑old son RJ, who suffers from Netherton’s syndrome—a rare congenital skin disorder affecting about 70 people worldwide that makes the skin appear red, scalded and scaly and requires constant moisturizing with creams and Vaseline to prevent painful drying; after a stranger mistook RJ’s condition for abuse, police were called and surrounded the family with armed officers (who did not draw their weapons) while they were shopping, prompting an apology from the officer and highlighting public ignorance, while the family also endures bullying, denial of entry to play centres, and harsh comments despite RJ’s otherwise normal, cheerful demeanor; the disorder, a severe form of ichthyosis, is genetic, has no cure, and is managed by regular cleansing, moisturising, and careful handling, with support often found through online groups of other affected families.

Transport for London removed Protein World’s “Are you beach body ready?” posters featuring bikini‑clad model Renee Somerfield from the Underground after the three‑week advertising contract ended, amid a backlash that included a Change.org petition with over 50,000 signatures, more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority, defacement by activists, and a planned protest in Hyde Park; the company defended the un‑photoshopped image, engaged with critics on social media, cited a bomb threat to its headquarters, and said it would consider the reaction for future campaigns, while the ASA continues to assess the complaints, and the protein‑powder market in the UK is rapidly expanding.

Rail firms announced a series of fare hikes—up to 87 percent on the London‑Cotswolds route—just ten days after the general election, despite the prime minister’s and Labour’s pledges to freeze or cap prices; David Cameron wrote to First Great Western (FGW) urging an urgent review of its plan to raise an off‑peak return from Charlbury to London from £33.30 to £62.40 on 17 May, while FGW justified the increase as aligning the north‑Cotswolds service with its other routes and offered advance‑purchase tickets that could cost as little as £20; other announced hikes include Crewe‑Northampton first‑class off‑peak singles rising from £30 to £37, Stafford‑Liverpool anytime returns climbing 24.5 percent to £33, and a Manchester‑Stoke first‑class day return up 22 percent to £35.30; Virgin claimed most of its hikes affect “Virgin‑only” fares, which remain at least 20 percent cheaper than rivals, and noted its overall West Coast increase of 1.65 percent is well below the industry average; train companies can adjust unregulated fares—about half of their revenue—during three annual windows, prompting criticism that the hikes contradict the parties’ price‑freeze promises.

Former soldier John Young, 66, and his new wife Elaine, 54, were attacked in their Oldham home when thugs began pelting the front window with stones and then threw bricks, one of which shattered the door glass and struck Young in the left eye as he opened the door to confront them; the impact caused an open forehead wound and permanent blindness in that eye despite emergency surgery, prompting the couple—who had married three weeks earlier and were writing thank‑you cards for wedding gifts—to feel unsafe, move to a flat in Southport, and describe the incident as senseless vandalism with no known motive, while Greater Manchester police continue to investigate and urge witnesses to come forward.

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, 25, has signed a one‑year contract extension keeping him at the county until the end of the 2016 season after a successful comeback from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that claimed his father’s life and forced him to miss the entire 2014 campaign; following an ankle operation he returned during Derbyshire’s pre‑season tour of Abu Dhabi, and elite performance director Graeme Welch praised his exceptional character, hard work in training and off‑field duties, and recent good form, expressing confidence the new deal will boost his confidence for the upcoming season.

Harley Renshaw, a five‑year‑old from Stretford, was diagnosed with an aggressive form of neuroblastoma that had spread to his kidney, neck, lungs and bones, prompting 80 days of intensive chemotherapy, kidney‑tumour surgery, a stem‑cell transplant and weeks of radiotherapy at Manchester’s Christie Clinic, during which he wore a self‑decorated Ninja‑Turtle mask to feel braver; after a year of treatment he was declared cancer‑free, will undergo regular follow‑ups, and his story—highlighted by Nickelodeon’s gift of Ninja‑Turtle presents, a Cancer Research UK Little Star award and his role as the face of the charity’s Kids & Teens campaign—has drawn attention to neuroblastoma, a rare childhood cancer affecting fewer than 100 UK children annually, typically under five, with unknown causes, varied symptoms, and treatment that may include surgery, chemotherapy, antibody therapy and radiotherapy.

Tim Sherwood urges 19‑year‑old Jack Grealish to concentrate on cementing his place in Aston Villa’s first team rather than worrying about his international future, after his impressive performance in Villa’s FA Cup semi‑final win over Liverpool; while Grealish is currently caught in a tug‑of‑war between the Republic of Ireland and England, Sherwood says the choice is entirely up to him—much like Nabil Bentaleb’s decision to play for Algeria—and his father agrees that he should focus on club football and gain more Villa appearances before making a final national‑team decision.
