Landing fees for private jets vary widely, with Japan’s three major airports topping the list—Haneda charging £4,559 ($6,850), Narita £3,728 ($5,600) and Kansai £3,594 ($5,400) per 767‑400 landing—while other costly sites include Toronto’s Pearson (£3,461/$5,200), Darwin (£3,059/$4,600), Bristol (£2,929/$4,400), La Guardia (£2,630/$3,950), Dublin (£2,729/$4,100) and Salzburg (£2,530/$3,800); the private‑jet market is a multi‑trillion‑dollar industry with 2.5 million U.S. flights and 705,000 European flights recorded in 2013, and peak demand occurs during events like the Super Bowl and Monaco Grand Prix, where round‑trip charter costs can reach $38,000–$54,000, while popular routes such as Los Angeles‑Las Vegas (£2,890/$4,340) and Milan‑Rome (≈$5,880 one‑way) illustrate the high‑value travel that drives these fees.

Katie Gallegos of Clackamas County, Oregon, who runs Dogpatch Resort, took her fast‑eating Labrador Cooper and a smaller pup named Daisy to a McDonald’s drive‑thru for ice cream, where Daisy took a few dainty licks while Cooper gulped the rest of the cone in one bite; she always lets Daisy eat first because Cooper always eats quickly, and the video of the outing has amassed over seven million views, drawing both cute reactions and criticism for feeding the dogs a creamy treat, which Gallegos defends by noting Cooper’s excellent health and her own past dog’s occasional ice‑cream habit, and she later posted another clip of the pair at Starbucks getting a “pup‑uccino” (whipped cream only) that Cooper also devoured in one go.

Gary Locke, the former Hearts manager who joined Kilmarnock as Allan Johnston’s assistant last summer, has been appointed the club’s permanent manager on a three‑year contract after serving as interim boss since February when his ex‑Tynecastle teammate resigned; during his interim spell he lost only once in seven games, will address a press conference on Friday, and was photographed shaking hands with chairman Jim Mann upon signing the deal.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp of Eustis, says Seminole County elementary threatened to suspend her five‑year‑old autistic son, Logan, because he wears DoTerra essential oils—lavender, chamomile and sandalwood—applied to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused, but teachers claimed the scents were a distraction to other students; Kemp received a school‑board letter labeling the oils a “problem” for staff and students, yet she intends to fight the decision, and after the dispute Lake County school officials later clarified they would not suspend Logan, describing the issue as a health matter.

A beach‑side apartment complex in Westhampton, known as the Sandpiper complex and used as a holiday home from May to November, was devastated by a fire on Wednesday at about 3 p.m., destroying 90 condos and causing the building to collapse; the blaze was so intense it melted paint from nearby structures, produced black smoke visible three miles out over the ocean, and thwarted twelve fire crews who could not enter the units, while investigators consider a possible ignition source near a parked car, and residents and the building manager reported total loss of property.

At 88, the queen celebrated a spring‑time ride in Windsor Great Park on her black Fell pony Carltonlima Emma, forgoing a helmet in favor of a silk scarf, a habit she has maintained since she first rode a Shetland pony named Peggy at age four; despite a lingering knee injury that has limited her riding and ended her participation in trooping the colour, she remains an avid equestrienne, breeding Fell and Highland ponies at her Hampton Court stud and Balmoral, while her grandchildren also ride some of her horses, and the passage notes that Fell ponies—hardy, docile animals native to Cumbria since the Neolithic—have served as pack and trade animals for the Carvetii, Romans, Vikings, Normans, and during the industrial era before becoming popular family riding ponies in the 1950s.

An argument over noise between Brisbane neighbours escalated when 28‑year‑old shift worker Phillip Pama confronted 55‑year‑old Leon Yeaman, who was making loud music in his yard on Muller Road around 9 pm; Pama allegedly struck Yeaman once in the head, causing Yeaman’s death at the scene around 11 pm, and Pama was subsequently charged with manslaughter, granted conditional bail with passport surrender, a curfew from 6 pm to 2 am and twice‑weekly police reporting, with a further court date set for May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52‑year‑old Russian music teacher, tried to hire a hitman to torture and kill her 15‑year‑old former pupil Damian Vanya after he ended their year‑long relationship; offering 100,000 ruble (about £1,400), she told an undercover police officer posing as a hitman that she wanted the boy beaten, his arms, legs and kidneys broken, to bleed out and then be finished off, and was filmed doing so before being arrested in a sting operation and charged with attempted murder, facing up to 15 years in prison, while Vanya expressed relief at her capture.

Jose Mourinho, seen with his wife Matilde Faria at the 2014 Victoria’s Secret fashion show, says he prays daily and talks to God about his personal life but never about football, keeping his professional and family spheres separate; he attends church only when he feels the need, especially in Portugal, and, as a World Food Programme ambassador, is aware of poverty and supports hunger‑relief efforts, describing himself as a good family man and friend who acknowledges mistakes despite his competitive, emotional profession, while noting Chelsea’s current league‑top position and recalling a £25,000 fine earlier in the season for alleging a “campaign” against the club.

Bob Barker, the longtime host of “The Price Is Right” who stepped down in 2007 after 35 years, returned to the show on April 1 for the first time in eight years; at 91, he led the opening “Lucky Seven” price‑guessing game before handing hosting duties back to Drew Carey.

An off‑duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested at 12:30 a.m. on Friday in Washington, D.C., after allegedly trying to break into a house on the 3200 block of D Street SE; he faces felony charges of attempted burglary and destruction of property, has had his security clearance revoked and been placed on leave, and is assigned to the agency’s foreign missions branch that supports diplomatic activities, with a court arraignment set for Friday afternoon, while the agency simultaneously deals with separate misconduct investigations involving a high‑ranking supervisor and other officials.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, a 38‑year‑old from Lahore, Pakistan, was at a city safari park when he spotted a hungry male lion and, armed only with his camera, left his car to approach the animal, getting within about 10 feet before lying on the ground to shoot a few frames; the camera’s shutter sound alerted the lion, which aggressively lunged toward him, forcing Saeed to scramble back into his car in a close‑call encounter.

New York City police have released images of a distinctive heart‑shaped tattoo bearing the name “Monique” on the right leg of an unidentified woman, hoping to determine her identity; the woman, estimated to be 25‑45 years old, was found unconscious on March 22 near Shore Parkway and 26th Avenue in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, could not be revived by paramedics, and was pronounced dead that evening, with no personal identification found, while investigators await the medical examiner’s report on the cause of death and have asked anyone with information to contact NYPD Crime Stoppers at 800‑577‑TIPS.

Hannah and Alex, a New Zealand couple returning from the UK, bought a 1986 Hino flatbed truck and spent about a year and a half constructing a solar‑powered, two‑bedroom wood‑and‑steel home on its bed after they could not afford a traditional property; the self‑sufficient residence, featuring a wood‑fired stove, gas‑heated water, stained‑glass windows, spring water, and solar panels that reduced their first power bill to $25, sits on a lot they purchased in Nelson, cost roughly $25,000 to build, and has inspired them to consider building another similar home.

Researchers led by Courtney Blackwell at Northwestern University studied 352 kindergarten students in a Midwestern suburban district and found that children who shared iPads in class over an academic year scored about 30 points higher on early literacy tests than peers who either used a personal iPad or had no iPads at all, indicating that collaborative learning around the technology—not merely collaboration itself—drives the improvement and suggesting schools should reconsider tablet use, especially in early grades, to maximize effectiveness.

A piglet born without hind legs in Qionglai, Sichuan, has learned to balance and walk on its two front trotters, earning the nickname “super pig” and becoming an internet sensation after a heart‑warming video showed its unsteady, snout‑low steps while foraging for food; despite frequent near‑tips, it consistently regains balance, mingles with its four‑legged littermates, and draws crowds of villagers, while its owner, farmer Ms Duan, notes the piglet’s unique condition, a phenomenon echoed by other two‑legged animals such as a rabbit at Liuzhou Zoo that also gained fame in China.

During the inaugural IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, Dayle Coyne Racing front‑outside tire changer Todd Phillips was injured when Francesco Dracone’s car, entering for tires and fuel on lap 25, spun while exiting his pit box and clipped Phillips’s leg; Phillips received stitches at the infield care center and was released, while many cars struggled with traction after hours of rain, and Dracone, who spun on turn one, did not finish the race, ending up 23rd.

Milton Vieira Severiano, a 32‑year‑old man from Rio de Janeiro, brutally murdered his 29‑year‑old dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena of the “Jaula das Gostozuedas” troupe, by repeatedly smashing her head into concrete, punching her, and then shooting her in the face five times, claiming he acted out of jealousy over men looking at her and calling her a “slut”; after the killing he stole a neighbor’s car, crashed it, and was stopped by police who found four handguns, a shotgun and a bullet‑proof vest in the vehicle, and he now faces a life sentence.

Sarah Wilson, the 41‑year‑old journalist and author of the bestseller “I Quit Sugar,” disclosed in an interview with Women’s Weekly Australia that severe anxiety, compounded by mounting stress, thyroid disease, distant family and isolation, drove her to a point where she could not see a reason to continue living and came close to suicide; she noted that depression and anxiety are intrinsically linked, describing anxiety as the “new depression,” and emphasized the need to recognize this connection to better address the rising rates of anxiety among Australian women—one in three will experience it in their lifetime—while also sharing that she has recently found some peace and encouraging anyone in need to contact Beyond Blue (1300 224 636) or Lifeline (13 11 14).

Elena Curtin, a 23‑year‑old from Portland who was seven months pregnant, was charged with second‑degree assault after she returned home in November 2014 and beat her boyfriend’s heroin‑using ex‑girlfriend with a crowbar when the woman refused to leave the bathroom; prosecutors dropped the charge on the grounds that Curtin was “completely justified in her outrage,” citing Oregon law that permits force against an intruder, and she avoided a potential six‑year prison sentence, gave birth in January, and now lives with her parents while the couple’s former partners have reconciled.

Gemma, a pit bull living in California, was filmed being given treats when her owner added a broccoli spear to test her reaction; the dog immediately displayed disgust, chewed the vegetable, and spat it out onto the floor, prompting a hope that the children she lives with won’t imitate her and will instead learn to enjoy greens, while other videos show Gemma sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC apologized after a hyperlink on its official site, originally leading to the now‑defunct Young Entrepreneur Awards page, mistakenly redirected visitors to a pornographic website that had taken over the address after the awards were discontinued in 2011; the bank removed the link, denied any association with the external site, affirmed that its website remains secure, and expressed regret for any inconvenience caused.

A 13‑year‑old boy named Marcus in Clinton, Maryland, called 911 after a fire started on the first floor of his home on Sunday morning, trapping him and his 9‑year‑old sister Aaliyah in a second‑floor bedroom that was too hot to exit through the hallway. During an 11‑minute call, Marcus calmly directed firefighters to the room, soothed his sister’s panic, and gave instructions on how to reach them. Prince George’s County firefighters entered the home, broke a window, and rescued the siblings, with a veteran firefighter handing Marcus out the window and giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both children were taken to Children’s Hospital with non‑life‑threatening injuries, while their older brother, mother, and step‑father escaped on their own and were taken to MedStar Hospital.

Blue fluorescent algae (Noctiluca scintillans), a single‑celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, lit up Australia’s east coast, with striking photos taken at Jervis Bay on the south coast of New South Wales where photographer Andy Hutchinson called the neon‑glowing beach a “beautiful supernatural scene” caused by millions of plankton emitting light; a similar display occurred at Sydney’s Manly Beach in August 2014, and University of New South Wales expert Iain Suthers explained that the carnivorous cells prey on diatoms and produce the glow as a natural defence mechanism, with about 90 % of occurrences being due to natural causes.

New genetic tests, such as EndoPredict, can assess breast cancer aggressiveness after surgery by analyzing tumour markers, allowing doctors to identify patients with a low (as low as 5%) risk of recurrence and potentially spare them from chemotherapy and its severe side effects; while currently offered privately for about £2,500, experts argue NHS adoption could offset costs by reducing chemotherapy use, as illustrated by a patient whose low test score led her to forgo chemo despite a second cancer diagnosis.

More than 25 women have been air‑lifted from Royal Navy vessels because of pregnancy, including five from HMS Ocean and at least one from the decommissioned HMS Illustrious (nicknamed “HMS Lusty”), with eighteen other ships such as HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise and HMS Richmond also conducting emergency evacuations; a Ministry of Defence spokesman noted a strict “no‑touching” rule at sea, implying the pregnancies began before boarding or during leave, and this data follows the incident in which Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a warship, was flown back to the UK amid allegations of a sexual relationship with a crew member, prompting an investigation and her replacement; women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, comprising about 9 % of personnel in 2014, and in May 2015 three women became the first female submariners, while similar evacuations occurred in Afghanistan (99 servicewomen between 2006‑2013, including 16 in 2013 and 18 in 2011) and Iraq (102 women), reflecting strict military rules that bar pregnant personnel from war zones and result in their return on flights usually reserved for injured troops.

A drone carrying a small camera, smoke flares and a plastic bottle with traces of cesium was discovered on the rooftop of Japan’s prime‑ministerial residence, prompting police and officials to warn of possible terrorism, especially ahead of the Olympics and a G7 summit; investigators noted the drone’s 50‑centimetre size and that the cesium amount was not immediately harmful, while Japanese law restricts drone flights only near airports, leaving most of Tokyo, including government buildings, unrestricted, and the incident coincided with a court’s approval to restart two reactors at the Sendai nuclear plant—a move championed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe but unpopular with many citizens, though Abe was abroad in Indonesia at the time.

Lu Xincai, a security guard in Zhejiang, China, brings his 84‑year‑old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer’s and often gets lost, to work each day by riding his motorbike with her on the back, securing both with a sash; after his father’s death and with his wife living elsewhere and his son in school, he feels responsible for her care, slowly traveling the four‑kilometre route so they can talk, and even at his bank workplace he checks on her in a dedicated room to ensure she does not wander off.

Heavy drinking among U.S. adults rose 17.2 % between 2005 and 2012, driven largely by increasing rates among women, with the CDC defining heavy drinking as more than one drink per day for women and two for men and binge drinking as four (women) or five (men) drinks on a single occasion; over the decade, women’s binge‑drinking rate grew more than seven times faster than men’s, leading to 8 % of Americans being classified as heavy drinkers and 18 % as binge drinkers in 2012, while overall alcohol use remained stable; county data showed wide variation (e.g., 6 % binge drinking in Madison County, Idaho, versus 36 % in Menominee, Wisconsin, and 2 % heavy drinkers in Hancock County, Tennessee, versus 22 % in Esmeralda County, Nevada); the study, based on about 3.7 million adults from the CDC’s Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System, noted that alcohol‑related deaths numbered 88,600 in 2010 and excess‑drinking costs exceeded $220 billion annually, and experts linked the rise to shifting social norms that make heavy drinking more acceptable for women, greater affluence and cheaper alcohol, increased advertising, and weakened control policies.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections in England far too often, putting women and babies at risk of infections, complications, disability or death, and diverting funds from other patients; although more than a quarter of births now involve a caesarean—a rate that has more than doubled since the early 1990s—the World Health Organization says the ideal proportion should be only 10‑15 % and that the procedure should be done only when medically necessary, noting that planned caesareans cost the NHS about £2,369 versus £1,665 for natural birth and that as many as one in ten caesareans cause infections, a stance that conflicts with current NHS and NICE guidelines which allow the operation for anxiety (tokophobia), previous complicated births, age over 40, or conditions such as asthma, diabetes or depression.

Michelle Filkins, a 44‑year‑old woman from West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 after Mark Conklin discovered her living in his $800,000 summer home on Martha’s Vineyard, where she claimed ownership, fled in a gray Nissan pickup, and later attempted to re‑enter; she is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property after allegedly staying in the house for at least a week and holding a yard sale of stolen items—including deck chairs, a grill, side tables, lamps, posters, cookware, linens and a painting—and police are urging anyone who received these goods to return them and have contacted the Edgartown Police Department, with her next court appearance set for May 14.

Bella Crooke from Melbourne lost her iPhone at a friend’s birthday party, and after dialing it a security guard turned it in to Albury police on the NSW‑Victoria border; the unlocked phone was used by officers to post humorous selfies, puns and photos—including a “holding cell” picture—on her Facebook page to inform her it was safe and could be collected, prompting jokes from friends and the police replying to messages on her behalf; Bella arrived later, was recognized from her Facebook profile without needing to give her name, reclaimed the fully charged phone, and has since set a password, praising the officers for their good humor.

A five‑day‑old hippopotamus calf in South Africa’s iSimangaliso Wetland Park was fatally caught in a prolonged fight between two adult male hippos; as the adults tussled, a sub‑adult grabbed the calf, its mother tried to intervene by attacking the aggressor’s neck, which caused the calf to be flung into the air and dragged across the water’s surface, and the infant died of its injuries hours later while the mother watched in horror, an event witnessed by tour operator Stacey Farrell.

A three‑bedroom, 1,990 sq ft maisonette in Knightsbridge’s exclusive Egerton Place has been listed for £575,000, far below the £1.5 million price of the next cheapest three‑bedroom flat, but it carries only a three‑year lease and requires extensive modernisation; if the lease were extended—potentially costing £3.35‑£4.5 million for a 90‑year term—the property could be worth around £6 million, with a modernised value estimated at £2,750‑£3,000 per sq ft, while a larger neighbouring maisonette could reach £7.5 million; the flat includes three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking and a communal garden, and the current freeholder is thought to be the Welcome Trust, with agents warning that the short lease represents a significant premium for any buyer.

Starbucks announced that a computer outage, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, disrupted point‑of‑sale registers at 8,000 company‑operated stores in the United States and Canada—7,000 in the U.S. and 1,000 in Canada—preventing credit‑card transactions and prompting many baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods, while some locations closed early to avoid further giveaways; the glitch also affected Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores, but was resolved by Saturday, allowing stores to resume normal business, and the incident occurred just after the Seattle‑based chain reported record quarterly earnings of $4.6 billion, with its shares rising 4.4 % to $51.50.

Terrorist training and radicalisation are now taking place in rural West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys and Pembrokeshire, where individuals blend into ordinary community activities while pursuing extremist aims, according to Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter‑Terrorism Unit; the region’s history of Islamic extremist activity dates back to 1998 when Abu Hamza allegedly sent ten extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons, includes 2005 sightings of two 7/7 bombers white‑water rafting in North Wales, a 2010 Al‑Qaeda‑inspired plot by three Cardiff men, and connections to the Lee Rigby murder through Michael Adebowale’s Arabic studies at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llandybydder, while secret meetings among suspects Omar Latif, Gurukanth Desai, Abdul Miah, Mohammed Chowdhury and Shah Rahman were photographed in a Welsh country park, prompting Jones to stress that terrorism is not confined to large cities and that community intelligence is vital for authorities.

A juvenile 5.68‑metre female Omura’s whale, a species once feared extinct and only described in scientific literature in 2003, was found washed up on a remote Exmouth beach in Western Australia after Cyclone Olwyn, marking the first sighting in WA and only the second in Australia; after initial difficulty, Department of Parks and Wildlife staff confirmed its identity through DNA profiling, and Environment Minister Albert Jacob called the discovery highly significant because little is known about the whale, which is normally restricted to tropical and subtropical waters of Indonesia, the Philippines and the Sea of Japan and is distinguished by a sleek body, 53 vertebrae and four digits on each pectoral fin, with the carcass now buried and its skeleton slated for recovery in a few years for further scientific study and possible museum display.

The passage reports on Texas CEO Cheryl Rios’s claim that a woman’s hormones make her unsuitable for the presidency, using Hillary Clinton as an example, while also noting that male hormones have historically impaired male leaders; it then shifts to a broader discussion of entrenched gender bias in the workplace and politics, citing studies and examples that show women face both overt and covert discrimination, that bias limits women’s advancement despite their numerical superiority in education and the workforce, and that greater gender equality benefits companies, families, and society, concluding that overcoming stereotypes—not biochemistry—is essential for women to achieve leadership roles.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy, 89, is downsizing his Cotswolds home by auctioning more than 200 antiques valued at around £100,000 in a 238‑lot sale at Dominic Winter’s saleroom in South Cerney, Gloucestershire, this Saturday; the collection, built from his lifelong interests in classic literature and military history, includes a hand‑painted lime‑wood diorama of the 1415 Battle of Agincourt commissioned from L.M. Rendall, a yew longbow with mother‑of‑pearl handle, a portrait of Hardy holding the bow, early Victorian furniture, paintings, swords, flintlock rifles, silverware, crystal chandeliers, and dozens of books dating back to the 17th century, while Hardy—who studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and C.S. Lewis at Oxford, published two books on the medieval longbow, and was consulted on the Tudor ship Mary Rose—expressed sadness at parting with his treasured library but hopes new owners will enjoy the items as he has; he is best known for his roles as veterinarian Siegfried Farnon in “All Creatures Great and Small,” multiple portrayals of Winston Churchill, and Cornelius Fudge in the “Harry Potter” films, and despite retiring from stage work after a fall, he intends to continue television acting.

Michael Scott Shemansky, a Florida man on parole for battery against law‑enforcement and with a history of bipolar illness and a prior psychiatric commitment, became a murder suspect after his mother, Sandra Shemansky (57), was found dead at their Winter Garden home on the day he missed a court‑ordered supervised visit with his son; authorities say he fled the scene on foot, was seen briefly asking for water, and has been on the run since Saturday, while police hold the undisclosed murder weapon and urge anyone with information to call 407‑656‑3636.

Eugene, United States, was granted the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships after the IAAF Council bypassed the normal bidding process, citing a “unique strategic opportunity” involving public authorities, the private sector, the national Olympic committee, NBC and an enthusiastic public; the city had previously lost its 2019 bid to Doha, Qatar, but a recent presentation convinced the governing body of its capability, a decision echoed by IAAF President Lamine Diack as a move to access a key market and support global sport development, similar to the 2007 Osaka championships which were also awarded without bidding, and the passage notes Mo Farah’s 2013 gold in the men’s 10,000 m in Moscow.

Leonie Granger, a 25‑year‑old aspiring model from Gillingham, Kent, used her looks to befriend 56‑year‑old professional gambler Mehmet Hassan after spotting him flashing £50 notes at a West End casino, luring him to his flat where she let in her boyfriend Kyrron Jackson and accomplice Nicholas Chandler; the trio tied Hassan up, kicked him to death, ransacked his home for hidden winnings and fled with about £3,000, after which Granger was found guilty of manslaughter and sentenced to 16 years, while Jackson and Chandler were convicted of murder and received life sentences with a minimum term of 36 years.

Chelsea midfielder Cesc Fabregas, once a prolific play‑maker who had amassed 15 Premier League assists by mid‑January and seemed poised to challenge Thierry Henry’s record of 20 assists in a season, has fallen into his familiar post‑Christmas slump, delivering a poor performance in Spain’s 2‑0 defeat to the Netherlands and being rated only four out of ten by a Spanish newspaper; his statistics have dropped sharply to just one assist in his last five games and four in 15 appearances for club and country in 2015, raising concerns about his durability as Chelsea chase the title, though manager José Mourinho remains hopeful that Fabregas can rediscover form, as evidenced by his recent assist for Diego Costa in a 3‑2 win over Hull City, and that a late‑season resurgence could help secure the Premier League crown.

West Ham are close to signing 17‑year‑old Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, who impressed during a two‑week trial with the club’s academy and has attracted interest from Belgian sides and other European teams as one of the Caribbean’s top prospects, while the club also announced that season tickets for the Olympic Stadium will start at £289 – the lowest price in the Premier League – to help fill the 54,000‑seat venue for the 2016‑17 season.

Police have halted a murder‑investigation into the January 24 assault on Mike Lane, a 40‑year‑old joint master of the Tedworth Hunt, after three months despite video, a dossier of evidence, suspect photos and car registrations linking balaclava‑clad protesters who beat him with iron‑bar‑tipped ropes, kicked him in the head, and caused concussion, broken teeth, facial swelling and memory loss; Lane and hunt supporters condemn the decision as “pathetic” and “disgraceful,” arguing that the evidence was provided, while Wiltshire Police say the inquiry is pending further information and remains “undetected” until new evidence emerges.

Adam Gadahn (born 1978, later known as “Azzam the American” and Abu Suhayb) was a U.S. citizen who converted to Islam in 1995, left the United States for Pakistan in 1998, and became al Qaeda’s most prominent English‑language propagandist, appearing in videos that threatened attacks, urged lone‑wolf assaults, and praised terrorist acts; he was indicted in 2006 by a California grand jury for treason and material support, listed among the FBI’s most‑wanted terrorists, and was killed in a U.S. counter‑terrorism operation in January, a death announced by the White House, which also noted the separate killing of fellow al Qaeda operative Ahmed Farouq and the hostage Warren Weinstein.

Chinese parents’ enthusiasm for child prodigies has turned to basketball with five‑year‑old Mai Zizhuo, who has been shooting hoops since age two‑and‑a‑half and recently went viral in a Chinese video that shows him scoring a string of baskets, dribbling two balls simultaneously without losing rhythm, and maintaining focused eye contact with the camera; the clip has earned him a massive fanbase across basketball‑obsessed China, prompting thousands of netizen comments ranging from disbelief and jokes about special effects to curiosity about his father, while the nation’s most famous basketball figure, former NBA star Yao Ming, serves as a backdrop to Mai’s rising fame.

Tom O’Carroll, a former leading activist for the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE)—the 1970s‑80s group that campaigned to legalise child sex and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL) to lower the age of consent and legalise incest—has joined the supporters of the media‑pressure group Hacked Off, attending its rally in the Houses of Parliament on 25 February to lobby MPs for a statutory press‑regulation body as recommended by the Leveson inquiry; the meeting, chaired by comedian John Cleese, was open to the public, and O’Carroll later blogged about his participation, a development described as an embarrassment for Hacked Off, while noting his past roles as an Open University information officer, a member of NCCL’s gay‑rights sub‑committee, and his 1981 conviction for “corrupting public morals.”

Mercedes‑Benz Fashion Week Australia transformed Bondi’s iconic Icebergs Club pool into a catwalk after draining the water, staging a ten‑piece monochrome capsule by the unisex label Ten Pieces—headed by Icebergs restaurateur Maurice Terzini and partner Lucy Hinckfuss—designed to be worn in 20 ways and suitable for both sexes; models walked through the empty concrete pool and along the break wall against an ocean backdrop while guests enjoyed nibbles from Icebergs, drinks from Santa Vittoria, and sunny 28 °C weather, with onlookers gathering on the balcony, the road above, and the beach to watch the minimalist, androgynous show.

Bolton‑born boxer Amir Khan spent a family day at a Northern California safari park, where he, his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa posed with giraffes, sea lions and fed a rare white tiger at Six Flags Discovery Kingdom, and later announced that his next bout will be against former light‑welterweight champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about a potential fight with British rival Kell Brook or other opponents such as Adrien Broner or Keith Thurman.

A Palestinian teenager, Mohammed Abu Khdeir, who was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July, had his name mistakenly added to the national memorial wall at Jerusalem’s Mount Herzl—normally reserved for fallen soldiers and terror victims—prompting objections from his father, who said he was never asked for permission and refused to have his son listed among “soldiers of the occupation,” as well as from Almagor, an Israeli victims‑of‑terror organization that labeled the killing a rogue attack and argued he should not be recognized as a terror victim; after Almagor’s CEO Meir Indor wrote to the National Insurance Institute of Israel demanding removal and threatened to have other names taken off if the request was ignored, the institute announced it would delete Abu Khdeir’s name from the memorial, and his name has also been removed from the organization’s website, while a panel of judges continues to hear evidence against the three suspects in his killing.

California‑based YouTuber Lionel Hutz recorded his young son repeatedly trying to rest his head on the family cat’s belly in the garden; the cat, after briefly staying still and licking its fur, promptly moves to a new spot each time, prompting the boy to follow and lie down again, and after a few cycles the cat finally leaves, after which a later video shows the pair reconciling as the child gently feeds the cat treats.

A police corruption trial in Philadelphia remains ongoing, and one of the more than a dozen former drug dealers testifying for the federal government, 32‑year‑old Robert Kushner, lost his varsity basketball coaching position at the Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after his testimony about years selling marijuana; he told jurors that undercover officers had stolen $81,000 in cash and seven pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest, a case whose charges were later expunged as part of a probation sentence, though he was arrested again in 2011 and received four years’ probation and had pleaded guilty to a 2008 DUI, and while he says he never intended to deceive the school and believes he is innocent of the 2011 charges, the six former drug‑squad officers accused of racketeering claim the government’s case relies on lying drug dealers and a rogue ex‑cop.

An explosion at the paraxylene‑producing plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian province injured six people, five from broken glass, and sparked a large fire that was later brought under control by more than 600 firefighters; the blast occurred at an oil storage facility after a leak, though no toxic chemical spill was reported, and the plant—previously the site of a 2013 explosion without casualties—has been a focal point of protests against PX factories, leading to its relocation from Xiamen to a more remote site after a 2007 backlash over pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, the Aston Villa teenager and Republic of Ireland under‑21 international, insists on keeping his socks low over his shin‑pads—a superstition he’s followed all his life and refuses to change despite referees’ comments, even though he uses children’s‑size shin‑pads; after making his first Premier League start in Villa’s 3‑3 draw with QPR, he said the tough, relegation‑scrap match was a boost, he’s pleased with the manager’s faith and hopes to earn more starts before season’s end.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, the 22‑year‑old daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, suffers from global, irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive after nearly three months in a medically induced coma, with no response to visitors or familiar voices and a tracheostomy in place; her grandmother Cissy Houston expressed sorrow and hope for a miracle, while her father claimed she is awake and watching him, and the family’s attorney noted that although doctors say she may live a long life, her quality of life and rehabilitation outcomes will not be known for years.

Russia took a 2‑0 lead in their Fed Cup tie after Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point and defeated Germany’s Sabine Lisicki 4‑6, 7‑6(4), 6‑3, while Svetlana Kuznetsova earlier beat Julia Goerges in straight sets; despite Pavlyuchenkova’s 13 double faults, Lisicki’s 63 unforced errors proved decisive, and Russia now needs just one win from Sunday’s three matches to reach the final and claim its first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales, still reeling from last week’s severe weather, have been warned that an east‑coast low – the same system that battered the coast for three days – is expected to return later this week, bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday and raising flood levels, especially in the already‑saturated Hunter region where flooding and high winds caused extensive damage; the State Emergency Service, which fielded thousands of calls and still has 4,409 of 24,196 jobs unfinished, is concerned the new storms will hinder clean‑up efforts and is urging communities to prepare homes and families, while meteorologists note the approaching trough will be farther offshore and likely less intense over Sydney, with forecasts calling for showers and mild temperatures across Sydney, Newcastle, Gosford and Wollongong.

Nina Moric, the 38‑year‑old model who appeared in Ricky Martin’s “La Vida Loco” video, refuted Italian media reports that she attempted suicide, explaining that she collapsed at home on Saturday night from low blood pressure, suffered a head injury and bruises, and was treated in hospital before recovering at home; she posted photos of her injuries on Instagram, denied claims made by her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso and others, and clarified that he was in Naples at the time, while also noting past media speculation about a 2009 overdose; Moric was previously married to paparazzo Fabrizio Corona, who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities, and they share a son, Carlos Maria, born in 2002.

A YouGov poll for The Sunday Times found that as Kate and William await their second child, 12 % of the 2,200 Britons surveyed favor the name Diana for a girl—after William’s mother—while Alice and Charlotte each received 9 % of the vote; for a boy, 13 % chose James with Alexander as the runner‑up, and a quarter of respondents hoped for a daughter compared with only 3 % who wanted another son, sentiments echoed on Twitter. The poll also showed strong public support for William’s decision to take six weeks of paternity leave, with 68 % approving.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near a group of protesters in Khost, eastern Afghanistan, on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding 64, including Afghan lawmaker Humayoon Humayoon; the protesters were on their way to a larger rally against the provincial governor, the attack occurred around 10 a.m. local time, the Taliban denied involvement, and no other group has claimed responsibility.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after his agent, Dinorah Santana, confirmed the 31‑year‑old right‑back rejected the club’s final contract offer—a three‑year extension contingent on him playing in at least 60 % of matches—ending negotiations; Alves spent seven seasons at the Catalan club, winning four Spanish titles and two Champions League trophies, but could not agree on a new deal and will depart the Nou Camp.

Pablo Osvaldo, now on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and having scored three goals in six games, has urged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to move to Argentina and join him, arguing that their South‑American style would suit Boca, that the fans would go “absolutely crazy” to see them play at La Bombonera, and that both players would be well‑received and fit perfectly with the team.

Lewis Ferguson, an 18‑year‑old amateur jockey, suffered a spectacular double‑somersault fall from his horse at Wincanton that went viral online, but he escaped with only a cut on his nose; despite the incident, he returned to Paul Nicholls’ yard on Thursday morning to muck out the stables like any other apprentice, received supportive comments from fellow jockeys, joked about the attention and potential gymnastics prospects, and noted he gained a few hundred Twitter followers from the “good banter.”

James Haskell, the England flanker and London Wasps captain, celebrated the release of *Avengers: Age of Ultron* by posting an Instagram photo of himself in an Iron Man costume, captioning it “Avengers movie is out so thought I would release the inner Iron Man” with related hashtags; the film premiered at Westfield London, drawing crowds to see the A‑list cast. Haskell, a Windsor‑born player who first joined Wasps in 2002, spent eight seasons there before moving in 2009 to Stade Français, then to Japan’s Ricoh Black Rams after the 2011 World Cup, and later to New Zealand’s Highlanders (making 12 appearances) before returning to Wasps for the 2012 season, where he has since exceeded 100 club appearances and earned 57 England caps.

The wide‑leg trouser is a leading SS15 trend, offered in denim, cropped, printed or striped styles as a fresh alternative to skinny jeans, and can be worn confidently by pairing high‑heeled shoes that expose the foot and simple knit, shirt or tee tops to balance the volume; high‑waisted, longer lengths further elongate the leg, while denim is the easiest way to nail the look, as seen on Gucci’s SS15 runway and in high‑street versions like Topshop’s Miller jean, with additional billowing designs showcased by Celine, Stella McCartney and Poppy Delevingne at the AW15 Chloe show, and affordable options available from online label Finery London and astylealbum.com.

The University of Michigan chose to proceed with a campus screening of the film “American Sniper” after more than 200 students petitioned to cancel it, citing concerns that its portrayal of the Iraq war could reflect negatively on the Middle East and the region’s large Arab‑American community; a counter‑petition and backlash led vice president for student life E. Royster Harper to state that canceling the showing conflicted with the university’s commitment to freedom of expression, so the film will be shown as part of the UMIX series, with a family‑friendly “Paddington” screening offered as an alternative, and the decision was praised by football coach Jim Harbaugh.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter on Rottnest Island, Western Australia, on April 3, causing a large flame that struck a quokka; the animal survived with singed fur. Police questioned the men, seized video evidence, evicted them from the island, and each was charged with animal cruelty, with a court appearance scheduled for April 17 in Fremantle. Quokkas are small marsupials native to several West Australian islands, notably Rottnest and Bald Island.

102-year-old former New York nightclub dancer Alice Barker, who performed in the 1930s and 1940s at venues like the Cotton Club and Café Zanzibar alongside stars such as Bill “Bojangles” Robinson and Frank Sinatra, had never seen any motion pictures of herself because her films, photographs, and memorabilia were lost; with the help of filmmaker Mark Cantor of jazz‑on‑film.com and volunteers, a video of early music videos called “soundies” featuring her performances was assembled and shown to her at her nursing home, delighting the ageless dancer.

A recent OSV survey of 1,100 British adults shows that washing one’s own car is fading, with 31 % of men and three‑quarters of women never having done it and only 12 % of those who do so regularly; just 5 % have ever asked their children to wash the car for pocket money. The decline is attributed to factors such as Sunday shop openings, more live football, the growth of hand‑car‑wash services and the size of 4×4/off‑road vehicles, alongside reduced time and the availability of cheap automated washes. Nonetheless, owners tend to wash their cars during holidays—an estimated 15 million were cleaned over the Easter break—and regional habits vary, with Birmingham, Chelmsford and Sheffield seeing the most weekly washes, while Oxford, Bath and Edinburgh see the fewest; Audis, Toyotas and BMWs are most often washed by owners, whereas Range Rovers, Peugeots and Mercedeses are least likely.

Martin Skrtel praised Liverpool captain Steven Gerrard as one of the world’s best players and credited him with helping Skrtel settle at Anfield after his 2008 arrival, while acknowledging that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard but believing the club has potential replacements; Gerrard is set to feature in the FA Cup semi‑final against Aston Villa at Wembley, aiming to finish his Liverpool career with a final on his birthday (May 30) before moving to LA Galaxy, and both he and Skrtel could return to the lineup after serving three‑match bans for violent conduct in a March loss to Manchester United.

At 75, Jack Nicklaus hit a hole‑in‑one on the 130‑yard fourth hole of the Augusta National Par‑3 Contest, becoming the first player to ace that turf while playing alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw; he later recalled that he had simply set out to win the contest and make a hole‑in‑one. His ace was part of a day that saw five holes‑in‑one, matching the 2002 record, as Camilo Villegas followed with aces on the fourth and eighth holes but lost the title to Kevin Streelman in a playoff. Nicklaus, who became the youngest green‑jacket winner in 1963 and claimed his sixth in 1986, is one of only five men to complete a career Grand Slam.

Tornado sirens sounded Wednesday night in Kansas as storms produced multiple twister reports, including one about 6 mi northwest of Goddard (≈17 mi west of Wichita) that moved northeast, and additional sightings near Aetna in southwestern Kansas; nighttime tornadoes were highlighted as especially dangerous. The National Weather Service also noted a possible tornado in Potosi, Missouri, with accompanying wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage and water‑covered streets, while nearby areas reported dark clouds and baseball‑size hail. Further storms were forecast for Thursday across the Midwest, the Mississippi and Tennessee River valleys, and the southern Great Lakes.

Oklahoma reserve deputy Robert Bates, 73, pleaded not guilty to second‑degree manslaughter after he fatally shot Eric Harris during an April 2 weapons‑sting arrest, claiming he meant to stun Harris with a taser but mistakenly fired his gun; a judge nonetheless permitted Bates to travel to the Bahamas for a family vacation, drawing criticism from Harris’s family, while a preliminary hearing is set for July 2, Bates has apologized along with Sheriff Stanley Glanz, the family’s lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment because of donations and a friendship with the sheriff and that records were forged—a claim the sheriff’s office denies, though Bates’s training documents released by his lawyer show he had proper law‑enforcement training, and two other deputies involved have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor, the 26‑year‑old Irish fighter, is set to challenge Jose Aldo for the featherweight title in Las Vegas on July 11, marking Aldo’s eighth belt defence, and has recently added a tiger‑face tattoo to his stomach—joining an existing gorilla‑eating‑a‑heart design on his chest—while posting “if you see the tiger, it’s too late. You’re food.” McGregor has publicly claimed Aldo lacks the same motivation, saying the champion “doesn’t want the belt in his presence,” and during a March promotional tour in Dublin he seized Aldo’s belt and raised it before 5,000 home supporters, underscoring the fractious nature of their rivalry.

Australian prime minister Tony Abbott was cheered by about 50 people as he quickly downed a schooner of beer at a university‑sport function, prompting anti‑drinking campaigners and cultural studies professor Julie Robert to condemn the act as glorifying binge drinking and linking masculinity to heavy alcohol consumption; Robert warned that the performance‑oriented display encourages risky drinking habits and noted that media and political reactions—such as opposition leader Bill Shorten’s quip and health minister Sussan Ley’s defence—further normalize the behaviour, while also referencing past prime ministers like Bob Hawke who have similarly showcased drinking, and highlighting a shift in public attitudes toward binge drinking.

Indiana officials reported a sharp rise in HIV cases more than two weeks after Gov. Mike Pence approved a 30‑day emergency needle‑exchange program in Scott County, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary infections tied to the area, up from 106 the previous week; the outbreak, centered among intravenous drug users of the prescription painkiller Opana, prompted the distribution of 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants and the return of about 1,400 used ones, while a mobile unit boosted enrollment. Pence is reviewing health officials’ reports and will decide early next week whether to extend the program beyond April 25, amid debate over longer‑term needle‑exchange policies: Senate President Pro Tem David Long called the emergency response “the right reaction” but questioned its sustainability, the House passed a bill on April 7 to allow the 23 Indiana counties with the highest hepatitis‑C rates to establish exchanges (hepatitis C often co‑occurs with HIV), and a conference‑committee hearing is scheduled before the legislature’s April 29 adjournment. Critics note that federal law bans public funding for such programs, Pence’s order provided no money, and state agencies must find their own resources, raising concerns about the program’s long‑term viability.

An obsessive Arsenal fan quizzed his girlfriend, Saskia, with a school‑style exam about his favourite club—multiple‑choice, tables, and “in your own words” sections—marking her answers in red; she earned 43.5 out of 50 (87 %), impressing him enough to promise not to dump her, which he announced on Twitter alongside her posted snaps. The test covered Arsenal basics (e.g., what “FC” stands for, the fans’ nickname, current manager, kit type, starting‑XI, top scorers, 2014 FA Cup final score and winner, and why Arsenal is the best team), and she earned extra marks for creative answers such as calling Alexis Sánchez “buff” and Eden Hazard a “p***k.” Although she confused player positions and missed a few details, her boyfriend corrected wrong answers with capital letters and angry faces, ultimately grading her an “A.” The post attracted mixed reactions: many praised the couple as “proper GF material” and the boyfriend as a “legend,” while others thought the test was excessive, dubbing him a “biff‑head.”

Carlos Toro, a 66‑year‑old former mid‑level Medellín cartel member who fled Colombia in the 1980s, spent 27 years as a DEA informant—providing key intelligence that helped dismantle the cartel, capture drug lord Carlos Lehder and prosecute former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega—under the promise of U.S. citizenship; after retiring due to declining health, his promised citizenship never materialized, his temporary visa expired on January 1, and he now faces deportation, living illegally in the United States, unable to obtain a green card, passport, or Social Security benefits, and fearing death if returned to Colombia.

A 14‑year‑old girl in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh, allegedly gang‑raped by five village men when she stepped outside to relieve herself, set herself on fire with kerosene and is now in Delhi’s Safdarjung Hospital with about 70 % burns; her brother rescued her by dousing the flames, and the accused men have been arrested, amid a broader climate of heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India following recent high‑profile cases, bans on the documentary “India’s Daughter,” and widespread protests demanding greater protection for women.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal, eager to beat rivals Manchester City in the Sunday derby at Old Trafford, confirmed that Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw are still unfit and will miss the match, despite Van Persie's claim of fitness; most other players are training in good condition, with Wayne Rooney, David De Gea, Ángel Di María, Radamel Falcão and others preparing for the game. Van Gaal highlighted the importance of the three points to potentially finish second or third and secure a top‑four spot, avoiding a Champions‑League qualifying round, while noting the need to control aggression after a 1‑0 loss in the earlier encounter. He expressed enthusiasm for the derby atmosphere and praised the supportive United fans.

Arsenal and Liverpool supporters staged a coordinated protest at the Emirates Stadium during their lunchtime Premier League match, leaving seats empty for the first ten minutes and displaying banners that linked the league’s £5.14 billion TV‑rights deal to the steep £64 cheapest ticket price, which they described as “extortionate” and a symptom of football’s rising costs; organized by Arsenal’s Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool’s Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, the fans condemned the high prices, late kick‑offs and perceived commercialization, called for ticket reductions that match working‑class wages, and warned that without change a generation of supporters could be lost, with further protests planned after full‑time.

A newborn in Barnsley, West Yorkshire, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life‑threatening condition where the bile ducts are blocked, after her skin turned yellow shortly after birth; despite an initial surgery to unblock the ducts, doctors determined she needed a liver transplant to survive. With neither parent a suitable donor, the baby’s maternal aunt, Shanell Reader—her mother Jade’s twin sister—volunteered and was found to be an ideal match, donating part of her liver in November. The transplant succeeded, and after six weeks in hospital the infant, Star, returned home and has made a good recovery, though she will require ongoing blood and liver‑function tests and lifelong anti‑rejection medication. Biliary atresia affects about 1 in 16,000 newborns and can lead to liver failure and death if untreated; the Kasai procedure is a common early treatment, but in Star’s case a partial liver transplant was the only viable option.

Chelsea players took part in Audi’s Football Challenge, with Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake paired against teammates Loïc Rémy and Willian in a series of football‑shooting contests involving Audi cars. In the first round they scored by firing balls into a car boot, winning 5‑3, and they continued to dominate the next two rounds—sinking long‑range shots into convertibles and playing over a makeshift tennis net formed by a £127,000 Audi R8 V10 Plus—giving them a 6‑0 lead. The final round saw Rémy and Willian claim victory by shooting from long range, though Willian accidentally shattered a wing mirror on one of the Audis, prompting a humorous reaction from Rémy.

Robert J. Dellinger, a 54‑year‑old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire who held senior roles at PPG Industries, Sprint, Delphi and General Electric, pleaded guilty in February to negligent homicide for the December 7, 2013 crash in Lebanon, NH, that killed 24‑year‑old Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, her 29‑year‑old fiancé Jason Timmons, and their unborn child, and he also pleaded guilty to assault for the fetus’s death; at his Wednesday sentencing he asserted he was not suicidal despite earlier statements that he had tried to kill himself by driving his pickup across a median at over 100 mph, and he now faces a 12‑to‑24‑year prison term while also confronting a wrongful‑death suit, with his defense attributing his actions to Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac, and advanced multiple sclerosis; his wife Deborah described him as a man of ethics, integrity and modesty, and court records note he received a severance package exceeding $1 million in cash and stock when he left his job in 2011 and that a family trust holds four properties in Sunapee valued at about $3 million.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky was convicted of second‑degree murder for poisoning her five‑year‑old son, Garnett‑Paul Spears, by loading a lethal amount of salt into his feeding tube while he was hospitalized for multiple medical problems, and was sentenced to 20 years to life, avoiding the maximum 25‑years‑to‑life term; the New York judge noted her mental illness but called the crime “unfathomable in its cruelty,” while prosecutors argued she killed the boy to gain attention and used his illnesses for self‑aggrandizement, and her ex‑partner, the boy’s father Chris Hill, posted angry Facebook messages demanding she be placed in the general population and expressing a wish that she die in prison; Spears’ lawyer maintained her innocence, blamed hospital negligence, and announced plans to appeal, and she was held at Westchester County Jail pending sentencing.

Fears over two new influenza strains—H3N2 and B/Phuket—that caused a spike in deaths in Europe and the United States have led to an improved vaccine arriving in Australia a month later than planned, now covering H3N2, B/Phuket and H1N1; high‑risk groups such as the very young, the very old and most Indigenous Australians will receive free, government‑funded shots from 20 April, and experts, including Dr Alan Hampson, say the modified vaccine is worth the delay and should be taken by everyone, noting it will also be the formulation used in the next northern‑hemisphere winter.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln’s tomb are defending the site after a National Geographic article dismissed its interior as “having all the historical character of an office lobby,” while also confronting looming budget cuts in Illinois, where Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed dissolving the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb and folding it into another department amid a state financial crisis; the tomb’s hours and staffing have already been reduced after a $1.1 million funding cut for Springfield sites, and a recent incident found its iron door locked despite posted open‑hours, prompting concerns from the Lincoln Monument Association about further cuts, yet the agency notes that recent renovations—including $730,000 for lighting, $390,000 for waterproofing, and over $2.5 million in repairs—have left the tomb in “excellent physical condition,” describing its circular, marble‑and‑bronze interior, its reconstruction history (originally dedicated by President Grant in 1874, rebuilt in 1899 and 1930), and its significance as the 150th anniversary of Lincoln’s assassination is observed despite the criticism.

The passage highlights a resurgence of 1990s and early‑2000s fashion trends—such as bucket hats, camouflage prints, double denim, UGG boots, ultra‑short “Daisy Dukes,” Juicy Couture velour tracksuits, brightly coloured sunglasses, corsets worn as outerwear, and loose harem trousers—while noting that JNCO’s oversized rave jeans are also slated for a comeback, prompting criticism that many of these retro styles are impractical and should remain in the past.

The week’s trending stories ranged from natural wonders to pop‑culture quirks: after heavy rain in the New York area, four rainbows stretched across the early‑morning sky, captured by fashion CEO Amanda Curtis; rural China’s practice of hiring exotic dancers for wakes faced a new vice crackdown; Robert Downey Jr grew agitated during a UK Channel 4 interview about his private life; a Kardashian‑inspired “lip‑plumping” challenge—sucking on a jar to mimic Kylie Jenner—gained a hashtag; 102‑year‑old Alice Barker starred in a time‑travel short with filmmakers; a bomb‑themed prom proposal sparked accusations of racism from school officials; Ewan McGregor was announced as Lumière in “Beauty and the Beast,” drawing social‑media buzz; Johnny Depp appeared nearly unrecognizable in the “Black Mass” trailer; a pregnancy announcement referenced “The Fresh Prince of Bel‑Air,” and a military dad’s photobomb of his son was noted for its originality.

Serena Williams celebrated her 700th career win at the Miami Open with a giant cake, defeating Germany’s Sabine Lisicki 7‑6, 1‑6, 6‑3 to reach the semifinals, while Andy Murray was also honored with a cake after his 500th victory; Williams’ hopes of meeting sister Venus were ended when Venus lost to Spain’s Carla Suárez Navarro, and the world No. 1 now awaits a semifinal clash with Romania’s Simona Halep, who advanced after beating Sloane Stephens 6‑1, 7‑5.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human‑rights and women’s‑entrepreneurship activist who ran the second‑floor café T2F in Karachi—a colorful, graffiti‑adorned space that hosted discussions on technology, free speech and controversial topics like Balochistan—was shot dead at point‑blank range by two gunmen after she closed the venue on a Friday night, also wounding her mother; no group claimed responsibility and police gave no motive, but her murder sparked nationwide grief as she had become a prominent figure for humanism, love and tolerance, inspiring many young Pakistanis seeking secular wisdom and freedom of thought.

Mangu Ram, an 82‑year‑old Hindu who fled the 1947 partition to Jammu‑Kashmir at age 14, has spent seven decades living in a slum without the right to own property, vote or work in the state government—a status shared by roughly 100,000 “West Pakistan refugees” (WPRs) who, despite never having lived in Pakistan, are barred by a pre‑independence law that grants citizenship only to those born in the former undivided Kashmir and to about 35,000 Hindus who later arrived from Pakistan‑controlled Kashmir; the denial of these rights has trapped three generations in abject poverty, preventing children from entering state‑run colleges or state jobs, but the recent electoral success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s Hindu‑nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in the state’s coalition government has raised hopes among activists such as Labha Ram Gandhi that the WPRs may finally receive “state‑subject” status, though they warn they are prepared to protest violently if promises are not fulfilled.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, who scored the winner against Shonan Bellmare, is still weighing a potential summer move to Premier League leaders Chelsea after club president Naoki Ogane disclosed an offer believed to be around £4 million; Chelsea may loan him to partner club Vitesse Arnhem, but the 22‑year‑old wants a team where he can play regularly and develop. Former FC Tokyo boss Ranko Popović praised Muto’s intelligence, speed, strength and confidence, calling him a unique talent, while Chelsea manager José Mourinho acknowledged awareness of the Japanese international and noted that commercial interests—such as the club’s £200 million sponsorship with Yokohama Rubber—alongside financial‑fair‑play considerations influence transfer decisions, though the club still seeks quality players and prospects.

The passage praises Australia for abandoning its rule that barred overseas‑based players from national selection, arguing that England’s similar policy under coach Stuart Lancaster is outdated and harmful to its World Cup prospects; it cites examples such as Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell thriving with Toulon, Steffon Armitage’s improvement after moving to France, and the enhanced performances of Nick Abendanon and Jonny Wilkinson abroad, contending that England should select the best players regardless of club location to avoid “what‑ifs” and give the home‑nation team the strongest possible squad.

Firechat, an off‑grid messaging app that leverages Apple’s Multipeer Connectivity Framework (and a similar Android Bluetooth feature) to create local wireless mesh networks, has been downloaded over five million times and lets users chat without mobile or data signals within about 30 feet, though messages typically travel no farther than roughly 200 feet; Open Garden’s new egg‑shaped Greenstone device acts as a beacon and booster for these mesh networks, extending their reach by holding up to 1,000 recent messages, operating on a one‑year battery, and currently supporting Firechat within a 20‑foot range, with the goal of providing resilient communication for communities, neighborhoods, hospitals, festivals, protests, and other events where conventional connectivity may be unavailable.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle, a 5'3", 240‑lb married woman from New Jersey, uses her TED talk to reclaim the word “fat” as an honest, body‑positive descriptor rather than an insult, arguing that women are conditioned to deny their size despite widespread size discrimination that has risen 66 % in three decades and a cultural preference among girls aged 11‑17 for thinness. She cites research showing that greater exposure to diverse bodies increases acceptance and even preference for them, and she leverages her burlesque performances—started in 2012—to showcase a glamorous “fat” body and inspire confidence, noting that her first show, though initially nerve‑wracking, empowered her to feel “like she could walk through fire.” Since the 2014 talk was posted on YouTube three weeks ago, it has amassed nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback, including letters and a teenage girl’s email about reevaluating body image, suggesting that body‑positivity is gaining ground despite occasional negative comments.

Theo Walcott has spent much of the season on Arsenal’s bench, being named as a substitute in 17 of 33 league games and only making a brief appearance in the 0‑0 draw with Chelsea, while hoping to start again when the Gunners face Hull; despite his limited playing time, he featured in a Lanvin photoshoot with teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, Mesut Özil and runway model Olga Sherer, marking the fashion house’s role as Arsenal’s official tailor since 2013, and the squad will wear similar attire for the FA Cup final at Wembley.

An auction of legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker’s Cinovation Studio collection will be held at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and online at PropStore.com on May 29, featuring over 400 items—including 417 original pieces from more than 50 productions—estimated at a total of $746,100, with several lots expected to exceed $40,000 such as the “Alien Edgar” bug from Men in Black ($40,000) and the “Mikey” costume from the same film ($30,000); other notable items include a Two‑Face mask from Batman Forever ($1,500), the Grinch costume from How the Grinch Stole Christmas ($8,000), various puppets and props from Gremlins 2, Planet of the Apes, An American Werewolf in London, Hellboy, Mighty Joe Young, Michael Jackson’s Moonwalker, and more, reflecting Baker’s 30‑year career and offering collectors a no‑reserve chance to own iconic Hollywood memorabilia.

Carwyn Scott‑Howell, a seven‑year‑old British boy from Talybont‑on‑Usk, Wales, died while on a ski holiday with his family in Flaine, France, after becoming separated from his mother on the last run of the day, entering dense woodland and falling over a 164‑foot drop; police located his body by following his footprints and sliding marks in the snow, and his family, who described him as daring, outgoing, a competent skier who started at three and modeled himself on Bear Grylls, expressed profound devastation and a “vast void” in their hearts, while friends, school staff, and the local community offered tributes, noting his lively, caring nature and the tragedy’s impact on the community.

Laura Scurr, a 15‑year‑old from Whitley Bay, became obsessed with achieving a “size zero” figure, hiding food and surviving on as little as one piece of fruit a day, which led to severe anorexia, a slowed heart rate and a collapse that required a week on a heart monitor at North Tyneside General Hospital; after receiving support from eating‑disorder services she began recovery, now speaking out about the pressures on teenage girls to be ultra‑thin and has even reached the semi‑final of Miss Teen GB, a contest that promotes confidence‑building experiences away from size‑zero stereotypes.

Liverpool unveiled its 2015/16 home kit—a gingham design with all‑white branding, a memorial flame and “96” tribute to Hillsborough—at Anfield, marking New Balance’s first kit for the club after a record‑breaking £300 million four‑year deal that replaces Warrior; players including Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Martin Škrtel, Simon Mignolet, Jordan Henderson, Adam Lallana and Philippe Coutinho modeled the strip and delivered the “hold nothing back” message while fans urged Sterling to stay, despite his recent rejection of a £100,000‑a‑week contract and Arsenal links, with Liverpool insisting the 20‑year‑old will remain for the season as they look ahead to a FA Cup semi‑final at Wembley and aim for future success.

The University of Manchester team, led by Dr. Sarah Bridle, has released the largest high‑definition map of dark matter to date, covering about 0.4 % of the sky (roughly 150 times the area of the full Moon) and showing red clumps of dense dark matter and blue regions of scarcity; created from early Dark Energy Survey data captured by the 570‑megapixel Dark Energy Camera on the 13‑ft Victor M. Blanco telescope at Cerro Tololo, the map was built by measuring the shapes of 130 million galaxies with precision of one part in 1,000, a process requiring super‑computer power equivalent to 500 desktops for two weeks, and it reveals filaments, voids and the correlation between dark‑matter concentrations and galaxy formation, serving as the first step toward a three‑dimensional map of dark matter and dark energy that will eventually cover 12.5 % of the sky over the survey’s five‑year, 2018‑targeted mission.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven’s 21‑year‑old Dutch international Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal – who previously coached Depay in the Netherlands’ 2014 World Cup squad – eager to make him one of his first summer signings; the move follows Depay’s prolific season in which he has scored 20 goals in 26 league games to help PSV clinch their first Eredivisie title in seven years, and comes after Tottenham’s £15 million bid was rejected and amid interest from Paris‑Saint‑Germain and other top clubs; born in 1994 to a Ghanaian father and Dutch mother, Depay began at VV Moordrecht, moved to Sparta Rotterdam, joined PSV at 12, debuted in 2011 and has over 100 appearances, earning a reputation for pace, dribbling, powerful right‑foot shots and versatility on the left wing, with comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo; internationally, he was first called up by van Gaal in 2013, scored the winning goal against Australia and another against Chile at the 2014 World Cup, and was nominated for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea secured a 3‑1 victory over Manchester City’s youth side at the Academy Stadium, taking a first‑half lead through a double from Tammy Abraham and sealing the win with a late Dominic Solanke strike; Abraham’s two volleys highlighted his dominance, while Solanke’s powerful finish capped the scoring, and the match featured notable contributions from Chelsea’s midfield captain Charlie Colkett, the explosive Kasey Palmer, and solid defensive work from Fikayo Tomori and Jake Clarke‑Salter, whereas City’s efforts were led by Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts, Brandon Barker and a resilient but out‑matched back line that included Tosin Adarabioyo and Ruben Sammut.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, says sexual preference is innate and opposes recognizing same‑sex marriage as a constitutional right, arguing that marriage definitions should be decided by state legislatures rather than courts; nevertheless, he told CBS’s “Face the Nation” and Fusion magazine that he would attend a same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares about, respecting their choice despite personal disagreement, and as a Catholic he views divorce as wrong but would still love a divorced person, while noting his campaign has already secured donor commitments exceeding the $51 million he expects to need for the primary race.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, are a Spanish‑Latvian couple who quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open‑ended, low‑cost cycling odyssey that began in London and, in 356 days, has taken them across 16 countries and nearly 7,000 miles (about 11,132 km) through western and eastern Europe—including France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia‑Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia and Armenia—and they now aim to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the American continent. Living on less than €3 a day (about €0.10 per kilometre), they keep expenses minimal by camping (161 nights in tents, 66 nights via Couchsurfing and 44 nights via Warmshowers), relying on free or donated food such as pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk, seasonal produce, occasional wild fruit and dumpster‑dived items, and only spending roughly €2.74 per day on food. Their journey is documented on their blog “thecrazytravel,” where they share photos, describe the freedom of traveling without a set agenda, and emphasize that their legs provide all transport while kindness from strangers supplies most of their shelter and meals.

A Texas couple who wed in 2012 discovered months after their wedding that James Evans, owner of Premiere Photos, had printed a racial slur on the bottom of photo‑booth snapshots from their celebration at the Beautiful Bell Tower in northwest Houston; after the bride’s sister informed them, the couple hired attorney Cathy Hale and filed a lawsuit under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act alleging negligence and breach of contract, seeking at least an apology, while Evans denied the allegations, claimed no evidence linked his company to the caption and that the couple suffered no mental anguish; mediation is set for the next morning with a trial scheduled for July if no settlement is reached.

Mike Brown, England’s full‑back, said he will take a cautious approach after his latest concussion, admitting he is unsure when he can return for Harlequins and has already pulled out of the club’s Aviva Premiership clash with Saracens; the injury followed a knock that left him unconscious in England’s 47‑17 win over Italy and a subsequent headache after the France game, and his awareness of concussion symptoms—enhanced by World Rugby’s online modules—has led him to prioritize health over rushing back, urging teammates to do the same, while fellow internationals such as Northampton’s George North have been told by specialists not to play again this season after four rapid concussions, and Ireland’s Johnny Sexton previously served a 12‑week stand‑down, highlighting a broader emphasis on player safety.

Smartphone and internet use are being linked to a decline in how often British couples have sex, with a typical heterosexual pair now averaging three encounters per month—down from four in 2000 and five in 1990—according to research cited in Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book *Sex by Numbers*. Spiegelhalter and survey researcher Catherine Mercer attribute the drop to the erosion of boundaries between public and private life as people stay constantly connected to work and social communications, leaving less quiet, uninterrupted time for intimacy; they also note that more people living alone and competing demands on time push sex lower on the list of priorities.

Tibetan mastiffs, massive dogs that can weigh up to 80 kg, were once prized status symbols in China, with a golden‑maned puppy selling for £1.2 million in 2023, but the breed’s fortunes have collapsed as the government’s anti‑corruption drive and bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in cities such as Beijing, Shanghai and Tianjin have halted the practice of gifting them to officials; consequently, many are now being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hot‑pot meat and leather, with rescued dogs found emaciated, injured and dead, while unscrupulous breeders and gangs offload poor‑quality or stolen mastiffs, and rapid urbanisation has further highlighted that the breed is ill‑suited to city life.

A poll of 600 women in the Paris region found that every female user of mass transit has experienced some form of gender harassment or sexual assault—often unrecognized because of normalized low‑level abuse—and half first suffered it before age 18; harassment ranges from insults, insistent flirting, whistling and comments on appearance to sexual attacks or rape, leaving six out of ten women afraid of being attacked on public transport (versus three out of ten men) and forcing many to alter routes, schedules, attire and behavior, effectively excluding them from public life; the report to the French women’s rights ministry prompted calls for a campaign to curb sexist and threatening behavior, with council leaders Pascale Boisard and Ernestine Ronai emphasizing the need for women to recognize these acts as abnormal, for aggressors and witnesses to be reached, and noting that acts such as touching someone’s backside constitute sexual assault punishable by up to five years’ imprisonment and a €75,005 fine.

Leeds‑based Direct Line’s #everydayfix competition asked people to identify their top “everyday emergencies” – a survey of 2,000 respondents highlighted not being able to sleep (46 %), losing keys (37 %), and phone battery loss (31 %) among the most stressful issues – and then invited London design firm Makerversity’s groups to create prototype solutions; three concepts made the shortlist: “Snooze,” an alarm clock that links to a phone and mutes notifications for better sleep; the “Forget Me Lock,” a key‑mounted device that swivels green when the door is open and red when locked to confirm the front door’s status; and “Nipper,” a ultra‑small mobile charger powered by any household battery that plugs directly into a phone, with the public voting on Twitter via retweets to decide which will be funded on Kickstarter by 46 April, while other ideas such as a bone‑conduction helmet, a parking‑space alert pin, and a relay‑app for dead phones did not make the final cut.
