Vera Baird, the Northumbria Police and Crime Commissioner, allocated more than £500,000 of taxpayer money to Victims First Northumbria—a charity she directs—while chief constable Sue Sim sits alongside her on the charity’s board; the funding, made possible after a Home Secretary rule let PCCs commission victim services, has triggered a Ministry of Justice probe amid accusations of a conflict of interest and “soap‑opera” behaviour, with critics deeming the arrangement inappropriate, Sim announcing her retirement in June, and both officials defending the decision as compliant with MOJ procedures.

Three people have been sentenced and two are awaiting sentencing for a brutal assault on 53‑year‑old Greg Valecce in a Philadelphia basement, where he was beaten, tied to a chair and forced to receive offensive tattoos over a 42‑hour period; Corry “Corey” Campbell, 21, the gang’s ringleader, was sentenced to 20 years in state prison, his friend Carl Halin received the same term, and Campbell’s girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, got 23 months, while David Thomas, 28, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, await sentencing or trial; the trio, dubbed “tattoo terrorists,” claimed they acted because Valecce allegedly hurt Campbell’s cat and stole money and weed, and the abuse—captured on video—left Valecce with broken ribs, wrists, facial fractures and lasting psychological trauma despite later having the tattoos removed.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven’s 21‑year‑old Dutch international Memphis Depay, with manager Louis van Gaal eager to secure the winger as one of his first summer signings despite interest from Paris‑Saint‑Germain and other top clubs; Tottenham’s £15 million bid last summer was rejected, and United now appear in pole position. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season and helped PSV clinch their first Eredivisie title in seven years, is praised for his pace, dribbling, powerful right foot and ability to cut inside from the left wing, drawing comparisons to Arjen Robben and a young Cristiano Ronaldo. Born in 1994, he progressed from VV Moordrecht to Sparta Rotterdam and joined PSV at 12, debuting in 2011 and signing his first professional contract in 2012, accumulating over 100 appearances. Internationally, van Gaal gave him his first Oranje call‑up in 2013 and included him in the 2014 World Cup squad, where he scored the winning goal against Australia and was nominated for the tournament’s Best Young Player award.

Chelsea secured a 3‑1 victory over Manchester City’s youth side at the Academy Stadium, taking a first‑half lead through a Tammy Abraham double before Dominic Solanke added a late third‑goal; Abraham’s powerful volleys and Solanke’s finish sealed the win, while City’s efforts were highlighted by Isaac Buckley‑Ricketts’s equaliser, strong defensive displays from Fikayo Tomori, Jake Clarke‑Salter and Bradley Collins, and notable contributions from players such as Kjetil Haug, Pablo Maffeo, Tosin Adarabioyo, Cameron Humphreys‑Grant and others, though several struggled to impact against Chelsea’s attacking pressure.

Marco Rubio, a Florida senator and presidential candidate, says people are born with a sexual preference and that same‑sex marriage should not be a constitutional right, arguing that states—not courts—should define marriage and that any change requires legislative debate; nevertheless, he said he would attend a same‑sex wedding of a family member or staffer he cares about despite disagreeing with the decision, noting his Catholic belief that divorce is wrong but that he would still love a divorced person, and he has already secured donor commitments exceeding the $47 million he expects to need for the primary race.

Pablo Mandado, 27, and Ilze Zebolde, 31, quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on an open‑ended, low‑cost cycling odyssey that began in London and has, in 356 days, covered almost 7,000 miles across 16 countries—including France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia‑Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia and Armenia—with plans to continue into Asia and eventually cycle the length of the Americas; they survive on less than three euros a day by sleeping mainly in a tent (161 nights), using couch‑surfing and Warmshowers (110 nights total), and spending about €2.74 daily on simple foods such as pasta, bread, rice, eggs, milk and seasonal produce, supplemented by occasional meals from strangers and dumpster‑diving, and they document the journey on their blog “thecrazytravel.”

Mike Brown, England’s full‑back, says he will adopt a cautious approach after his latest concussion, admitting he is unsure when he can return for Harlequins and has pulled out of the England‑Ireland Six Nations clash despite hoping to be fit; he emphasizes the importance of recognizing concussion symptoms, a lesson reinforced by World Rugby’s online modules, and warns against risking long‑term absences like those suffered by Johnny Sexton and Geoff Parling. Meanwhile, Northampton’s wing George North has been told by leading medics not to play again this season after sustaining a fourth rapid‑fire concussion, prompting a visit to a neurosurgeon, while other players such as Ireland’s Johnny Sexton have also faced extended layoffs due to head injuries.

Smartphone and internet use are being blamed for a decline in how often British couples have sex, with a typical heterosexual pair now averaging three encounters a month—down from four in 2000 and five in 1990—according to research cited in Professor David Spiegelhalter’s book *Sex by Numbers*. Spiegelhalter and survey researcher Catherine Mercer attribute the drop to constantly checking emails and the erosion of boundaries between work, home and public life, which squeezes out private time, while also noting that more people are living alone and that competing demands push sex down the list of priorities.

Tibetan mastiffs, once prized status symbols in China with prices reaching £1.2 million and given as gifts to officials, have sharply declined in popularity due to the government’s anti‑corruption drive, bans on dogs over 50 kg in major cities, and urbanisation making the large, loyal breed unsuitable for city life; as a result, many are being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hot‑pot meat and leather, with rescued dogs found in cramped cages, some dead or injured, while breeders face a glut of low‑quality, cross‑bred dogs that cannot be sold, leading to a market collapse and widespread cruelty toward the breed.

Leeds‑based Direct Line ran a #everydayfix competition, inviting groups to design products that solve common “everyday emergencies” identified in a survey of 2,000 people (top issues were not being able to sleep, losing keys, traffic, etc.); three prototypes were shortlisted – “Snooze,” an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep, the “Forget Me Lock,” a key‑mounted device that swivels green when the door is open and red when locked, and “Nipper,” a tiny phone charger powered by any household battery – and the public can vote for their favourite on Twitter, with the most‑retweeted product by 40 April moving to a Kickstarter campaign, while other concepts such as a bone‑conduction helmet, a parking‑pin alert system, and a relay‑app for dead phones did not make the final cut.
